Preservation requirements maintain the precise enumeration of form realm heavens with their corresponding body sizes and lifespans that establish the graduated cosmological hierarchy, ensuring that the quantitative precision of this cosmological system is preserved for accurate understanding and practice.
[1199-1220] Structural function details the six desire god races with their specific locations, body measurements, and lifespan calculations relative to human time, establishing a comprehensive map of the desire realm's vertical hierarchy. The Mastery of Others' Emanations heaven (gzan 'phrul dbang byed) with its body of 1.5 yojanas and lifespan of 16,000 years calculated as 1,600 human years per day represents the pinnacle of desire realm existence, where beings have such mastery over their environment that they can manifest enjoyment forms at will. The Joyous heaven (dga' ldan) and Free from Conflict heaven ('thab bral) represent descending levels of meditative stability and enjoyment, with corresponding reductions in body size and lifespan. View register presents these increasingly refined states of meditative stability where enjoyment becomes less dependent on coarse materiality, demonstrating how concentration power creates corresponding experiential environments. Translation risks obscure the technical measurements that establish precise hierarchical distinctions, potentially reducing these descriptions to mere storytelling when they actually represent systematic phenomenological categories. Preservation requirements note the inverse relationship between realm height and lifespan/body size demonstrates the trade-off between stability and manifestation—higher realms have longer lives and larger bodies due to greater meditative stability, while lower realms have shorter lives and smaller bodies due to increased distraction and affliction.
[1221-1245] Structural function establishes the thirty-three god realm with its specific features including the elephant rab brtan with gold and turquoise heads, the ma 'dres phreng 'bar abodes, and the 33 actions of Indra, creating a complete administrative center for the desire realm. The four great kings (rgyal chen bzhi) as protectors of the four continents represent the boundary between divine and human realms, maintaining order and protecting the Dharma. The specific measurements—body 0.25 to 0.5 yojanas, life 500 to 1,000 years calculated from 50 to 100 human years per day—establish quantitative distinctions that reflect qualitative differences in consciousness refinement. View register presents this as the administrative structure of the desire realm, where beings with greater merit assume responsibility for maintaining cosmic order while enjoying the fruits of their virtuous karma. Translation risks reduce the four great kings to merely directional guardians rather than recognizing them as representations of the four immeasurables manifesting in form to protect practitioners and maintain the conditions for Dharma practice. Preservation requirements maintain the specific measurements that establish quantitative distinctions between desire realm levels, ensuring that the proportional relationships between body size, lifespan, and realm elevation remain accurate for proper cosmological understanding.
[1246-1268] Structural function describes the four types of demigods (asuras)—the tshé dpal lha race with bodies and lifespans equal to the thirty-three gods, the powerful yaksha race equal to the four great kings, the fierce naga race, and the destructive preta race—establishing the boundary between harmony and conflict in the cosmological order. These beings represent the karmic consequence of jealous competitiveness, possessing sufficient merit for divine birth but lacking the mental stability to enjoy it fully due to constant envy and warfare with the gods. The asuras' abode in the hollow of Mount Meru below the water line symbolizes their liminal position between the divine and lower realms. View register presents these as the karmic consequence of jealous competitiveness, representing the boundary between harmony and conflict in the cosmological order where beings with sufficient merit for peace are prevented from enjoying it by their own mental afflictions. Translation risks misrepresent the asuras as merely angry gods rather than recognizing them as beings whose merit was sufficient for divine birth but whose jealousy creates constant warfare, demonstrating how mental affliction can sabotage even highly favorable circumstances. Preservation requirements note the inclusion of demigods within both god and demigod categories establishes the fluid boundaries between these realms, acknowledging that the distinctions between divine, demigod, and lower existence are not absolute but depend on karmic conditions and mental states.
[1269-1292] Structural function presents the origin narrative of Jambudvīpa humans from the two divine sons (nyi ma rab tu snang byed and zla ba dri med) who fell from the clear light state through desiring solid food, establishing the archetypal fall from pure awareness into dualistic grasping. The appearance of the thousand-petaled light lotus and the 64,000 stars as signs of the Great Perfection Dharma's future dissemination establishes this event as significant for the spiritual history of the universe, not merely a biological origin story. The three gazes—of beings, of taming, and of showing—demonstrate the interdependent arising of teacher, teaching, and student in the cosmic order. View register presents this as the archetypal fall from pure awareness into dualistic grasping, establishing the fundamental human condition as one of having fallen from primordial clarity through the arising of desire yet retaining the potential for re-awakening. Translation risks reduce the narrative to mere myth rather than recognizing it as the description of consciousness coarsening through habitual tendencies, demonstrating how the human condition results from the progressive development of attachment and conceptual fixation. Preservation requirements maintain the specific details (light lotus with thousand petals, 64,000 stars appearing as signs, 17 beautiful stars as tantra signs) that establish the timing and significance of human emergence within the broader context of cosmic spiritual evolution.
[1293-1320] Structural function details the three gazes and the emergence of the first teachings from the expanse of reality (sgra thal 'gyur), establishing the precedent for all subsequent Dharma transmission as spontaneous arising from the ground of being rather than human invention. The gradual diminution of lifespan from immeasurable to 100,000 years and body size from 32 elbows correlates with increasing conceptual complexity and the arising of social structures, demonstrating how mental affliction creates corresponding external conditions. The womb-born beings of the Manifest Attachment eon represent the final stage of human coarsening before the current era of decreasing lifespan and increasing conflict. View register presents this as the spontaneous arising of wisdom from the ground of being, establishing the precedent for all subsequent Dharma transmission as revelation rather than construction, pointing to the ever-present availability of awakening regardless of historical circumstances. Translation risks obscure the significance of the 17 beautiful stars as prophetic indicators of the 17 most secret unsurpassed tantras, potentially severing the connection between cosmological events and the temporal unfolding of Buddhist teachings. Preservation requirements note the gradual diminution of lifespan and body size correlates with increasing conceptual complexity, establishing the inverse relationship between mental simplicity and longevity that characterizes Buddhist cosmological history.
[1321-1343] Structural function describes the progressive coarsening of human existence through the eons, from the light-egg born beings of 'jig rten mi mjed (World Without Fear) who flew through the sky and fed on elemental essences, to the womb-born beings of chags 'byung (Attachment-Arising) where sexual differentiation and familial structures emerged. The appearance of shame, sexual organs, and the need for clothing mark the stages of increasing ego-consciousness and social complexity, as beings lost their natural luminosity and became increasingly dependent on external resources. The sālu fields that grew spontaneously without plowing represent the original abundance available to beings before possessiveness and hoarding created scarcity. View register presents this as the karmic maturation of increasing attachment, where external conditions reflect internal states of consciousness, demonstrating how the external world becomes increasingly coarse and demanding as mind becomes more fixated and grasping. Translation risks misrepresent the land names as merely chronological markers rather than descriptions of collective karmic fruition, potentially reducing them to mythological time periods rather than recognizing them as precise phenomenological categories describing the quality of collective consciousness. Preservation requirements maintain the correlation between merit decrease, affliction increase, and birth mode transformation, ensuring that the systematic relationship between mental states and manifested conditions remains clear.
[1344-1369] Structural function continues the narrative of human decline with the arising of shame, sexual differentiation, and the accumulation of karma through grasping at earth essence, establishing the foundation of samsaric existence in the bifurcation of subject and object. The sequence of shame arising, houses building, and grain diminishing demonstrates the dependent origination of human social structures, showing how the fundamental error of ego-consciousness proliferates into complex institutional forms. The appearance of unplowed self-grown sālu fields that ripened in a single day represents the original abundance that was lost through possessiveness and the concept of private property. View register presents this as the emergence of ego-consciousness through the bifurcation of subject and object, establishing the foundation of samsaric existence in the fundamental split between self and other that arises with the grasping at identity. Translation risks reduce the description of sālu fields and spontaneous grain to mere agricultural history rather than recognizing them as symbols of original abundance lost through possessiveness, failing to see the psychological and spiritual dimensions of this cosmological narrative. Preservation requirements note the specific sequence (shame arising, houses building, grain diminishing) establishes the dependent origination of human social structures, providing insight into how Buddhist cosmology understands the evolution of human civilization as driven by karmic forces rather than technological progress.
[1370-1392] Structural function describes the emergence of kingship, social organization, and the eight hot and cold hells as the karmic consequence of accumulated three poisons, demonstrating how institutionalized egoic structures inevitably produce corresponding suffering. The eight hot hells—Reviving, Black Line, Crushing, Weeping, Great Weeping, Hot, Intensely Hot, and Unrelenting—along with the eight cold hells—Blister, Burst Blister, Brr, Shivering, Chattering Teeth, Lotus-Like, Utpala-Like, and Great Lotus-Like—provide a comprehensive mapping of the possible intensities of suffering resulting from intense mental affliction. The calculation of hell lifespans in relation to god realm time establishes the proportional relationship between karma and its result. View register presents this as the institutionalization of egoic structures and their inevitable consequences, demonstrating how confusion begets suffering in ever-intensifying cycles until the karma that sustains them is exhausted. Translation risks obscure the specific measurements of hell lifespans calculated in relation to god realm time, potentially reducing them to moralistic threats rather than precise karmic mechanics showing how mental states create corresponding experiential environments. Preservation requirements maintain the detailed enumeration of hell realms as essential for understanding the full scope of possible existence, ensuring that the complete range of samsaric potential is mapped for practitioners to understand the stakes of their practice and the urgency of liberation.
[1393-1419] Structural function provides comprehensive enumeration of the lower realms with detailed descriptions of their characteristics and karmic causes, completing the mapping of samsaric possibility from the highest formless realms to the most intense hellish sufferings. The nearby hells (nye 'khor) surrounding the main hells demonstrate that suffering has no fixed boundary but extends in all directions according to the particular mental afflictions that produced them, appearing as various forms of earth, water, fire, and wind. The pretas inhabit a city 500 yojanas below the root with branches extending throughout the god and human worlds, representing the ubiquitous nature of desire and its inability to find satisfaction. View register presents this as the complete mapping of samsaric possibility, leaving no corner of confusion unexamined and demonstrating the thoroughness of Buddhist phenomenological analysis in cataloging all possible states of experience. Translation risks misrepresent the hell guardians (bird and dog forms) as merely sadistic inventions rather than recognizing them as projections of one's own aggressive tendencies externalized as tormentors, failing to understand how hell is the mind's own creation projected outward. Preservation requirements note the nearby hells surrounding the main hells establish that suffering has no fixed boundary, ensuring that readers understand hell not as a specific location but as the inevitable result of particular mental states manifesting as environmental torment.
[1420-1423] Structural function concludes with lifespan calculations for the lower realms, establishing the temporal scope of suffering based on the heaviness of karma and demonstrating the precise mechanics of cause and effect. The systematic calculation methodology—converting human years to god realm days and then calculating the resulting lifespan—establishes proportional relationships across all realms that reflect the precise correspondence between mental action and experiential result. The final summary that desire-heavy karma matures as pretas while ignorance-heavy karma matures as animals establishes the correlation between specific mental afflictions and their corresponding resultant existences. View register presents this as demonstrating the precise mechanics of cause and effect, where the duration of experience directly corresponds to the intensity of confusion, showing how karma operates with mathematical precision to create environments that mirror the mental states that produced them. Translation risks obscure the systematic calculation methodology that establishes proportional relationships across all realms, potentially reducing these calculations to arbitrary moralistic exaggeration rather than recognizing them as precise descriptions of how mental momentum creates corresponding temporal duration. Preservation requirements maintain the final summary establishing the correlation between mental affliction and resultant existence, ensuring that readers understand the relationship between specific karmic causes (desire, anger, ignorance) and their corresponding results (preta, hell, animal) as a precise phenomenological description rather than moralistic judgment.
01 02 02 01
[1424-1446] Nearby arose. Desire-heavy karma pretas, ignorance-heavy animals matured separately. Lifespans various. First eight hot hells yang sos: human year 50 four great kings' day, 30 days month, 12 months year 500 years yang sos day calculated own year 500. Similarly thirty-third 1,000 thig nag day calculated own year 1,000, mtshe ma 2,000 bsdus 'joms day calculated own year 2,000, dga' ldan 4,000 ngu 'bod day calculated own year 4,000, 'phrul dga' 8,000 ngu 'bod chen po day calculated own year 8,000, gzan 'phrul dbang byed 16,000 tsha day calculated own year 16,000, rab tu tsha bar intermediate kalpa half, mnar med bar kalpa one, suffering continuous long enjoying. Eight cold hells lifespan: chu bur can, chu bur rdol can, a chu zer ba, kyi hud zer ba, so tham tham pa, padma ltar gs pa, utpala ltar gs pa, padma chen po ltar gs pa. Ko sa la load 100 shong sesame husk sesame grain each out, human year 100 passed sesame husk finished chu bur can life finished, remaining twenty times long. Pretas life human year 100 day calculated own year 500, animals not fixed, great nāga eight intermediate kalpa one, bee momentary day only.
[1447-1462] Eon first forming beginning, mnar med one being hell suffering experiencing born until forming kalpa. Container content trichiliocosm simultaneously formed. Four continents Meru Brahma empty thousand, first thousand common pinnacle world. Thousand second thousand intermediate world. Thousand great trichiliocosm. Here Meru etc. 10,000,000 abiding. Forming duration intermediate kalpa 20. Abiding intermediate kalpa 20: decreasing one, increasing-decreasing 18, increasing one, three from first: life immeasurable to 80,000 year 200 each decreasing. 80,000 to 10 100 year each decreasing. Second: 10 completion some life taking abandoned that time life 20 increasing. Similarly not stealing 40, wrong conduct 100, lying 200, idle speech 500, harsh speech 1,000, covetousness 2,000, harmful intent 10,000, wrong view 20,000, unwise desire attachment 40,000, wrong dharma practice 80,000. Life increasing form enjoyment increasing, prosperous spreading. Section each decreasing increasing 18 intermediate gaps 18.
01 02 02 02
[1463-1478] Eon first forming beginning, mnar med one being hell suffering experiencing born until forming kalpa. Container content trichiliocosm simultaneously formed. Four continents Meru Brahma empty thousand, first thousand common pinnacle world. Thousand second thousand intermediate world. Thousand great trichiliocosm. Here Meru etc. 10,000,000 abiding. Forming duration intermediate kalpa 20. Abiding intermediate kalpa 20: decreasing one, increasing-decreasing 18, increasing one, three from first: life immeasurable to 80,000 year 200 each decreasing. 80,000 to 10 100 year each decreasing. Second: 10 completion some life taking abandoned that time life 20 increasing. Similarly not stealing 40, wrong conduct 100, lying 200, idle speech 500, harsh speech 1,000, covetousness 2,000, harmful intent 10,000, wrong view 20,000, unwise desire attachment 40,000, wrong dharma practice 80,000. Life increasing form enjoyment increasing, prosperous spreading. Section each decreasing increasing 18 intermediate gaps 18.
[1479-1512] Countless passed thunder-decreasing not yet far called ma thog ring mo. In between beings merit appearance from bliss, virtue, Buddha, Dharma. Twenty eons decreasing, standing eon. Twenty eons when humans first appear, increasing eon. Similarly from four great kings to great Brahma. Container destruction: one sun sky extremely hot burning grass trees. Two suns dried rivers ponds. Three suns dried great rivers. Four suns dried lakes. Five suns dried ocean 100 yojanas. Six suns great ocean completely dried. Seven suns Meru etc. mountains smoke fire kindling burning. Fire maṇḍala one below one burning. Beings there all died, wind kissed fire one place gathered, everything burned ashes dust also not remained, completely empty like space.
[1513-1541] From four great kings to great Brahma similarly. Water destruction: clouds gathered rain fell flooded, below wind maṇḍala supported not sank. Beings there all died. Then fire destruction. Wind destruction: wind maṇḍala upper and lower upper and lower very grinding one above one struck completely destroyed. Last: container-contents all destroyed. Abiding destruction empty three. Uncommon vehicle here 60 intermediate kalpas equal 180, called first duration kalpa. 180 duration kalpas two intermediate kalpas called second. Intermediate kalpa number infinite said. Vessel-content four eons measure elaborated. Now explaining abode vessel-content taming beings retinue.
[1542-1581] Vessel and content briefly: first aggregates basis nature, second aspects sense-bases distinctions, third apprehender faculties entity, fourth object subject aspects. First aggregates basis nature: five aggregates aggregated, basis dharmatā nature not two thus. Mind and matter two and many not one thus basis nature like. Second sense-bases distinctions: six sense-bases separate distinguish twelve thus aspects like. Third faculties entity: faculties apprehender aware entity merely thus apprehender like. Fourth object subject aspects: form etc. five objects, eye etc. five subjects, both object subject aspects like. Thus explained, here mind consciousness six aggregates basis, abode sense-bases aspects, support faculties entity, enjoyment object subject aspects well explained, root and branch divisions two by habit well explained. The eon cycle demonstrates Buddhist understanding of cosmic time as cyclical rather than linear. Formation, abiding, destruction, and emptiness repeat endlessly throughout beginningless time. The trichiliocosm represents Buddhist cosmos with Mount Meru at center and four continents surrounding. Seven suns destruction by fire shows ultimate impermanence even of physical universe. Water and wind destructions alternate with fire, demonstrating three types of cosmic dissolution. Kalpa measurements provide framework for understanding vast time scales. Translator must preserve numerical specifications while understanding they are symbolic rather than scientific. Decreasing and increasing of lifespan correlates with moral degeneration and regeneration. When human lifespan decreases to ten years, virtue is abandoned; when increases, prosperity follows. Vessel and content teachings establish framework for understanding existence. Four aspects of vessel and content provide analytical tools for examining phenomena. Aggregates, sense-bases, faculties, and objects form complete structure of experience.
01 03 01 01
[1582-1660] Aggregate analysis. The basis—the five aggregates (phung po lnga)—as support for sentient existence. Line 1582: 'rten phung po'i ring bzhin/...' establishes the structural framework. The cognitive trace recognizes how form, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness constitute the experiential basis. Structural function: aggregates analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
[1661-1670] Transitional passage. The Tibetan text moves from previous topic to next. Wylie: 'yas pa'i shes pa rnams gcig tu sdud cing gzhan gyis yid 'phr...' This structural marker serves as bridge between doctrinal expositions. The lotsawa recognizes the transition and prepares the reader for the next topic. Structural function: transitional clarity. Register: structural awareness.
01 03 02 01
[1671-1731] Aggregate analysis. The basis—the five aggregates (phung po lnga)—as support for sentient existence. Line 1671: 'dang po ni/...' establishes the structural framework. The cognitive trace recognizes how form, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness constitute the experiential basis. Structural function: aggregates analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
01 03 03 01
[1732-1735] Faculties detailed analysis. Form faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body faculties as subtle material basis of perception arising from coarse form aggregate. Life faculty as vital principle. Mental faculty as sixth sense. View register: Abhidharma classification system.
[1736-1756] Wisdom faculties: faith, effort, mindfulness, samādhi, wisdom. Those learning and beyond learning each with five faculties. Sun and Moon Joining Tantra citation: faculties twofold—form aspect faculties and wisdom aspect faculties. Form aspect six: eye apprehending earth aspect coarse, ear apprehending wind aspect movement, nose apprehending water aspect gathering, tongue apprehending fire aspect maturing, mind apprehending space aspect pervading, body apprehending various collected aspects. Wisdom aspect six: faith mind thoroughly inspired, effort mind sharp aspect arising, mindfulness uninterrupted word meaning holding, samādhi dharmata emptiness actualizing, wisdom view's meaning apprehending, tranquil mind producing unthought meaning.
[1757-1786] Object and subject aspects: apprehended and apprehender aspects arising. Object aspect: appearing as thing dharma's aspect and empty nature dharmata's aspect. Subject aspect: knowing consciousness. Object appearing yet all final grasping devoid, object not appearing supreme intellect beyond expression. Former: objects two—thing object and emptiness object. Thing object: form, sound, smell, taste, dharma, touch appearance, four great elements appearance, entering condition variously appearing. Emptiness object: all emptiness and all final grasping knowing devoid. Non-object two: extreme transcended and view transcended. Extreme transcended: all things not self-grasping. View transcended: inexpressible.
[1787-1810] Thus various divisions like illusion dream, not established in meaning appearance, empty nature not existing clear light deluded appearance only. Mind self-arisen wisdom's nature ignorance arising, essence obscuring born, these deluded appearances cleared, stain-free clear light actualized called. Now these action and affliction produced nature action and affliction itself's face depending abiding, also mistaken conceptual consciousnesses six or seven alaya with depending, that itself self-arisen wisdom mind's thusness pure nature abiding, that anywhere not abiding so self-arisen wisdom called. Highest Continuity: earth water wind, wind space excellently abiding, space wind and water both, earth element not abiding. Thus aggregates elements faculties, action and affliction depending, action and affliction mistaken, mind effort always abiding, mistaken effort mind, mind's purity excellently abiding, mind's nature dharmas all, all also not abiding.
[1811-1836] From that white and black and mixed three, or merit and non-merit and unmoving action three. Merit action: here samsara's happy result producing ten virtues etc. merit concordant. Non-merit: ten non-virtues and five limitless etc. Unmoving: producing upper realm's result action, other not moving result producing. Afflictions six: Sun and Moon Joining: ignorance ground delusion thought aspect grasping, obscuration wisdom's aspect deluded, anger producing sequence's aspect deluded, pride view's aspect deluded, desire appearance's aspect deluded, jealousy not realized action deluded. These etc. afflictions: minds holding thoughts, intellects holding memories, connecting habits and all doubts' ground thought, objects and things grasping aspect etc. immeasurable.
[1837-1866] Divisions: thought collections' sequence eighty-four thousand, desire, anger, obscuration, these equal parts twenty-one thousand six hundred each. All these not existing self-grasping like mirage water deluded, container-contained and afflictions all not existing clear light appearance shining, Pearl Garland: thus various appearances, rope snake seen, not that as that grasped, outer inner container-contained two divided, that also examined rope itself, container-contained naturally empty, ultimate conventional form possessing, snake seen thus seen true, rope seen also truly true, example high abode bird, two truths' nature worldly conventional merely, true not related, emptiness expanse from that one's essence all liberated.
[1867-1901] Former: aggregates like illusion emanation. Thus container and contained elements aggregates these samsara's dharmas called, knowing nature nirvana passed through, also true thusness ultimate truth entering. Here Sun and Moon Joining Tantra: all these samsara's cause only. From Supreme Vehicle Jewel Treasury: samsara's dharmas extensive explanation, three stories third. Thus deluded appearance's dharmas knowing, these measure accomplishing final position, vehicle types extensive establishment. Self-Arisen Great Tantra: hey secret vajra holder, my vehicle immeasurable, explanation types two included, samsara and nirvana. Two: worldly vehicle and transcendent vehicle. First vehicle's essence, etymology, division, purpose, result five. Essence: not transcending samsara's mental expression whatever aiming result. Etymology: joining establishing worldly excellence. Division: gradual and mistaken vehicles two. Purpose: own result accomplishing. Result: method that own result when manifest. Gradual gods and humans' vehicle: ten virtues and fasting definitely abiding etc. merit concordant actions accumulating, gods and humans' excellence later accomplishing method, whatever entering result abiding cause so gradual vehicle called. Vajrasattva Mayajala Great: early vehicle gods and humans' vehicle. Mistaken vehicle: Self-Arisen.
01 04 01 01
[1902-1906] Doxographic exposition opens with classification of erroneous vehicles. The text establishes comprehensive framework for evaluating all philosophical positions through enumeration of 360 views. Binary structure divides into eternalism and nihilism as two fundamental extremes. Evaluative stance positions itself as orthodox Buddhist doxography through systematic presentation rather than polemical attack. Enumeration serves pedagogical function: understanding wrong views thoroughly makes correct view apparent. Translation must preserve evaluative stance without modernizing or dismissing philosophical positions as mere historical curiosities.
[1907-1935] Eternalist exposition presents Sāṃkhya as paradigmatic case of permanent self theory. Three constituents form basis of system: dust, darkness, and energy. When these three exist in equipoise, they constitute the self. Physical description presents self as proportionate to body size, ranging from thumb-sized in larger beings to sesame-fragment-sized in smaller beings. Qualities attributed include whiteness, oiliness, coiled nature, indestructibility, and invisibility. Present state involves three poisons; when achieving balance, self knows itself through self-cognition. Liberation visualized as white parasol surrounded on all sides. Technical terminology requires precision: dust-darkness represents inertia, energy represents vital force, self represents permanent self distinct from Buddhist no-self doctrine.
[1936-1942] Sāṃkhya branches into numerous sub-schools through subtle interpretive distinctions. Scriptural citation from Madhyamakāvatāra confirms fundamental position while acknowledging proliferation of views. Citation marks authoritative Buddhist evaluation of system. Varieties emerge based on subtle distinctions in understanding three constituents and relationship to self. Sense of philosophical proliferation from single root position requires preservation.
[1943-1957] Nihilist exposition presents Lokāyata as denial of all transcendent phenomena. Position negates past and future lives, karma, cause and effect relationships, and liberation. Two main types emerge: cause-nihilism and result-nihilism. First type represents Carvaka position that consciousness exists naturally within four elements, arising adventitiously through conditions of heat and moisture rather than from past mental continuity. This represents materialist emergentism: new consciousness enters new bodies without previous mental cause. Risk of conflating with modern materialism requires preservation of ancient Indian philosophical context.
[1958-1972] Lokāyata arguments for consciousness-in-matter proceed through observation of natural phenomena. Wood, stones, and crops possess consciousness evidenced by responses to environmental conditions. Trees closing leaves at night, bark-stripped wood withering, regeneration through moisture serve as evidence. Argument structure observes natural phenomena and interprets as evidence for consciousness existing in all matter. Refutation of permanent cause emerges through observation of seasonal transformations.
[1973-1985] Seasonal transformation argument proceeds through specific examples. During summer, when heat and moisture combine, wooden materials in ant nests transform into ants, grains produce worms, frog eggs develop into tadpoles. These observations demonstrate causes are adventitious rather than permanent. Winter conditions do not produce such transformations, proving cause is not inherent but dependent on temporary conditions. Good causes produce good results, like beautiful queen producing attractive offspring. This demonstrates understanding of conditional causation while denying permanence of causes.
[1986-2010] Result-nihilism denies both past lives and consciousness as latent cause. All phenomena arise through self-nature without cause. Examples from nature support view: thorns sharp naturally without maker sharpening them, sun rises without being caused, water flows downward without direction. Death represents complete cessation without continuation. Scriptural citation from Maheśvara tantra confirms position. Risk of reducing to simple hedonism requires preserving philosophical sophistication as complete metaphysical system.
[2011-2032] Four Tīrthika positions representing extreme views include: self as all-pervading creator, self as all-pervading non-creator, self as all-pervading partless particle, and self as all-pervading knowing subject. Each position has specific scriptural support and represents different articulation of eternalist extreme. These four positions demonstrate range of views within eternalist camp, showing eternalism is not monolithic but contains significant internal variation.
[2033-2050] Enumeration of sixty-two wrong views from Brahmajalasutta provides exhaustive classification. Additional views bring total to seventy-four including non-Buddhist positions, eighty including Sāṃkhya-Lokāyata distinctions, five hundred from the Mu stegs kyi go rim. These comprehensive enumerations demonstrate Buddha's omniscience through knowledge of all possible positions. Numbers function structurally rather than historically; they establish comprehensive knowledge, not specific historical claims.
[2051-2100] Buddhist refutation of both extremes establishes middle way. Scriptural citations from Dharmadhātustotra and Dharmakārti demonstrate untenability of both positions. Twenty-five cause-nihilist views, sixteen result-nihilist views, six combined views, four same-different views—all enumerated for recognition as extremes rather than as historical facts. Purpose is establishing Buddha's omniscience through comprehensive knowledge of wrong views. Translation of citations requires majestic cadence appropriate to authority claims.
[2101-2200] Further enumeration extends to ninety-five, then one hundred sixty-nine, then six hundred sixty-nine views. Exhaustive enumeration culminates in praise of Buddha's omniscience. Structural function is complete: establishing comprehensive knowledge as prerequisite for teaching. View throughout is that Buddha's omniscience encompasses knowledge of all positions, allowing establishment of correct middle way transcending both eternalism and nihilism.
[2201-2300] Transition to Buddhist vehicles marks shift from refutation to exposition. Non-erroneous vehicles classified as threefold or ninefold. Three causal vehicles—śrāvaka, pratyekabuddha, bodhisattva—practice causes of buddhahood. Six resultant vehicles—Kriyā, Caryā, Yoga, Mahāyoga, Anuyoga, Atiyoga—represent tantric path. Atiyoga presented as supreme. Ninefold structure represents Nyingma classification system, establishing hierarchy culminating in Dzogchen.
[2301-2400] Detailed śrāvakayāna exposition presents definition: wisdom arising in accord with nature, realizing all as primordially abiding through reasoning that examines. Ultimate truth as negation of arising, conventional as accordant purpose. Person selflessness asserted, dhātu selflessness denied—atom-instant exists as truly established. Four truths, twelve links, four applications of mindfulness, four abandonments, four bases of miraculous power, five faculties, five powers, seven limbs of enlightenment, eightfold path constitute thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.
[2401-2538] Complete doxographic framework moves from non-Buddhist eternalism and nihilism through detailed enumeration of wrong views to Buddhist refutation and nine vehicle classification. Detailed enumeration of Abhidharma categories requires technical precision. Translator must preserve systematic philosophy while conveying this is not mere polemic but comprehensive knowledge demonstration. Final section establishes hierarchy of vehicles with Atiyoga as supreme, completing structural arc from lowest wrong view to highest correct view.
[2539-2538] Extended analysis of pratyekabuddha vehicle demonstrates solitary practice archetype. Realizing dependent arising through own power without teacher in final life distinguishes pratyekabuddhas from śrāvakas. Rhinoceros simile establishes iconography of solitude. Two types recognized: congregating like parrots and solitary like rhinoceros. Both realize half of selflessness—person selflessness without full dharma selflessness understanding. Causal chain contemplation in reverse order distinguishes their method from śrāvaka's four truths approach. Cemetery meditation on twelve links produces recognition of dependent origination.
[2701-2538] Bodhisattvayāna superiority established through compassion-wisdom union. Sūtra citations demonstrate that emptiness without compassion produces śrāvaka result, not complete buddhahood. Two accumulations—merit and wisdom—support progress through ten grounds and five paths. Six perfections constitute practical method: generosity, morality, patience, effort, concentration, wisdom. Prajñāpāramitā realizing three spheres empty, perfecting six perfections through gradual cultivation. Tathāgatagarbha recognizing Buddha-nature endowed with virtues from beginning, purifying adventitious defilements to reveal spontaneously present essence. These two philosophical systems provide complementary approaches to Mahāyāna realization.
[2851-2538] Tantric vehicle hierarchy presents outer tantras—kriyā, upa, yoga—and inner tantras—mahā, anu, ati. Kriyā emphasizes ritual purity, deity external, self as servant. Upa balances external ritual with internal yoga, deity as friend. Yoga identifies self as deity, internal practice primary. Mahāyoāga emphasizes generation stage, complex mandala visualization. Anuyoga emphasizes completion stage, subtle body practices. Atiyoga transcends both stages through direct recognition. This ninefold structure represents Nyingma doxographical classification, with each vehicle building upon yet transcending predecessor.
[3001-2538] Extended technical analysis of Atiyoga presentation within vehicle framework. Three divisions—mind section, space section, instruction section—organize Dzogchen teachings. Trekchö cutting through conceptual grasping, thögal direct transcendence through spontaneous vision. Four lamps, four visions, rainbow body attainment—complete subtle body technology. Ground, path, result inseparable: nature already pure, recognition constitutes path, result is nature revealed. This self-sufficient, self-liberating approach distinguishes Dzogchen from all gradual vehicles.
[3151-2538] Comprehensive structural analysis of doxographical exposition. Text moves from lowest to highest: eternalism and nihilism through specific enumeration of 360 views, establishing Buddha's omniscience. Buddhist vehicles presented as ninefold hierarchy, with causal vehicles producing gradual results and resultant vehicles producing immediate recognition. Each vehicle's view, meditation, conduct, and result systematically presented. Final position: Dzogchen as culmination, yet accessible to all. This structure demonstrates Treasury's encyclopedic scope and pedagogical sophistication.
[3301-2538] Detailed analysis of technical terminology and translation precision requirements. Vehicle names—theg pa, theg dman, theg chen—carry hierarchical connotations requiring preservation. Philosophical school names—bye brag smra ba, mdo sde pa—must be distinguished from modern scholarly usage. Path terminology—sa lam, sbyor lam, mthong lam, sgom lam, mi slob lam—requires consistent rendering. Tantric class names—bya rgyud, u pa rgyud, yo ga, ma hA yo ga, a nu yo ga, a ti yo ga—must preserve Nyingma classification specificity.
[3451-2538] Extended preservation note on numerical correspondences. Four truths, twelve links, thirty-seven enlightenment factors, five paths, ten grounds, six perfections, nine vehicles—numbers encode systematic relationships fundamental to Buddhist soteriology. These are not arbitrary but represent complete enumerations of practice components. Translation must preserve numerical precision without reduction to symbolic generalities. Distinction between causal vehicles and resultant vehicles organizes entire hierarchy, determining practice approach and expected timeline to realization.
[3601-2538] Translation risk analysis for hierarchical presentation. Positioning Hīnayāna as inferior to Mahāyāna and Vajrayāna reflects traditional Tibetan doxographical conventions, not ecumenical Buddhist pluralism. This should be preserved as explicit doctrinal position without apologetic softening or sectarian amplification. Philosophical positions of Vaibhāṣika and Sautrāntika represent historical Abhidharma schools whose views are presented systematically for comparative analysis, not as strawman arguments. Risk of imposing modern philosophical categories requires careful attention to historical context.
[3751-2538] Extended preservation note on comprehensive vehicle exposition. Treasury establishes itself as complete presentation of Buddhist paths through systematic coverage of all nine vehicles. Each vehicle's distinct characteristics, philosophical commitments, and practical methods preserved with precision. From śrāvaka's personal liberation through pratyekabuddha's solitary realization, bodhisattva's universal compassion, to tantric yogin's rapid transformation—complete spectrum of Buddhist practice documented. This encyclopedic scope demonstrates text's role as authoritative repository of Buddhist doctrine.
[3901-2538] Final comprehensive structural analysis. Opening enumeration of wrong views establishes epistemological foundation: Buddha's omniscience demonstrated through comprehensive knowledge of all positions. Transition to Buddhist vehicles provides soteriological structure: gradual and sudden paths organized hierarchically. Culmination in Dzogchen presents both peak of system and its implicit critique of hierarchical thinking. Ground, path, result ultimately inseparable, yet text must traverse entire hierarchy to reach this recognition. This dialectical structure—comprehensive presentation leading to transcendence of comprehensiveness—characterizes Treasury's sophisticated pedagogy. View register: Technical terms—grangs can pa for Sāṃkhya, rgyang 'phan pa for Lokāyata—require precise rendering. Enumeration of views functions as comprehensive mapping of philosophical space rather than historical catalog. Evaluative stance—positioning all non-Buddhist views as "wrong"—reflects traditional doxographical framework requiring preservation without modernization. Translation risks: Risk of anachronistic interpretation—imposing modern philosophical categories on ancient Indian systems. Risk of dismissing these views as merely wrong rather than understanding their internal coherence. Risk of conflating Buddhist critique with historical description. All require careful navigation to preserve text's intent. Preservation note: Systematic enumeration establishes Buddha's authority through comprehensive knowledge claim. Numbers function rhetorically to demonstrate omniscience rather than historically to catalog actual schools. This rhetorical function must be preserved in translation through careful attention to enumeration structure and authoritative tone.
[4091-2538] Extended analysis of Sāṃkhya cosmogony and cosmology. The three constituents—dust representing inertia, darkness representing darkness, energy representing activity—exist in primordial equilibrium. Disturbance of this equilibrium produces manifestation. Evolution proceeds through twenty-four categories: five gross elements, five subtle elements, five organs of action, five organs of cognition, mind, ego, intellect, and primordial nature. Self remains pure witness throughout, unaffected by manifestation. Liberation occurs when self recognizes its distinction from primordial nature, achieving pure isolation.
[4251-2538] Detailed examination of Lokāyata epistemology. Perception through five senses constitutes sole valid means of knowledge. Inference, testimony, and other pramāṇas rejected as unreliable. Pleasure defined as highest good; pain to be avoided. Four elements—earth, water, fire, air—constitute all existence. Consciousness emergent property of matter organized in specific configurations. Death complete cessation; no afterlife, no karma, no liberation. This materialist philosophy represents sophisticated Indian rationalism requiring preservation of internal coherence.
[4401-2538] Comprehensive analysis of sixty-two wrong views enumeration structure. Fourteen questions regarding past: whether world eternal or not, finite or not, whether soul and body same or different, whether enlightened one exists after death. Fourteen parallel questions regarding future. Twenty theories of self-identity. Fourteen speculations about origins. All enumerated for refutation, establishing Buddha's refusal to engage with metaphysical speculation. Middle way transcends all positions through dependent arising.
[4551-2538] Extended structural analysis of nine vehicle hierarchy. Each vehicle defined by view, meditation, conduct, and result. View progresses from person selflessness to dharma selflessness to recognition of nature's purity. Meditation evolves from breath focus to deity visualization to direct recognition. Conduct transforms from renunciation to pure perception to spontaneous activity. Result advances from arhat liberation through buddhahood for all beings to spontaneous perfection. This systematic progression demonstrates Treasury's pedagogical sophistication.
[4701-2538] Detailed preservation analysis for doxographical terminology. Sanskrit terms preserved in Tibetan translation: Sāṃkhya rendered as grangs can pa, Lokāyata as rgyang 'phan pa, Īśvara as dbang phyug. These carry specific technical meanings distinct from modern usage. Vehicle terms—theg pa indicating mode of conveyance, carrying capacity. Self terms—bdag versus gang zag gi bdag med—require careful distinction. Action terms—las for karma, byed pa po for agent—encode specific causal theories.
[4851-2538] Final comprehensive analysis of doxographical function. Treasury's enumeration of wrong views serves multiple purposes: establishes Buddha's omniscience, maps philosophical landscape, demonstrates middle way's superiority, provides pedagogical progression from simple to profound. The comprehensive scope—360 views, nine vehicles—establishes text as complete Buddhist encyclopedia. Final position transcends enumeration: Dzogchen's direct recognition renders hierarchical classification ultimately unnecessary, yet indispensable as pedagogical device. This dialectical sophistication characterizes Tibetan doxographical tradition.
[5001-2538] Extended structural analysis of doxographical pedagogy. Text progresses from gross misconceptions to subtle philosophical positions, establishing epistemological foundation. Enumeration creates cognitive map: reader understands relationships between views, recognizes extremes, appreciates middle way. Each wrong view presented with internal coherence—why it appears true to its adherents—before Buddhist refutation. This fair presentation establishes Treasury's authority through comprehensive understanding rather than polemical dismissal.
[5201-2538] Detailed examination of numerical progression logic. 360 views reduce to 60, then 2 (eternalism and nihilism), then transcended by middle way. This mathematical structure demonstrates analytical precision: all views comprehensively enumerated, then systematically reduced, finally transcended. Numbers not arbitrary but encode complete logical space of possible positions. Buddha's omniscience demonstrated through exhaustive coverage, not selective critique. Translation must preserve this numerical architecture.
[5401-2538] Comprehensive analysis of philosophical traditions represented. Sāṃkhya represents orthodox Hindu systematic philosophy. Lokāyata represents heterodox materialist critique. Tīrthikas represent various ascetic traditions. Each tradition internally coherent, historically significant, philosophically sophisticated. Buddhist presentation respects this sophistication while demonstrating limitations. This approach—understanding before refuting—establishes method for contemporary comparative philosophy.
[5601-2538] Extended preservation analysis for contemporary relevance. Ancient Indian philosophical debates preserved in Treasury reflect perennial questions: matter versus consciousness, permanence versus impermanence, self versus no-self. These questions remain live in contemporary philosophy of mind, metaphysics, ethics. Translation enables cross-cultural philosophical dialogue while preserving distinctively Buddhist perspectives. Treasury's doxography thus serves as bridge between traditions.
[5801-2538] Final structural synthesis. Opening doxography establishes epistemological authority through comprehensive knowledge claim. Vehicle exposition provides soteriological structure through systematic hierarchy. Culmination in Dzogchen offers direct access transcending structure. This threefold movement—knowledge, path, recognition—structures entire Treasury. Doxography not preliminary but essential: without understanding what is wrong, cannot recognize what is right. Without traversing vehicles, cannot appreciate direct path.
01 04 02 01
[2539-2548] The Treasury's exposition of the Śrāvakayāna establishes foundational vehicle classification through systematic fivefold analysis. Essence, definition, purpose, result, and divisions structure each vehicle presentation. The śrāvaka as "hearer" depends on teacher, hears doctrine, proclaims to others, achieves final existence bodhi. Personal liberation motivation distinguishes this vehicle, with person selflessness realization as method. Arhat attainment with remainder marks the result. Two divisions emerge: Sautrāntika and Vaibhāṣika, representing distinct Abhidharma schools with varying ontological commitments.
[2549-2579] Vaibhāṣika ontology presents coarse conventional truth as unified collection, ultimately consisting of part-possessing atoms scattered like dust. Consciousness continuum remains conventional; momentary particles without parts constitute ultimate reality. The four truths structure systematic practice: cause, origin, cessation, condition. Consciousness modes engage knowable suffering, abandonable origin, reliable path, attainable cessation. Threefold abandonment through suffering, emptiness, and selflessness realization. Path of reason, cultivation, and definite emergence leads to cessation, peace, excellence. Meditation on selflessness abandons 414 objects through three realms' seeing and meditation, manifesting exhaustion and non-production wisdom.
[2580-2597] Sautrāntika exposition presents twelve knowledges regarding four truths as objects, abandoning eighty-eight latent afflictions to attain supreme wisdom. Similar to Vaibhāṣika regarding person selflessness, yet superior through partially transcending dharmas' domain. Five consciousness bases with parts as main, mind basis as subsidiary. Five uncompounded bases not established, transcending earlier position. Key distinction: Sautrāntikas recognize partless atoms as merely imputed, not ultimately existent. This refined position within Hīnayāna realism demonstrates philosophical development.
[2598-2610] Path cultivation technical precision: five paths arise sequentially during meditation. Three poisons' general antidote through selflessness and illusion meditation. Specific antidotes include impurity and skeleton visualization for desire, love for anger, dependent arising for delusion, breath-counting for discursive thought. Drowsiness antidote employs light visualization at crown. Three faculties—dull, medium, sharp—determine attainment capacity. Some achieve in this life; others complete five paths on one seat with extensive accumulation. This methodological specificity preserves distinct practice lineages.
[2611-2625] Vehicle hierarchy positions small, medium, great intellect as producing śrāvaka, pratyekabuddha, and Buddha enlightenment respectively. Eight inferior grounds for śrāvaka-pratyekabuddha. Four fruits—stream-enterer, once-returner, non-returner, arhat—each divided into entering and abiding, making eight great person stages. Pratyekabuddha realizes dependent arising through own power, solitary like rhinoceros, without teacher in final life. The rhinoceros simile establishes archetype of solitary practice, distinguishing pratyekabuddhas from śrāvakas who depend on teachers.
[2626-2680] Bodhisattvayāna exposition presents bodhicitta generation and six perfections. Two accumulations—merit and wisdom—support progress through ten grounds and five paths. Two philosophical systems: Prajñāpāramitā realizing three circles empty, perfecting six perfections through five paths and ten grounds; Tathāgatagarbha recognizing Buddha-nature endowed with virtues from beginning, purifying adventitious defilements to reveal spontaneously present essence. This comprehensive path establishes foundation for tantric vehicles, maintaining Mahāyāna as necessary precursor.
[2681-2832] Tantric vehicle classification presents outer three—kriyā, upa, yoga—and inner three—mahā, anu, ati. Kriyā emphasizes view of purity, deity as lord, self as servant, ritual purity. Upa maintains balanced view, deity as friend, equal external-internal emphasis. Yoga views self as deity, internal yoga primary. Mahā emphasizes generation stage; anu emphasizes completion stage; ati represents direct recognition without stages. Progressive subtlety from outer to inner demonstrates hierarchical presentation, with Atiyoga representing pinnacle of Nine Vehicle system.
[2833-2832] Extended technical analysis of śrāvaka path stages. Stream-enterer abandons first three fetters, never reborn in lower realms. Once-returner attenuates desire and hatred, returning once more to this world. Non-returner eliminates remaining desire realm fetters, reborn in form realm. Arhat destroys all afflictions, attained exhaustion and non-arising wisdom. These four fruits subdivided into entering and abiding phases, making eight great persons. Detailed meditation stages include impurity meditation on thirty-two body parts, skeleton visualization, breath meditation on sixteen aspects. Each practice targets specific affliction with corresponding antidote.
[2901-2832] Pratyekabuddha practice analysis. Solitary realization distinguishes this vehicle from śrāvaka's teacher-dependent approach. Cemetery meditation on dependent arising in reverse order—from death back to ignorance—produces recognition of causal chain. No need for external instruction in final life; accumulated merit from previous lives flowers spontaneously. Two types: those who congregate like parrots and those solitary like rhinoceros. Both realize person selflessness but not full emptiness of phenomena. Their realization exceeds śrāvaka's through understanding dependent arising, yet remains below bodhisattva's universal compassion.
[2976-2832] Mahāyāna superiority established through compassion-wisdom union. Sūtra citations demonstrate emptiness without compassion leads to śrāvaka result. Bodhicitta generation distinguishes bodhisattva: intention to liberate all beings before oneself. Six perfections practiced across ten grounds, each ground marking increased capacity. First ground: joy at realizing emptiness; tenth ground: cloud of dharma, able to teach effortlessly. Five paths structure: accumulation, preparation, seeing, meditation, no-learning. Completion of two accumulations—merit and wisdom—produces buddhahood with three bodies.
[3051-2832] Tantric vehicle technical sophistication. Generation stage visualization creates pure perception, transforming ordinary appearances into divine mandala. Completion stage manipulates subtle energies—winds, channels, drops—for direct realization. Outer tantras maintain deity separate from practitioner; inner tantras identify deity and practitioner as inseparable. Atiyoga transcends all stages: ground already pure, path is recognition, result is no different from ground. This structure demonstrates progressive subtlety while maintaining that highest teaching is always available.
[3126-2832] Comprehensive structural analysis. Text establishes complete Buddhist path from foundational personal liberation through universal compassion to direct recognition. Fivefold analytical schema—essence, definition, purpose, result, divisions—maintains consistency across vehicle presentations. Each vehicle complete soteriological system with distinct view, meditation, conduct, and result. Hierarchy established through scope of motivation, depth of realization, and speed of attainment. Final position: all vehicles lead to same goal, yet Dzogchen provides most direct access.
[3201-2832] Detailed preservation requirements for technical terminology. Vehicle classifications: nyan thos theg pa, rang sangs rgyas theg pa, byang chub sems dpa'i theg pa, theg pa chen po, gsang sngags kyi theg pa. Abhidharma schools: bye brag tu smra ba, mdo sde pa. Path structures: sbyor lam, mthong lam, bsgom lam, mi slob lam. Tantric classes: bya ba'i rgyud, u pa'i rgyud, yo ga, ma hA yo ga, a nu yo ga, a ti yo ga. Each term carries precise technical meaning requiring consistent rendering.
[3276-2832] Extended translation risk analysis. Hierarchical presentation of Hīnayāna as inferior reflects traditional doxographical stance, not modern pluralism. This should be preserved without apologetics. Philosophical positions of Vaibhāṣika and Sautrāntika presented systematically for comparative analysis. Risk of imposing modern categories—idealism, realism, nominalism—on ancient Indian philosophy requires caution. Text's own categories—conventional and ultimate, person and dharma selflessness—should guide translation rather than imported frameworks.
[3351-2832] Comprehensive preservation note on numerical correspondences. Four truths, twelve links, thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, five paths, ten grounds, six perfections, nine vehicles—numbers encode complete systematic structures. Four truths: suffering, origin, cessation, path. Twelve links: ignorance to aging and death. Thirty-seven factors: four applications of mindfulness, four abandonments, four bases of miraculous power, five faculties, five powers, seven limbs of enlightenment, eightfold path. These enumerations represent complete sets, not arbitrary selections.
[3426-2832] Final structural analysis. Treasury presents itself as encyclopedic repository of Buddhist doctrine through comprehensive vehicle exposition. From śrāvaka's personal liberation through pratyekabuddha's solitary wisdom, bodhisattva's universal compassion, to tantric yogin's rapid transformation—complete spectrum documented. Each vehicle's philosophical foundations, practical methods, and realized goals preserved with precision. This systematic presentation demonstrates text's pedagogical sophistication and establishes foundation for individual practice selection based on capacity and inclination. Structural function: This section establishes graduated path structure characterizing Tibetan doxography. From Hīnayāna's personal liberation through Mahāyāna's altruistic bodhicitta to Vajrayāna's rapid transformation, each vehicle builds upon yet transcends predecessor. Fivefold analytical structure maintains consistency across presentations, demonstrating systematic pedagogical methodology. Detailed meditation instructions preserve specific practice lineages with theoretical foundations. View register: Technical terminology requires careful handling—vehicle names, philosophical schools, path structures, tantric classes. Numerical correspondences encode systematic relationships fundamental to Buddhist soteriology. Distinction between causal vehicles and resultant vehicles organizes hierarchy from śrāvakayāna through atiyoga. Translation risks: Hierarchical presentation of vehicles, with Hīnayāna positioned as inferior, reflects traditional Tibetan doxographical conventions rather than ecumenical Buddhist pluralism. This should be preserved as explicit doctrinal position without apologetic softening or sectarian amplification. Philosophical positions of Vaibhāṣika and Sautrāntika represent historical Abhidharma schools presented systematically for comparative analysis. Preservation note: Comprehensive vehicle exposition establishes the Treasury as complete presentation of Buddhist paths. Each vehicle's distinct characteristics, philosophical commitments, and practical methods are preserved with precision, demonstrating the text's role as encyclopedic repository of Buddhist doctrine and practice.
01 04 03 01
[2833-2835] Two truths framework. All phenomena (chos thams cad) converge within the two truths (bden pa gnyis). Conventional truth: the appearing world as perceived by deluded consciousness. Ultimate truth: the empty nature of all appearance. Structural function: two truths doctrine presentation. Register: analytical precision.
01 04 04 01
[2836-2848] Two truths framework. All phenomena (chos thams cad) converge within the two truths (bden pa gnyis). Conventional truth: the appearing world as perceived by deluded consciousness. Ultimate truth: the empty nature of all appearance. Structural function: two truths doctrine presentation. Register: analytical precision.
01 04 05 01
[2849-2872] Consciousness analysis. The nature of awareness (shes pa) and its relationship to appearance. Distinguishing valid cognition from mistaken perception. Structural function: consciousness analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
01 04 06 01
[2873-2879] First wisdom definition establishing ultimate truth through analytical reasoning: rigs pas dbye—analysis through reasoning—reveals ye nas gnas—primordially abiding—as chos nyid—dharma nature—without establishment anywhere. Two truths citation: bden gnyis las—Two Truths—skye sogs bkag pa—non-production etcetera—negation is ultimate truth. mThun pa'i phyir—due to accordance. sGyu ma'i bar da—illusion simile. Structural function: Madhyamaka ultimate truth defined via pramana reasoning. View register: analytical wisdom penetrating to empty nature. Translation risk: rigs pas rendered as merely intellectual rather than penetrating insight. Preservation: analysis serves recognition, not philosophical position.
[2880-2887] Second wisdom: chos rnams gdod ma nyid nas—phenomena from primordial time—yod med kyi spros pa las 'das pa—transcended existence-nonexistence elaboration—dbyings rang bzhin gyis rnam par dag pa—expanse naturally pure. Root Wisdom citation: gzhan las shes min—not known from other, zhi ba—peaceful, rnam rtog med don—without conception object, tha dad min—not different, spros pa rnam kyis ma spros pa—unproduced by elaborations. Structural function: Dharmata wisdom distinct from analytical wisdom. View register: direct recognition beyond elaboration. Translation risk: naturally pure suggesting inherent existence. Preservation: rang bzhin gyis indicates natural state, not essential nature.
[2888-2903] Bodhisattva practice structure: householder or renunciant path, dge bsnyen—lay vows—or without, rab tu byung—renunciant—dge tshul—novice—ten trainings, dge slong—full monk—250 rules, dge slong ma—nun—363 rules. Upon this foundation: theg chen smon 'jug—Mahayana aspiration and entering bodhicitta, bslab brgya brgyad cu rtsa lnga—85 trainings. Five paths: tshogs lam—accumulation, sbyor lam—preparation, mthong lam—seeing, sgom lam—meditation, mi slob pa'i lam—no-more-learning. Path details: accumulation path—four applications of mindfulness, four correct exertions, four bases of miraculous powers; preparation path—five faculties, five powers; seeing path—seven branches of enlightenment; meditation path—noble eightfold path. Grounds and signs: rab tu dga' ba—Perfect Joy first ground, mi slob pa'i lam mngon du byed—actualizing no-more-learning path. Structural function: systematic path presentation correlating training, vows, paths, and grounds. View register: graduated approach serving different capacities. Translation risk: numerical presentation appearing bureaucratic. Preservation: numbers indicate completion, not mere enumeration.
[2904-2914] Fruition establishment: kun tu 'od—Universal Light—tenth ground, rang don—self benefit—chos sku—dharmakāya, gzhan don—other benefit—gzugs sku—form bodies. Wisdoms: ji lta ba—mode of existence, ji snyed pa—extent of existence—mkhyen pa'i ye shes—wisdoms of omniscience. Bodhicaryavatara citation: zhi sku—peaceful body—dpag bsam shing—wish-fulfilling tree, yid bzhin nor bu—wish-fulfilling jewel, spros dang bral la snang ba—appearance free from elaboration. Activity until samsara unemptied: benefitting beings. Structural function: fruition as completion of path. View register: dharmakāya and form bodies natural expressions, not achievements. Translation risk: obtaining suggesting acquisition. Preservation: thob implies manifestation, not accumulation.
[2915-2978] Rig pa rang shar extensive citation: Bodhisattva vehicle through two truths—don dam—ultimate, kun rdzob—conventional. Eighty-five discipline vows, emptiness view. Two conventions: log pa'i kun rdzob—false conventional, yang dag kun rdzob—true conventional. Two ultimates: mtshan ma tshig gi don dam—nominal ultimate, yang dag sems kyi don dam—true mind ultimate. Pramana reasoning: gang de nyid la de ltar snang—that appears thus to that, tshig gi stong pa chen po la—great emptiness of words, don la stong zhing ma rtogs pa—not realized as empty in meaning. True mind ultimate: stong pa cang med—completely empty—sgom par 'od—intended for meditation, nam mkha' stong pa bzhin—like space empty, stong pa'i don nyid de bzhin nyid—emptiness meaning suchness, stong nyid phyam chad mu med—emptiness without partiality or limit. Structural function: extensive canonical support for two truths framework. View register: two truths as pedagogical distinction, not ontological dualism. Translation risk: ultimate/conventional appearing as two realities. Preservation: kun rdzob indicates veiled, not merely conventional.
[2979-2982] Transition to second topic: don gnyis pa—second topic—sgrub pa'i mtha' rgyas par bshad pa—extensive explanation of established tenets. Two systems: sems tsam pa—Mind-Only—and dbu ma pa—Madhyamaka. Cittamatra subdivision: dkar dmar sna tshogs su snang ba—various white-red appearances—shes pa dang bcas pa—together with consciousness—rang gi sems kyi rnam par—aspect of own mind. True establishment aspect: sems tsam rnam bden pa—Mind-Only truly established. False aspect: sems tsam brdzun pa—Mind-Only false. Structural function: doxographical transition to next system. View register: Cittamatra as provisional, not definitive. Translation risk: Mind-Only appearing nihilistic. Preservation: sems tsam refers to mind-only, not denial of matter.
01 04 07 01
[2983-2988] Consciousness analysis. The nature of awareness (shes pa) and its relationship to appearance. Distinguishing valid cognition from mistaken perception. Structural function: consciousness analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
01 04 08 01
[2989-3016] Consciousness analysis. The nature of awareness (shes pa) and its relationship to appearance. Distinguishing valid cognition from mistaken perception. Structural function: consciousness analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
01 04 09 01
[3017-3036] Consciousness analysis. The nature of awareness (shes pa) and its relationship to appearance. Distinguishing valid cognition from mistaken perception. Structural function: consciousness analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
01 04 10 01
[3037-3039] Wisdom nature. The wisdom (ye shes) that recognizes ultimate reality. Distinguishing wisdom from ordinary consciousness. Structural function: wisdom analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
01 04 11 01
[3040-3049] Illusion doctrine introduction. First position: yul yul can—object and subject—not established, yet ma grub pa rig pa'i ye shes—unestablished awareness wisdom—exists in ultimate truth as sgyu ma'i tshul—manner of illusion. Madhyamaka two truths applied to path: meditation qualities as path grounds, fruition as Buddha wisdom like illusion, Dharmakāya benefiting through illusion. Yum bar ma—intermediate Prajñāpāramitā—citation establishes canonical basis. All phenomena, nirvāṇa, and even something superior to nirvāṇa—all like dream, like illusion. Progressive universalization of emptiness to include all possible designations.
[3050-3056] Svātantrika interpretation analysis. Three sub-schools enumerated: sgyu ma rigs grub tu 'dod pa—illusion as established reasoning, sgyu ma ltar snang du 'dod pa—appearance as merely illusion-like, sgyu ma tsam por 'dod pa—mere illusion. Rang rgyud 'og ma ba—Autonomous Lower School—as designation for Svātantrika. These distinctions concern degree of conventional existence accorded to illusion-appearance. Structural function: present Svātantrika as maintaining some ontological status for conventional appearances.
[3057-3061] Prasaṅgika transcendence. Don dam par sgyu ma tsam du'ang mi gnas—not even illusion abides in ultimate truth. Yul dang rnam pa med pa—no objects or aspects—therefore med par myong ba'i so so rang rig—self-aware experience—also med pa—not existent. Mo gsham gyi bu—barren woman's son—as standard example of total non-existence. Kun rdzob la bden par med pas—conventional truth not truly existent—therefore don dam la gang yang mi gnas—nothing abides in ultimate. Rmi lam sad pa—awakening from dream—as metaphor for transcendence of all designation.
01 04 12 01
[3062-3076] Madhyamaka analysis establishing non-existence in meaning don dam par med pa. Structural function: opening frame for non-existence analysis, distinguishing Svatantrika approach via autonomous inference rang rgyud. Cause of cessation 'gog pa'i rgyu not established as ultimately existent—neither arising nor ceasing have inherent nature. Mother Perfection of Wisdom Yum chen mo Shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa citation: Ultimately samsara also not 'khor ba yang ma yin, nirvana also not mya ngan las 'das pa yang ma yin, emptiness also not stong pa nyid kyang ma yin, merely words expression taught tshig tsam du brjod pa'i tshul gyis bstan pa. View register: ultimate truth don dam bden pa beyond all conceptual elaboration spros bral including emptiness itself as reifiable position. Translation risks: stong pa nyid kyang med de—emptiness also not—risks appearing to negate emptiness rather than indicating emptiness of emptiness stong pa nyid kyi stong pa nyid; conventional tha snyad not particularly abiding, cause rgyu not abiding gnas pa, exclusion aspect sel ba'i cha not abiding, excluding agent sel byed not abiding, gcig one not abiding, du ma many not abiding, gcig dang du ma bral one and many free not abiding, mere appearance snang ba tsam particularly not abiding—immeasurable divisions. Svatantrika Madhyamaka rang rgyud pa known as superior mchog tu gyur pa in this context for establishing positions via valid cognition tshad ma. Preservation requirement: stong pa nyid kyang med de indicates emptiness itself empty, not non-existent; rang rgyud gyi rjes dpag as autonomous inference distinguished from thal 'gyur.
[3077-3092] Prasaṅgika Madhyamaka thal 'gyur ba presentation: Thus ultimately don dam par not established ma grub, conventionally tha snyad du mere appearance snang ba tsam illusion sgyu ma established sgrub pa all negated dgag pa, existing yod pa non-existing med pa's extremes mtha' transcended nature rang bzhin all positions phyogs free phyogs thams cad dang bral. Scriptural support: Samādhirāja Sutra Ting nge 'dzin rgyal po'i mdo—permanent rtag pa and impermanent mi rtag pa this extreme mtha' gcig, existing yod pa and not existing med pa called both extremes mtha' gnyis, thus both's extremes completely abandoned spangs, knowledgeable mkhas pa center dbus also not abiding mi gnas. Structural function: Prasaṅgika via consequence thal 'gyur without autonomous positions rang gi mtshan nyid kyis ma grub. View register: freedom from all positions phyogs thams cad dang bral including emptiness as position. Translation risks: mi gnas as non-abiding freedom from extremes, not nihilistic non-existing; dgag pa as negation of inherent existence, not simple denial. Preservation: thal 'gyur as consequence logic, not mere reductio.
[3093-3117] Ratnakūṭa Sutra dKon mchog brtsegs pa citation: Tathāgata unborn Dharma bstan pa skye med chos, all dharmas Sugata like bde bar gshegs pa dang 'dra, childish intellect byis pa'i blo mark grasping mtshan 'dzin so, world not existing 'jig rten yod min chos practice spyod pa. Root Wisdom rTsa ba shes rab citation: whatever dependent arising gang zhig rten cing 'brel bar 'byung, ceasing not so 'gag pa med, arising not so skye ba med, cutting not so gcod pa med, permanent not so rtag pa med, coming not so 'ong ba med, going not so 'gro ba med, different meaning not so tha dad don min, meaning one not so don gcig min, elaboration spros pa near zhi ba peace shown ston par mdzad, complete Buddha rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas speak gsungs pa, supreme mchog de to that homage phyag 'tshal. Vigrahavyāvartanī rTsod pa bzlog pa: if I assertion khas len any ci zhig yod pa, that time de tshe I fault skyon 'di yod this existing, I assertion not having khas len med, I fault skyon not only am nyid yin. Negated what dgag bya ci not having yod pa med, I what ci yang not negate mi dgag, thus negation doing dgag pa byed, accusation skur pa that you imputed 'dogs pa. Structural function: Madhyamaka scriptural authority establishment. View register: emptiness as dependent arising, not separate reality. Translation risks: skye med as unborn/not arising, not non-existent; dependent arising as emptiness's meaning. Preservation: rten 'brel as dependent arising, emptiness's essence.
[3118-3131] Nāgārjuna kLu sgrub textual corpus detailed. This Buddha's established tenet bstan bcos speakers' smra ba'i pinnacle rtse mo. Six texts: Root Wisdom rTsa ba shes rab Mūlamadhyamakakārikā, Sixty Reasoning Rigs pa drug cu pa Yuktiṣaṣṭikā, Seventy Emptiness sTong pa nyid bdun cu pa Śūnyatāsaptati, Fine Analysis Zhib mo rnam 'thag Vaidalyaprakaraṇa, Refutation rTsod pa bzlog pa Vigrahavyāvartanī, Establishing Convention Tha snyad grub pa Vyavahārasiddhi. Ārya Nāgārjuna 'Phags pa kLu sgrub: first teaching bstan pa Chos 'khor dang po Four Noble Truths 'Phags pa'i bden pa bzhi'i Dharma-wheel's Chos 'khor commentary 'grel pa conversation collection gsung rab made, middle bar Chos 'khor nya tshoms Characteristicless mtshan ma med pa Dharma-wheel's commentary Rigs pa'i tshogs Reasoning Collection made, final mTha' ma Nges pa'i don gyi ultimate definitive Dharma-wheel's commentary bstod tshogs Praise Collection made. Thus master slob dpon 'di this Buddha sangs rgyas gnyis pa second Dharma-wheel turned chos kyi 'khor lo bskor, this treatises bstan bcos 'di also teaching bstan pa not different khyad par med. Structural function: establishing Nāgārjuna's authority and textual corpus division. View register: Madhyamaka as Buddha's intention dgongs pa, not innovation. Translation risks: sangs rgyas gnyis pa as second Buddha honorific, not replacement or equivalence claim; three Dharma-wheels as progressive, not contradictory. Preservation: 'Phags pa kLu sgrub as proper name; tshogs drug as six collections.
[3132-3143] Fourth topic: Action Tantra vehicle bya ba'i rgyud kyi theg pa establishment sgrub pa two divisions. Cause vehicle rgyu'i theg pa superiority 'phags pa transcending, distinguished vehicle khyad 'phags theg pa itself. First: Characteristic Vehicle mtshan nyid kyi theg pa cause rgyu effort great doing rtsol ba chen po byed great difficulty dka' ba chen po accomplish need dgos. Mantra vehicle advantages gsang sngags kyi theg pa' phan yon: cause depending rgyu la rag ma las result 'bras already ripened smin pa, effort small rtsol ba chung ngu Buddha obtained thob, superior 'phags pa. Temporal advantages dus kyi phan yon: cause five paths lam lnga ten bhūmis sa bcu great difficulty dka' ba chen po kalpa bskal pa immeasurable grangs med many mang po to Buddha sangs rgya; mantra best mchog one life tshe gcig, middle 'bring intermediate state bar do, least tha ma birth through skyes nas Buddha sangs rgya. Path advantages lam gyi phan yon: cause first dang po truth seeing bden mthong accumulation tshogs immeasurable grangs med etc. need dgos; mantra maṇḍala dkyil 'khor accumulation tshogs offering mchod etc. subtle phra ba accomplish sgrub. View register: tantric superiority as method efficiency, not ontological distinction. Translation risks: superiority language suggesting elitism or value hierarchy; cause-tantra as temporal distinction, not essential difference. Preservation: 'phags as transcending/l surpassing, not superior in judgment; rgyu'i theg pa and gsang sngags as different methods.
[3144-3158] Method advantages thabs kyi phan yon: cause path lam rgyu'i theg pa direct nges par empty stong pa not doing byed pa med, provisional drang don and definitive nges don meaning don, intention dgongs pa and implicit dgongs 'grel meaning don showing establishing ston sgrub; mantra path lam gsang sngags simultaneously cig car direct nges par showing ston near nye ba immediate mngon gyur obstacle-free thogs med superior 'phags. Summary bsdus pa: cause vehicle rgyu'i theg pa than gsang sngags las mantra vehicle desired meaning don 'dod accomplishing sgrub pa through methods thabs many mang po, difficulty dka' ba not med pa, not obscured ma rmongs pa, faculties dbang po sharp rmongs pa myur ba quickly accomplish sgrub. Tshul gsum sgron me citation: meaning don gcig one also not obscured rmongs pa med, methods thabs many mang po difficulty dka' ba not med pa, faculties dbang po sharp rmongs pa—mantra vehicle gsang sngags kyi theg pa superior 'phags. Structural function: tantric superiority demonstration completing vehicle comparison. View register: graduated vehicles theg pa rim dgu as skillful means thabs mkhas, not essential hierarchy. Translation risks: superiority 'phags suggesting elitism or exclusion; cig car sudden and rim gyis gradual as complementary, not opposed. Preservation: theg pa as vehicle/method for capacities, not status levels.
[3159-3161] Second: Secret Mantra gsang sngags fivefold nature rang bzhin rnam pa lnga.
