Essence ngo bo: self-arisen wisdom rang byung ye shes expanse dbyings clear light 'od gsal truth bden pa direct mngon sum realizing rtogs pa method thabs supremely secret yang gsang. Divisions dbye ba: development bskyed rim completion rdzogs rim spontaneous lhun grub expanse dbyings measuring tshad pa types rigs. Structural function: transitioning to tantric framework with definitional structure. View register: tantra as direct path lam mngon gyur to clear light 'od gsal recognition. Translation risks: yang gsang as secret/esoteric in sense of profound, not hidden knowledge; gsang ba as protected, not concealed. Preservation: rang byung as self-arising, not self-created.
[3162-3170] Development stage bskyed rim generation bskyed pa. Self-arisen deity rang byung gi lha from emptiness stong pa las. Three samadhis ting nge 'dzin gsum: suchness de bzhin nyid, all-illuminating kun tu snang ba, causal rgyu. Divine pride lha'i nga rgyal vajra recitation rdo rje bzlas pa. Structure: deity yoga lha'i rnal 'byor as method for recognizing emptiness's clarity gsal ba aspect. View register: visualization visualization as skillful means thabs mkhas, not ultimate reality. Translation risks: deity generation lha bskyed appearing literal reification; three samadhis as stages, not separate meditations. Preservation: bskyed rim as developmental/generation stage, not mere creation; lha as yidam, not generic god.
[3171-3180] Completion stage rdzogs rim dissolution rdzogs pa. Energy channels rtsa, winds rlung, essences thig le. Four empties stong pa bzhi, clear light 'od gsal, illusory body sgyu lus. Structure: subtle body phra ba'i lus yoga rnal 'byor leading to clear light. View register: completion rdzogs as recognition of primordially present ye nas yod pa'i clear light, not produced. Translation risks: subtle body appearing material anatomical; four empties as progressive, not hierarchical. Preservation: rtsa rlung thig le as energetic anatomy, not gross physical.
[3181-3195] Great perfection rdzogs pa chen po beyond grol ba both gnyis ka. Trekcho khregs chod cutting through khregs chod conceptual mind rtog pa'i sems. Thogal thod rgal direct mngon gyur transcendence rgal ba. Structure: atiyoga as pinnacle theg pa'i rtse mo. View register: dzogchen transcends both development and completion, not negates. Translation risks: grol ba as transcending<span class="term">/beyond, not negating/</span>rejecting; khregs chod as cutting through obstacles, not destroying. Preservation: thod rgal as direct/leapover, not skippng stages.
[3196-3220] Integration of paths lam mthun sbyar. Lower vehicles theg pa dman pa as gradual rim gyis, higher mchog as direct cig car. All vehicles theg pa thams cad lead to same recognition ngo shes. Structure: hierarchical dang po'i mtha' la thug but inclusive. View register: different methods thabs for different capacities dbang po, same destination 'bras bu gcig. Translation risks: hierarchy suggesting inequality; cig car and rim gyis as contradictory rather than complementary. Preservation: theg pa as vehicle<span class="term">/method for capacities, not status levels; dbang po as faculties/</span>capacities, not moral worth.
[3221-3235] Atiyoga distinctive characteristics. Beyond cause and effect rgyu 'bras las 'das. Beyond effort and attainment rtsol sgrub las 'das. Beyond view and meditation lta sgom las 'das. Beyond acceptance and rejection blang dor las 'das. Structure: dzogchen as freedom from all dualistic frameworks. View register: primordial purity ka dag as always already pure, not achieved. Translation risks: beyond las 'das appearing as rejection; freedom from appearing as negation of valid methods. Preservation: ye nas as primordially<span class="term">/from the beginning; rang bzhin as natural/</span>nature, not essence.
[3236-3251] Concluding synthesis bsdus pa'i don. Svatantrika and Prasaṅgika as methods for different capacities. Madhyamaka as Buddha's intention dgongs pa. Tantra as swift method myur lam. Dzogchen as direct recognition dngos bstan. All lead to same emptiness stong pa nyid recognition ngo shes. Structure: hierarchical presentation with inclusive destination. View register: skillful means thabs mkhas accommodating all capacities without hierarchy of value. Translation risks: hierarchical presentation implying spiritual elitism; emptiness as goal rather than nature. Preservation: dgongs pa as intention, not hidden meaning; ngo shes as recognition, not achievement.
[3252-3281] Practice (sgrub) analysis. The sadhana structure: preliminary, main practice, conclusion. Generation stage: visualizing the deity. Completion stage: dissolving into dharmakaya. The practice's purpose: direct recognition of Buddha-nature. Register: technical precision. Structural function: cognitive trace maintenance.
[3282-3311] Activity (las) analysis. The four actions: pacifying, enriching, magnetizing, destroying. Each activity corresponds to specific deity family and wisdom aspect. The practitioner applies appropriate method for each situation. Register: technical precision. Structural function: cognitive trace maintenance.
[3312-3312] Activity (las) analysis. The four actions: pacifying, enriching, magnetizing, destroying. Each activity corresponds to specific deity family and wisdom aspect. The practitioner applies appropriate method for each situation. Register: technical precision. Structural function: cognitive trace maintenance.
01 04 13 01
[3317-3321] Doctrinal analysis. The Tibetan establishes the structural framework for understanding. Wylie: 'rig ma bsten pa la sogs pa blang dor dan...' marks the topic introduction. The cognitive trace follows the textual exposition with precision. Structural function: doctrinal exposition presentation. Register: analytical precision.
[3313-3340] Transitional passage. The Tibetan text moves from previous topic to next. Wylie: 'dang po ni/ phyi pa gsum gyis dkar gsum la sogs pa bsten zhi...' This structural marker serves as bridge between doctrinal expositions. The lotsawa recognizes the transition and prepares the reader for the next topic. Structural function: transitional clarity. Register: structural awareness.
01 04 14 01
[3341-3341] Detailed section enumeration: eighteen tantras of mind section, twenty-one of space section, hundred and nineteen of instruction section. Specific titles: Klong drug, Sgra thal 'gyur, Rig pa rang shar, etc. Enumeration establishes comprehensiveness. Not necessary to memorize; preserve sense of vast textual basis.
[3350-3370] Four kāyas exposition: dharmakāya, sambhogakāya, nirmāṇakāya, svabhāvikakāya. Buddha form dimensions as complete manifestation structure. Dharmakāya as essence, sambhogakāya as enjoyment, nirmāṇakāya as emanation, svabhāvikakāya as nature. Not sequential stages but simultaneous aspects. Translate *sku bzhi* as four kāyas consistently. Risk of reifying as separate entities; maintain aspect-nature relationship.
[3371-3410] View analysis: emptiness-luminosity union without separation. Non-dual understanding free from extremes. Not emptiness alone, not luminosity alone, but inseparable. *Stong gsal dbyer med* as technical formulation requiring precise rendering. Beyond existence and non-existence extremes. Dzogchen view register distinct from Madhyamaka negation. Preserve positive formulation of unity.
[3411-3450] Buddha qualities enumeration: ten powers, four fearlessnesses, eighteen distinct qualities. Standard Mahāyāna list of enlightened attributes. Ten powers: knowing appropriateness, ripeness, faculties, inclinations, paths, dhyānas, deaths-births, exhaustion, origins, cessation. Four fearlessnesses: claim of enlightenment, claim of cessation of obscurations, claim of teaching obstacles, claim of teaching path. Eighteen distinct: six unmixed, six unconfused, six unsurpassed. Enumeration preserves traditional structure without requiring verification.
[3451-3490] Meditation analysis: non-meditation and non-distraction. Natural abiding without contrivance. Beyond meditation and non-meditation duality. Not "not meditating" but meditation without meditator. *Sgom pa* negated as effortful, *ma yengs* affirmed as natural. Dzogchen meditation register distinct from gradual path techniques. Risk of nihilistic interpretation; preserve naturalness.
[3491-3530] Conduct exposition: beyond acceptance and rejection. Spontaneous activity without contrivance. *Spyod pa* as natural expression of view, not behavioral code. *Blang dor med*: nothing to adopt, nothing to reject. *Lhun grub*: spontaneous, not effortful. Three kāyas conduct: dharmakāya conduct as view, sambhogakāya as meditation, nirmāṇakāya as activity. Preserve spontaneity against ritualization.
[3531-3570] Result analysis: self-liberation and primordial purity. Spontaneous perfection already complete. Not attainment but recognition. *Rang grol*: liberated by itself, not by effort. *Ka dag*: pure from beginning, not purified. Result as ground revealed, not produced. Fruition fivefold: dharmakāya free from elaboration, sambhogakāya five-certainties, nirmāṇakāya benefit-beings, svabhāvikakāya indivisible, mahāsvabhāvikakāya uncompounded. Translate technical terms consistently across text.
[3571-3610] Samaya vows exposition: root and branch commitments. Dzogchen samaya distinct from lower vehicles: not external observance but recognition. Root: not losing view. Branch: compassion, devotion, activity. Violation as losing recognition, not breaking rules. Self-liberated in view means samaya self-maintained. Risk of license; preserve seriousness without ritualism.
[3611-3650] Path of unity: view, meditation, conduct, result as one. Not sequential but simultaneous. Ground, path, result inseparable. Trekcho and thogal as aspects, not stages. Atiyoga as complete in itself, not requiring other vehicles. Self-sufficient, self-liberating. Dzogchen as peak vehicle, yet equally available. Maintain both superiority and accessibility.
[3651-3690] Lineage transmission: mind transmission of buddhas, sign transmission of vidyādharas, oral transmission of individuals. Three streams converging. Masters of India and Tibet enumerated: Garab Dorje, Mañjuśrīmitra, Śrī Siṃha, Jñānasūtra, Vimalamitra, Vairocana, Nyima Özer, Nyima Döndrup, Zhonnu Özer. Specific names require accurate rendering. Geographical origins: Uḍḍiyāna, India, Tibet. Lineage as authority warrant.
[3691-3720] Teaching classification: six million four hundred thousand tantras of great perfection. Mind section, space section, instruction section. Black, white, variegated categories. Compilation history: who revealed, who concealed, who compiled. Klong chen rab 'byams pa as compiler of this text. Historical specificity as authentication device.
[3342-3349] Transitional passage. The Tibetan text moves from previous topic to next. Wylie: 'sems nyid don dam spros bral chen pos khyad par du byas pas ...' This structural marker serves as bridge between doctrinal expositions. The lotsawa recognizes the transition and prepares the reader for the next topic. Structural function: transitional clarity. Register: structural awareness.
01 04 15 01
[3731-3740] Structural function establishes the basis analysis framework through threefold classification of existence, non-existence, and both. The dzogchen view register operates at the level of spontaneous liberation without dependent origination. Translation risks include rendering "klong dkar po" as mere metaphor rather than recognizing its technical designation for expansive white space. Preservation requirements demand maintaining the distinction between the three khra bo factions and their alignment with sems sde, rang gnad, and man ngag traditions.
[3741-3750] Structural function presents the first khra bo faction aligned with sems sde, emphasizing the inseparability of appearance and mind. View register maintains the primordial purity of dharmatā without acceptance or rejection. Translation risks obscure the technical meaning of "rang dag gnas grol" as self-purified abiding liberation. Preservation requirements note the critical distinction between this view and lower vehicles through the phrase "tha snyad bya rtsol las 'das pa."
[3751-3760] Structural function introduces the second khra bo faction focused on appearance as self-liberated without cause. View register asserts that virtuous and non-virtuous actions lack inherent existence. Translation risks misrepresent "med snang" as mere non-appearance rather than appearance of emptiness. Preservation requirements ensure the technical term "'gyur ba stong yal" retains its specific meaning of empty transformation.
[3761-3763] Structural function completes the triad with the third khra bo faction integrating both extremes through oral instructions. View register presents the three essential points of ineffability, non-meditation, and unchanging nature. Translation risks conflate the three gnad into generic spiritual advice. Preservation requirements maintain the precise technical vocabulary distinguishing these three keys as unique to the man ngag sde tradition.
[3764-3765] Structural function establishes the two categories of klong dkar po related to vast action and view-meditation integration. View register positions these as expressions of the ocean-like expanse where primordial purity manifests without effort. Translation risks render "las rgya che ba" as mere magnitude rather than recognizing its technical sense of vast activity without causal origination. Preservation requirements maintain the distinction between the ocean expanse and sky expanse as separate categories with specific characteristics.
[3721-3730] Transitional passage. The Tibetan text moves from previous topic to next. Wylie: 'dang po ni/ shar sna tshogs rgyu med du shar bas snang ngo r...' This structural marker serves as bridge between doctrinal expositions. The lotsawa recognizes the transition and prepares the reader for the next topic. Structural function: transitional clarity. Register: structural awareness.
01 04 16 01
[3766-3777] Structural function establishes the two categories of klong dkar po related to vast action and view-meditation integration. View register positions these as expressions of the ocean-like expanse where primordial purity manifests without effort. Translation risks render "las rgya che ba" as mere magnitude rather than recognizing its technical sense of vast activity without causal origination. Preservation requirements maintain the distinction between the ocean expanse and sky expanse as separate categories with specific characteristics.
[3778-3785] Structural function details the great ocean expanse through self-abiding emptiness and primordial liberation. View register emphasizes the single wheel of great transcendence dwelling in emptiness. Translation risks lose the technical precision of "yin rang 'das chen po" as a specific classification. Preservation requirements note the phrase "stong pas gang du yang grub pa med par" establishes the view of emptiness without established existence anywhere.
[3786-3796] Structural function introduces the sky expanse with its two divisions of sun-moon expanse and jewel-white expanse. View register presents the essence of dharmatā as unalterable self-liberation. Translation risks misinterpret "rin po che'i klong dkar po" as metaphorical rather than technical terminology. Preservation requirements ensure the spontaneous perfection of qualities and self-purification of causes and conditions remains distinct from lower vehicle concepts.
[3797-3808] Structural function presents the rab 'byams sde through the essence of appearance known by mind and non-appearance known by natural state. View register classifies four types of vastness: external, internal, secret, and suchness. Translation risks conflate these categories without recognizing their hierarchical relationship. Preservation requirements maintain the three essential points of causelessness, conditionlessness, and non-establishment of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa as foundational to the external vastness.
[3809-3817] Structural function continues the external vastness exposition emphasizing the non-division of mind through absence of cause. View register asserts the natural state as spontaneously perfect great completion without partiality toward any vehicle. Translation risks obscure "gnas lugs ye rdzogs" as a specific technical classification. Preservation requirements note the phrase "gang yang ma spangs par yongs su rdzogs" establishes the non-rejection completion principle unique to dzogchen.
[3818-3827] Structural function presents the secret vastness through recognizing obstacles to appearance as self-liberated pure nature. View register maintains the completion of memory and thought as dharmatā. Translation risks misrepresent "dran bsam rang dag" as mere purified thought rather than the technical process of thought recognizing its own nature. Preservation requirements ensure the distinction between outer and inner obstacles remains clear.
[3828-3837] Structural function synthesizes the vastness categories into three divisions through the aspiration-arising great completion. View register presents the fourfold framework of view, meditation, conduct, and fruition. Translation risks conflate "bya spyod chos nyid du grol ba" with lower vehicle conduct concepts. Preservation requirements maintain the technical precision of "thob pa med pas ma thob pa rang la bzhag pa" as fruition without attainment.
[3838-3839] Structural function concludes the action-free expanse through the principle of liberation without action. View register establishes "bya ba med pas grol bas grol" as the essential formulation. Translation risks render this as mere passivity rather than spontaneous liberation. Preservation requirements note this phrase encapsulates the entire klong dkar po section's essential meaning.
[3841-3846] Structural function introduces the ornament expanse through appearances as mind-stream and emptiness free from grasping. View register presents the non-arising non-ceasing contemplation. Translation risks misinterpret "rgyan gyi klong" as decorative rather than functional ornament. Preservation requirements maintain the citation "mi skye mi 'gag cir mi dgongs" as canonical support.
[3847-3858] Structural function presents the play expanse and dharmatā expanse through unceasing manifestation and unaltered self-arising. View register emphasizes the unity of appearance and knowledge. Translation risks conflate "rol pa'i klong" with ordinary play. Preservation requirements ensure the technical term "mthong shes gnyis su med pa" retains its precise meaning of non-dual view and knowledge.
[3859-3869] Structural function transitions to the direct approach oral instruction section, establishing three teaching styles. View register presents the me btsa' analogy for hitting the essential point. Translation risks obscure "lam drang thad du smra ba" as merely straightforward rather than technically direct. Preservation requirements distinguish the three styles: scattered speech, conversational speech, and sutra self-commentary style.
[3840-3840] Transitional passage. The Tibetan text moves from previous topic to next. Wylie: 'zhes so/...' This structural marker serves as bridge between doctrinal expositions. The lotsawa recognizes the transition and prepares the reader for the next topic. Structural function: transitional clarity. Register: structural awareness.
01 04 17 01
[3870-3870] Structural function transitions to the direct approach oral instruction section, establishing three teaching styles. View register presents the me btsa' analogy for hitting the essential point. Translation risks obscure "lam drang thad du smra ba" as merely straightforward rather than technically direct. Preservation requirements distinguish the three styles: scattered speech, conversational speech, and sutra self-commentary style.
[3871-3882] Structural function details the scattered speech style through cutting the path extreme and manifesting the power-liberated path. View register presents the ineffability of dharmatā without letters. Translation risks misrepresent "spros gzhi'i tshig tsam du yang ma grub" as mere poetic expression. Preservation requirements note the specific technical vocabulary establishing causeless action and spontaneous liberation without practice.
[3883-3887] Structural function introduces the conversational speech style through thought-free natural state without delusion. View register presents the non-dual characteristics free from grasping. Translation risks render "glen pa yengs la bor ba" as mere distraction rather than the technical process of releasing fixation. Preservation requirements maintain the four essential points of wind, channels, body-mind disconnection, and self-liberation of movement.
01 04 18 01
[3888-3888] Wisdom-space (*ye shes kyi klong*) threefold analysis. First position: emptiness pervasion without path dependence. Word basis of elaboration non-existent. Inexpressible dharmatā.
[3888-3892] Four vital points of Anuyoga. Nāḍī-wind placement. Body-mind disconnection. Movement self-liberation.
01 04 18 02
[3893-3897] Structural function introduces the conversational speech style through thought-free natural state without delusion. View register presents the non-dual characteristics free from grasping. Translation risks render "glen pa yengs la bor ba" as mere distraction rather than the technical process of releasing fixation. Preservation requirements maintain the four essential points of wind, channels, body-mind disconnection, and self-liberation of movement.
[3898-3911] Structural function presents the sutra self-commentary oral instruction as the source of all teachings cut by suchness. View register establishes the non-difference of nature and cessation of saṃsāra support. Translation risks conflate this with lower vehicle sutra concepts. Preservation requirements note the technical term "stong nyid rtsod gzhi dang bral ba" establishes emptiness free from debate objects.
[3912-3914] Structural function introduces the four divisions of view, beginning with the bundle-sealed style. View register distinguishes between appearance as view without contrivance and realized mind as view. Translation risks misrepresent "sgang dril" as mere compression. Preservation requirements maintain the technical precision of the view classifications as specific to man ngag sde.
[3915-3921] Structural function continues the view exposition through absence of Buddha name, appearance as view, and measureless view-meditation. View register presents the three characteristics of essence, nature, and marks. Translation risks obscure the technical meaning of "ltos gzhi rang zad." Preservation requirements ensure the threefold liberation of afflictions, absence of acceptance-rejection, and exhaustion of paths remains distinct.
[3922-3928] Structural function introduces the obstacle-removing lancet style through cutting the boundary between saṃsāra and nirvāṇa. View view register establishes the threefold supportless nature. Translation risks misrepresent "gtar ka" as mere criticism. Preservation requirements note the two divisions of view-meditation warmth obstacle removal and entity dwelling obstacle removal.
[3929-3949] Structural function details the view-meditation warmth obstacles through the three stages of unstable, attained, and stable. View register presents the similes of recognizing bandits, adding wood to fire, and army victory. Translation risks render these as mere pedagogical flourish rather than precise technical descriptions. Preservation requirements maintain the specific analogies for each stage and their correspondence to view, meditation, conduct, and fruition. The section concludes with the threefold essential point of conduct purifying appearance, meditation removing movement obstacles, and view removing dharmatā obstacles.
[3950-3958] Structural function concludes the entity-dwelling obstacle removal through absence of cause-effect in nature and absence of habituation in marks. View register establishes the root of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa as rotten through investigation. Translation risks misrepresent "rtsa ba rul ba" as mere metaphor. Preservation requirements introduce the hidden-revealed section with its two divisions: one hidden revealing two, and two hidden revealing one.
[3959-3971] Structural function details the first pattern where view and conduct revealed hide meditation. View register presents union without beginning or end cutting the extremes of saṃsāra and nirvāṇa. Translation risks conflate "zung 'jug" with tantric union concepts. Preservation requirements ensure the four combinations of hiding and revealing maintain their technical precision.
[3972-3976] Structural function introduces the fourth self-clarifying explanation style through cutting word attachment. View register establishes establishment as supreme through non-dwelling. Translation risks render "tshig zhen rgyun chad" as mere intellectual critique. Preservation requirements note the three divisions of delusion-pursuing style, delusion-reversing style, and self-nature thigle placement.
[3977-3988] Structural function establishes the delusion-reversing style through cutting the root of delusion as ignorance. View register presents three approaches: cutting delusion at the root, leaving delusion self-purified, and emptying the delusion basis. Translation risks conflate these with path-based methods. Preservation requirements maintain the distinction between "rtsad nas bcad" as decisive cutting versus gradual purification.
[3989-3993] Structural function details the three approaches through essence, nature, and marks. View register establishes self-arising wisdom as first awareness and delusion-never-experienced as expansion. Translation risks misrepresent "rang rig pa dang po" as ordinary self-awareness. Preservation requirements note the technical term "khams gsum dong sprugs" as specifically dzogchen terminology.
01 04 19 01
[3994-4004] Structural function establishes the threefold natural state through essence, nature, and marks as the foundation for understanding delusion-never-experienced, non-abiding in delusion, and impossibility of future delusion. The progression creates temporal logic showing the ground nature transcends three times while remaining basis for samsara and nirvana. View register operates within Dzogchen <span class="term">/ Natural State /</span> Timeless Awareness. Key terms include "'khrul pa" (delusion), "rang byung ye shes" (self-arising wisdom), "khams gsum dong sprugs" (shaking three realms to their foundation). The ground nature is never stained by delusion in past, does not dwell in delusion in present, and will not experience delusion in future, yet remains basis for both samsara and nirvana without duality. Translation risks include misrepresenting "'khrul pa" as mere confusion rather than fundamental delusion creating samsara, and rendering "rang byung ye shes" without capturing its technical meaning as wisdom arising spontaneously without causes or conditions. The phrase "khams gsum dong sprugs" specifically means shaking three realms to their foundation, not merely purifying them. Preservation priorities maintain distinction between three aspects (essence, nature, marks) and temporal structure of past-never-experienced, present-non-abiding, future-impossible. The non-dual nature of samsara and nirvana sharing single ground must remain clear. Extended recognition: The term "thig le rang gnas" (thigle self-abiding) represents bindu remaining in its own place without movement, the indecomposable nature of awareness. "Spra bral" and "spros pa dang bral ba" indicate ineffable nature transcending conceptual designation.
[4005-4014] Structural function introduces thigle self-abiding nature through freedom from elaborations and beyond words, establishing direct introduction producing decisive confidence. Presents oral transmission (snyan rgyud) as means transmitting nature of reality from master to student without interruption. View register operates within Dzogchen <span class="term">/ Oral Transmission /</span> Direct Introduction. Oral transmission characterized by uninterrupted continuity, proximity of distinction, connection to auditory sense power, and freedom from obstruction by others. Letterless oral transmission of dharmatā meaning oral instructions represents highest form transcending verbal expression while still functioning as transmission. Translation risks include conflating "snyan rgyud" with ordinary oral instruction when it specifically refers to unbroken lineage of direct mind-to-mind transmission. The distinction between "yi ge dang bcas pa" and "yi ge med pa" must be preserved as technical taxonomy. Preservation priorities maintain hierarchy of transmission methods, with letterless oral transmission of dharmatā meaning oral instructions representing pinnacle. Simultaneity of factors—unobstructed connection to auditory sense power, freedom from interruption, decisive confidence with liberation—must be presented as structural features of authentic oral transmission. Extended recognition: Oral transmission represents one of three main Dzogchen lineages alongside mind transmission and sign transmission. The emphasis on continuity reflects understanding that realization must be transmitted through unbroken lineage to retain its power.
[4015-4039] Structural function introduces explanatory transmission through four cycles: outer, inner, secret, and unsurpassed secret. Each cycle presented through essence, nature, and marks, creating systematic presentation of progressively subtle teachings. Outer cycle establishes five poisons as path without abandonment; inner cycle presents non-material nature of dharmatā; secret cycle introduces simultaneity of recognition and attainment; unsurpassed secret cycle reveals non-reliance on words and direct perception. View register operates within Dzogchen <span class="term">/ Four Cycles /</span> Progressive Revelation. Outer cycle transforms five poisons into path without requiring abandonment, reflecting essential Dzogchen view that afflictive emotions are wisdom when recognized. Secret cycle presents three simultaneities: recognition and attainment occurring simultaneously, breath cessation and buddhahood occurring simultaneously, buddhahood and compassion arising simultaneously. Translation risks include rendering four cycles as merely hierarchical rather than structurally distinct pedagogical approaches. The phrase "dug lnga lam khyer la gnas" requires careful handling to avoid suggesting antinomian practices without proper view. Three simultaneities must be preserved as technical statements about nature of realization. Preservation priorities maintain systematic presentation of four cycles and respective characteristics. Three simultaneities in secret cycle—ngo sprad pa dang rtogs pa thob pa dus mnyam pa, dbugs chad pa dang sangs rgyas pa dus mnyam pa, sangs rgyas pa dang thugs rje 'byung ba dus mnyam pa—represent crucial technical formulations. Extended recognition: Three simultaneities reflect Dzogchen understanding that realization is not gradual process but occurs instantaneously when proper conditions present. Simultaneity of breath cessation and buddhahood refers to moment when conceptual mind ceases and non-conceptual wisdom arises.
[4040-4059] Structural function concludes unsurpassed secret cycle through non-reliance on words, direct perception, and four visions reaching their measure. Transitions to summary enumeration of Dzogchen textual corpus: nine expanses, twenty-one thousand chapters, three sections, thirty-five thousand chapters, eight great insertions, one hundred eighty nails, one thousand five hundred obstacles, seven thousand distinctions, one hundred fifty thousand cycles, five thousand essential points, sixty-four thousand ślokas, twenty thousand named tantras. View register operates within Dzogchen <span class="term">/ Four Visions /</span> Textual Corpus. Unsurpassed secret cycle establishes complete reliance on wisdom means not abiding in view holding to intellectual examination. Four visions reaching their measure without depending on fruition reflects Dzogchen view that fruition is not something to be achieved in future but already present. Translation risks include conflating "mngon sum du mthong" with ordinary direct perception when it specifically refers to direct recognition of natural state without conceptual mediation. Enumeration terms must be preserved as technical bibliographic categories rather than rendered as generic terms. Preservation priorities maintain distinction between unsurpassed secret cycle and lower cycles, particularly regarding non-reliance on words and direct perception. Four visions reaching their measure must be preserved as technical description of completion of Dzogchen practice. Extended recognition: Four visions represent progressive stages of thögal practice: direct realization of dharmakāya, experience of increased vision, reaching full measure of awareness, exhaustion of phenomena into reality.
[4060-4085] Structural function presents summary citation from Thal 'gyur tantra establishing all enumerated teachings emerge from Great Perfection of natural state. Verse summarizes textual organization: from three sections come nine expanses, from condensed words come thirty-four thousand ślokas, from which emerge thirty-five thousand chapters, twenty-one thousand bam po, subjects equal to extent of space. Synthesizes into three sections: sems sde, klong sde, and man ngag sde, with sems sde subdivided into three expanses. View register operates within Dzogchen <span class="term">/ Three Sections /</span> Nine Expanses. Three expanses of sems sde: expanse of dharmatā being ineffable, expanse of view having no existence-nonexistence, expanse of conduct having no existence-nonexistence. These establish radical non-duality of Dzogchen view and practice. Translation risks include misinterpreting "bam po" and "'phyong" as mere literary divisions rather than technical bibliographic categories. Three expanses must be preserved as technical terms describing ineffable nature of dharmatā and non-duality of existence and nonexistence. Preservation priorities maintain authority of Thal 'gyur citation and three-section organizational framework. Three expanses represent crucial doctrinal formulation establishing ineffability of dharmatā, non-duality of view, non-duality of conduct. Extended recognition: Thal 'gyur is one of seventeen tantras of man ngag sde, key canonical source for Dzogchen. Three sections represent historical organization into distinct lineages: sems sde focusing on nature of mind, klong sde on expanse/space dimension, man ngag sde on practical oral instructions.
[4086-4121] Structural function synthesizes textual categories of three sections into condensed summaries with precise numerical correspondences. Sems sde enumeration shows condensation from five thousand named tantras through progressive reduction. Klong sde enumeration shows condensation from three thousand named tantras, with three insertions: liberation through action, liberation through resting, bare liberation. View register operates within Dzogchen <span class="term">/ Textual Condensation /</span> Numerical Correspondences. Enumeration represents traditional ways of organizing vast Dzogchen literature. Three insertions in klong sde represent three approaches to liberation corresponding to different capacities of practitioners. Translation risks include rendering enumeration as merely symbolic rather than preserving technical precision of numerical correspondences. Terms "shan 'byed", "gags", "gnad", "gzer bu", "'phyong" must be preserved as technical bibliographic categories. Preservation priorities maintain precise numerical relationships between different levels of condensation. Three types of liberation—through action, resting, bare—must be preserved as distinct categories. Extended recognition: Three types of liberation represent three approaches corresponding to gradual, spontaneous, and instantaneous capacities of practitioners.
[4122-4154] Structural function completes enumeration with man ngag sde, subdivided into three expanses: expanse of display ceasing without interruption, expanse of mind not liberating through intellect, expanse of essence without good or bad. Enumeration continues with twelve thousand named tantras through progressive condensation to three insertions: expansion of essential points, seeing essential points, knowing essential points. Concludes categorizing all as both canonical teachings and treatises, with treatises subdivided into tantras, scriptures, and oral instruction treatises. View register operates within Dzogchen <span class="term">/ Oral Instruction Section /</span> Three Expanses. Three expanses represent most subtle teachings: display without cessation reflects continuous nature of manifestation; non-liberation through intellect indicates realization transcends conceptual mind; essence without good or bad establishes absolute equality of natural state. Translation risks include conflating three expanses of man ngag sde with those of sems sde when they represent distinct formulations. The phrase "blo la ma grol ba med pa'i klong" must indicate there is no liberation through intellect, not that mind is unliberated. Preservation priorities maintain distinct characteristics of man ngag sde and its three expanses. Three insertions—gnad spro ba, gnad mthong ba, gnad shes—must be distinguished from three insertions of klong sde. Extended recognition: Man ngag sde represents most extensive section of Dzogchen teachings containing practical instructions for realization. Three expanses reflect unique characteristics: uninterrupted nature of display, transcendence of intellectual liberation, absolute equality of essence.
[4155-4171] Structural function transitions to next major section on nature of tantra, establishing six topics: essence of tantra, definitive terminology, classification, extent of arising, examples, and establishment of validity. Begins systematic analysis of tantra as vehicle for teachings, establishing tantra as that which causes beings to be born in whichever class or family they belong to, with definitive etymology explaining "rgyud" as continuity that is decisive and uninterrupted. View register operates within Dzogchen <span class="term">/ Tantra /</span> Definitive Characteristics. Sixfold presentation follows standard Buddhist scholastic methods. Etymology of rgyud as that which causes birth in specific families and as decisive uninterrupted continuity establishes both soteriological function and structural characteristic of tantra. Classification into natural/essential tantra and textual tantra begins the typology. Translation risks include rendering "rgyud" merely as "tantra" without preserving etymological meanings of continuity and causation of birth in families. Distinction between "rang bzhin don gyi rgyud" and textual tantras must be preserved as fundamental classification. Preservation priorities maintain sixfold structure and specific etymological derivations. Definition of tantra as both that which causes birth in families and as decisive uninterrupted continuity must be preserved as two aspects of single definition. Extended recognition: Distinction between natural tantra and textual tantra parallels distinction between natural nirvana and attained nirvana. Natural tantra refers to continuity of awareness itself, while textual tantras are teachings that reveal this continuity.
01 05 01 01
[4172-4282] Consciousness analysis. The nature of awareness (shes pa) and its relationship to appearance. Distinguishing valid cognition from mistaken perception. Structural function: consciousness analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
01 05 02 01
[4283-4306] Structural function establishes the two primary approaches to Dzogchen practice: Trekchö (khregs chod) as the path for those with instantaneous faculties (dbang po cig car ba) who recognize primordial liberation without return to the ground, and Thögal (thod rgal) as the gradual path for those with progressive faculties (dbang po rim gyis pa) who utilize the key points of channels and winds to achieve liberation. The preliminary practices (sngon 'gro gsum) and direct pointing to one's own condition (mngon sum rang gnad la 'bebs pa) serve as the foundation for both approaches, establishing the necessary preparation before engaging in the main practice. The three key points of body (lus gnad), gates (sgo'i gnad), and objects (yul gyi gnad) provide the technical framework for practice, while the integration of wind and awareness (rlung rig gi gnad) creates the conditions for realization. View register presents these two paths not as contradictory but as skillful means adapted to different capacities, both leading to the same recognition of the four visions (snang ba bzhi) and liberation. Translation risks obscure the technical distinction between cig car ba (simultaneous/sudden) and rim gyis pa (gradual) faculties, potentially reducing these to psychological types rather than recognizing them as descriptions of karmic propensities that determine appropriate method. Preservation requirements note the specific threefold key points (lus, sgo, yul gnad) that constitute the technical vocabulary of Dzogchen practice, ensuring that these precise instructions are transmitted rather than generalized into vague meditation advice.
[4307-4327] Structural function details the specific body postures (lus kyi gnad) through three animal metaphors: lion posture (seng ge'i tshul), elephant posture (glang chen tshul), and rishi posture (drang srong lta bu), establishing physical supports for meditation that facilitate the recognition of mind nature. The gate key points (sgo'i gnad) emphasize non-movement (ma 'gul) of the gates themselves and the two clarity-producers (gsal byed rnam gnyis), creating the condition where even space itself remains unmoving. The object key points (yul gyi gnad) establish three modes of abiding: the pure expanse abiding (dag pa'i dbyings ni sdod pa), the nature of awareness abiding (de bzhin rig pa'i ngo bo sdod), and all appearances abiding (snang ba thams cad sdod pa). These technical instructions create a comprehensive framework for practice that addresses body, sense faculties, and perception simultaneously. View register presents these physical and perceptual techniques not as ends in themselves but as supports for recognizing the unchanging nature of mind, demonstrating how relative practice creates conditions for absolute realization without ever leaving the ground of primordial purity. Translation risks reduce sgo to merely "doors" without recognizing it as the technical term for sensory gates (sgo drug), or misinterpret ma 'gul as physical stillness rather than the non-movement of dualistic grasping at sensory experience. Preservation requirements maintain the specific animal metaphors for body postures, which encode not merely physical positions but the quality of presence (confidence for lion, stability for elephant, naturalness for rishi) that each posture is designed to cultivate.
[4328-4353] Structural function presents the second type of rgyud (continuity/tantra) as rang bzhin gyi rgyud (nature tantra), encompassing the meaning of ground, path, and result (gzhi lam 'bras bu'i don). The essence (ngo bo) is identified as empty-clear-awareness (stong gsal rig pa), while the definitive terminology (nges tshig) establishes that it pervades all and has the nature of producing buddhahood. This nature tantra is divided into three: ground nature tantra (gzhi rang bzhin gyi rgyud), essence nature tantra (snying po rang bzhin gyi rgyud), and nectar nature tantra (bcud rang bzhin gyi rgyud), each representing a different aspect or perspective on the same fundamental nature. View register presents these three divisions as different ways of approaching the same reality—ground emphasizing primordial purity (ka dag), essence emphasizing the spontaneous presence of ye shes, and nectar emphasizing the ripened result of practice—demonstrating how Dzogchen integrates view, meditation, and result into a seamless whole. Translation risks interpret rang bzhin merely as "nature" in a general sense rather than recognizing it as the technical term for the intrinsic nature of mind that is neither produced nor destructible, the ground of all appearance without being tainted by it. Preservation requirements note the threefold division into gzhi, snying po, and bcud establishes a complete framework for understanding how the nature of mind manifests as view, meditation, and result, ensuring that readers understand these as integrated aspects of a single reality rather than sequential stages.
[4354-4381] Structural function elaborates the ground nature tantra (gzhi rang bzhin gyi rgyud) as the original kadag rigpa possessing essence, nature, and compassion (ngo bo rang bzhin thugs rje gsum), establishing the triune structure that characterizes Dzogchen ontology. The essence is primordially pure (ka nas dag pa) without even the name of ignorance, meaning that delusion is a superimposition never actually experienced by the nature of mind itself. The nature is spontaneously accomplished (lhun gyis grub pa) with rigpa clear as light, indicating that awareness is self-illuminating without dependence on external conditions. The compassion is all-pervasive (kun la khyab pa) with arising and ceasing never blocked, demonstrating that the dynamic display of appearance is inseparable from the ground. View register presents this triune structure as the foundation of Dzogchen view, where primordial purity, spontaneous presence, and all-pervasive compassion are not sequential attainments but simultaneous aspects of the nature of mind as it always already is. Translation risks reduce thugs rje to merely "compassion" in the conventional sense of wishing others free from suffering, rather than recognizing it as the technical term for the dynamic, manifestation-capacity of awareness that responds spontaneously to the needs of beings without conceptual intervention. Preservation requirements note the specific formulation ka dag, lhun grub, thugs rje gsum as the three fundamental aspects of Dzogchen view, ensuring that these are transmitted as technical terms with precise meanings rather than general spiritual vocabulary.
[4382-4410] Structural function presents the essence nature tantra (snying po rang bzhin gyi rgyud) as the ye shes sum brtsegs (three-stacked wisdom) arising in the heart as essence, representing the potential for the four visions (snang ba bzhi) to manifest through the opening of the four lamps (sgron ma bzhi) from the eyes. The nectar nature tantra (bcud rang bzhin gyi rgyud) is described as the ripened result of practicing the vision of rigpa, characterized by emptiness without falling into marks, permanence without grasping extremes, and self-appearance of emptiness without falling into nihilism. The three clarities (gsal ba gsum), three confidences (gdeng gsum), and three non-reversions (mi ldog pa gsum) establish the qualities that accompany realization of the bcud rgyud. View register presents these progressively subtle aspects—ground as the base, essence as the potential, and nectar as the result—as demonstrating the continuity (rgyud) of Dzogchen practice, where the nature of mind never changes but its recognition deepens and ripens through practice. Translation risks obscure the technical reference to sgron ma bzhi (four lamps) as the subtle physiological and perceptual conditions for the manifestation of thögal visions, potentially reducing this to metaphor when it describes actual meditative experiences. Preservation requirements note the three clarities, three confidences, and three non-reversions constitute specific attainment-markers in Dzogchen practice, ensuring that these technical terms are preserved with their precise meanings rather than generalized into vague spiritual qualities.
[4411-4440] Structural function continues the detailed presentation of bcud rang bzhin gyi rgyud, emphasizing the non-duality of emptiness and clarity (stong gsal dbyer mi phyed) as the actual nectar of rigpa, which when ripened to completion is called bcud (nectar/essence). The progression through dangs ma gsum (three pure essences) and gsal ba gsum (three clarities) to the ultimate fruition of the three kayas and wisdoms demonstrates the path structure within the nature tantra framework. The three visions (snang ba gsum) of the expanse without day and night, awareness without clarity-obscuration, and dharmata without change-transformation establish the perceptual characteristics of full realization. View register presents these progressively refined descriptions as demonstrating that Dzogchen realization is not a single event but a deepening recognition that transforms all aspects of experience, from gross perception to the subtlest levels of appearance, into the display of wisdom. Translation risks misrepresent dangs ma as merely "pure" without recognizing it as the technical term for the subtle essence of the elements in the completion stage, or confuse snang ba thams cad with ordinary perception rather than recognizing it as the transformed vision where all appearance is seen as deity and pure land. Preservation requirements note the specific progression from ground through essence to nectar represents the Dzogchen understanding of the path as recognition (rtogs pa) rather than transformation (bsgyur ba), ensuring that this fundamental distinction is maintained.
[4441-4475] Structural function establishes the relationships between the various rgyud classifications, demonstrating that thabs kyi rgyud (method tantra) and rang bzhin gyi rgyud (nature tantra) are both aspects of gzhi rigpa (ground awareness), with the former representing the pointing-out (mtshon byed) and the latter the pointed-out (mtshon bya). The five different names—method tantra, nature tantra, ground, essence, and nectar—all refer to the single nature without transcending its essence, like different names for the same person. This integration establishes that all Dzogchen teachings, regardless of classification, point to the same reality of primordial purity and spontaneous presence. The three rgyud—ground, essence, and nectar—are explained as rgyud (continuity) because they connect all beings: all buddhas and sentient beings arise from the ground, recognition establishes the buddha-continuity, non-recognition establishes the sentient-being-continuity, making the ground itself the basis for both. View register presents this classification system as demonstrating the comprehensive scope of Dzogchen, which accounts for both the absolute nature and the relative methods, both the ground of being and the path of recognition, without ever confusing or conflating these two truths. Translation risks reduce the intricate classification system to mere scholasticism rather than recognizing it as the precise mapping of the relationship between view, meditation, and result that guides practitioners through the complexities of Dzogchen practice. Preservation requirements note the specific logic of why gzhi is called rgyud—because it serves as the ground (gzhi) for both samsara and nirvana, connecting all beings regardless of their recognition—ensuring that readers understand rgyud not merely as "tantra" in the sense of scripture but as "continuity" describing the unbroken nature of awareness.
[4476-4510] Structural function cites multiple scriptural sources including Mu ti phreng ba, Sangs rgyas rnam kyi gsang chen, and others to establish the definitive meaning of nature tantra as ground, essence, and nectar, demonstrating the scriptural basis for these classifications across Dzogchen literature. The metaphor of the king, minister, and subjects (rgyal blon 'bangs gsum) illustrates the relationship between the three heart-essences (rgyud kyi snying po gsum) of rig pa rang shar, rang grol, and yi ge med pa, showing how mastery of these three brings control over all tantras like a king controlling his realm. The metaphor of reaching three mountain peaks (ri gsum rgyi rtser phyin pa) illustrates the three pure essences (rgyud kyi dangs ma gsum), demonstrating how knowledge of these brings understanding of all tantras' inner meaning. View register presents these metaphors as skillful means to convey the hierarchical yet integrated relationship between different aspects of Dzogchen teaching, where understanding the essence brings mastery of the details without needing exhaustive study of every textual classification. Translation risks interpret these metaphors literally as descriptions of social or geographical hierarchies rather than recognizing them as pedagogical devices conveying the relationship between principle and application, between view and its elaboration. Preservation requirements note the multiple scriptural citations establish the universality of these classifications across Dzogchen lineages, ensuring that readers understand these are not idiosyncratic to a single teacher but represent the shared understanding of the Great Perfection tradition.
[4511-4545] Structural function presents the detailed classification of the seventeen tantras (rgyud bcu bdun) of Thal 'gyur (Disentangled Sound), providing both their metaphorical names and their functional descriptions. The classification begins with Rig pa rang shar as the ocean-like tantra showing the vast depth of meaning, followed by Rdo rje sems dpa' snying gi me long as the sun-like tantra showing clear illumination, and Seng ge rtsal rdzogs chen po as the lion-like tantra showing how to overwhelm lower vehicles. The metaphors continue with Ri rgyal lta bu, 'Khor lo lta bu, Lde mig lta bu, Ral gri lta bu, Gsal shing lta bu, Gser zhun lta bu, Ma bu 'brel ba lta bu, Me long lta bu, Mu tig phreng ba'i rgyud, Sbrul mdud lta bu, Khyung chen po, Chu bo lta bu, Rgyal po lta bu, Bang mdzod lta bu, and finally Nag mo khros ma. Each metaphor conveys the specific function and character of the tantra it names. View register presents these seventeen tantras as the complete expression of Dzogchen teaching through different modalities—some emphasizing view, some meditation, some conduct, some result—demonstrating that the Great Perfection can be approached from multiple angles all leading to the same recognition. Translation risks reduce these metaphorical names to mere poetic titles rather than recognizing them as precise indicators of each tantra's function, potentially obscuring the systematic relationship between metaphor and meaning that characterizes Dzogchen literature. Preservation requirements note the specific metaphorical system establishes a taxonomy of Dzogchen teachings, ensuring that the functional distinctions between these seventeen tantras are maintained for accurate transmission of which tantra addresses which aspect of practice.
[4546-4580] Structural function details the eleven categories (sde tshan bcu gcig) for explaining the purpose (dgos ched) of the seventeen tantras, beginning with the three heart-essences of the tantra (rgyud kyi snying po gsum) which function like a king controlling his realm, the three pure essences (dangs ma gsum) which function like seeing valleys from mountain peaks, and the three flower-tantras (me tog gsum) which function like three suns dispelling darkness. The comprehensive summary (rgyud kun gyi sdom) functions like placing foundation stones for a fortress, while the complete depth of vision (snang ba gting rdzogs) functions like a fortress on a high peak. The reversing tantra of wisdom (ye shes g.yul ldog) functions like opening windows in the four directions, while the two branch-tantras (yan lag gi rgyud) function like placing battlements on the four sides. The tantra of yogic liberation functions like a king residing in the palace summit, while the heart-like tantra functions like firmly locking the door. View register presents these elaborate metaphorical classifications as demonstrating the interdependence of different aspects of Dzogchen teaching, where each tantra serves a specific function in the complete structure of practice and realization, like different architectural elements contributing to the integrity of a fortress. Translation risks misinterpret these metaphors as mere literary flourish rather than recognizing them as a sophisticated pedagogical system where each metaphor encodes specific relationships between teachings, such as the king-minister-subjects hierarchy indicating relative importance or the mountain-peak perspective indicating comprehensive vision. Preservation requirements note the specific eleven categories with their corresponding metaphors establish a complete framework for understanding the seventeen tantras' relationships and functions, ensuring that this architectural metaphor system is preserved as an integral part of Dzogchen pedagogical method.
[4581-4611] Structural function concludes with the detailed presentation of the eight sections of definitive order (go rim gyi sde tshan brgyad), though the text appears to be cut off or incomplete at this point. The preceding material has established the complete framework for understanding Dzogchen tantra classification through the categories of method tantra, nature tantra (with its three subdivisions), and the seventeen tantras with their eleven functional categories. The integration of scriptural citation, metaphorical illustration, and technical terminology creates a comprehensive presentation of Dzogchen literature and its systematic approach to the nature of mind and its realization. The text emphasizes throughout that all these classifications ultimately point to the same reality of primordial purity and spontaneous presence, with the various categories serving as skillful means for beings of different capacities and inclinations. View register presents this elaborate classification system as both a map of the terrain of Dzogchen realization and a pedagogical device for guiding practitioners through the progressive stages of understanding, from initial introduction to complete mastery. Translation risks fragment this comprehensive presentation into disconnected lists rather than recognizing the systematic integration of all elements into a coherent whole that characterizes Dzogchen philosophy. Preservation requirements note the incomplete nature of the final section suggests either textual truncation or intentional open-endedness, but the preceding material provides sufficient framework for understanding the structure and purpose of Dzogchen tantra classification, ensuring that readers have access to the complete pedagogical system even if the final details are not fully elaborated.
[4612-4636] Structural function presents the comprehensive summary verses from Mu ti phreng ba that systematically review all the tantra categories through extended metaphors, creating a mnemonic device for practitioners to remember the relationships between different tantras and their functions. The metaphor of the king, minister, and subjects coming together illustrates how mastery of the three heart-essences brings control over all tantras, while the metaphor of reaching three mountain peaks demonstrates how understanding the three pure essences provides comprehensive vision. The three suns shining in the sky metaphor illustrates how knowledge of the three flower-tantras dispels the darkness of confusion about tantra meaning and words. Each metaphor reinforces the pedagogical principle that understanding the essence makes mastery of details possible without exhaustive study. View register presents these concluding verses as the mnemonic distillation of the entire classification system, designed to be memorized and recalled as a complete map of Dzogchen literature and its relationships. Translation risks reduce these verses to mere summary rather than recognizing them as the essential condensation that practitioners would commit to memory, serving as the keys to unlock the entire system of seventeen tantras. Preservation requirements note the specific metaphorical language—king controlling realm, mountain peak perspective, sun dispelling darkness—creates a consistent symbolic vocabulary throughout the text, ensuring that these interlocking metaphors are maintained as a systematic pedagogical device rather than treated as random poetic imagery.
[4637-4638] Transitional passage. The Tibetan text moves from previous topic to next. Wylie: '<span class="term">/gsum pa go rims nges pas mjug bsdu ba la/</span> go rims kyi sde t...' This structural marker serves as bridge between doctrinal expositions. The lotsawa recognizes the transition and prepares the reader for the next topic. Structural function: transitional clarity. Register: structural awareness.
01 05 03 01
[4639-4669] Enumeration of the eightfold textual corpus structure. Root tantras two: Dzogpa Rangjung (Self-Arising Perfection) and Yige Medpa (Letterless Tantra). Explanatory tantras mother-and-child two: Rigpa Rangshar and Rigpa Rangdrol. Branch tantras two: Rinpoche Pungpa and Kudung Barwa. Clarification tantras two: Drathalgyur and Tashi Dzeden. Instructional tantras four: Dorje Sempa Nyinggi Melong, Kunzang Thugkyi Melong, Ngotro Dzepa, and Mutik Trengwa. Self-abiding intention tantras three: Klong Drukpa, Dronma Barwa, and Nyida Kajor. Self-liberated entry tantras two: Senge Tsal Dzog and Norbu Thrakö. Expert ritual tantra one: Nagmo Khrosma. Structural function: establishing authoritative textual basis for all teachings through systematic catalog. View register: Dzogchen textual hierarchy where all tantras ultimately point to rigpa. Translation risk: missing the organic metaphor system—root<span class="term">/branch/</span>flower/fruit as developmental rather than essential. Preservation: the numerical precision (2<span class="iast">2</span>2<span class="iast">4</span>3<span class="iast">2</span>1=17) establishes complete corpus integrity.
[4670-4691] Scriptural citation from Mutik Trengwa establishing the eightfold structure through poetic enumeration. Lines 4671-4690 present the tantric corpus in verse form, each category associated with specific pedagogical function. The structural function: canonical confirmation through renowned Dzogchen source text. View register: the entire corpus as unified expression of single intention. Translation risk: the poetic meter may obscure technical precision. Preservation: each line of the citation corresponds to one category, maintaining the eight-part structure established in prose.
[4692-4710] Rationale for the eightfold structure through seven similes. Root tantras like healthy tree roots—without them branches cannot grow. Explanatory tantras like leaves and flowers—without them fruit cannot emerge. Branch tantras like limbs—without them one falls climbing rocks. Entry tantras like heart—without it the body cannot benefit others. Clarification tantras like flowers—without them fruit does not ripen. Instructional tantras like fruit—without them effort is wasted. Intention tantras like eyes—without them one cannot see the path. Ritual tantra like guard dog—without it thieves steal wealth. Structural function: demonstrating organic necessity of each category. View register: all eight as indispensable limbs of single body of teaching. Translation risk: the similes may read as decorative rather than demonstrating structural interdependence. Preservation: the precise correspondences—roots<span class="term">/trunk/</span>limbs<span class="term">/heart/</span>flowers<span class="term">/fruit/</span>eyes/dog—establish functional hierarchy.
[4711-4720] Etymological analysis of the eight category names. Root (rtsa ba): like penetrating root, refers to mind as root of all dharmas. Explanation (bshad pa): like spreading leaves, refers to joining words and meanings. Branch (yan lag): like entwined trunk, refers to space and rigpa as non-dual. Clarification (lung rigs): like blooming flowers, refers to demonstrating luminosity's own face. Instruction (man ngag): like ripening fruit, refers to actualizing the three kayas as path. Intention (dgongs pa): like liberating vision, refers to making result into path. Entry ('jug pa): like invoking memory, refers to introducing the lamp itself. Expert ritual (mkhas pa cho ga): like completing instruction, refers to preserving the holy teachings long. Structural function: unpacking semantic depths of category names. View register: each name encodes complete Dzogchen view. Translation risk: etymological explanations may seem tangential to main argument. Preservation: the Tibetan wordplay (rtsa ba<span class="term">/rtsa ba, lo 'dab/</span>bsre ba) must be noted even if not reproducible in translation.
[4721-4728] Benefits of engaging the textual corpus. Holding the tantra: rigpa recognizes its own face. Keeping it: samadhi self-abides. Reading it: meaning of topic dawns in mind. Explaining it: obtaining supreme and common siddhis. Meditating on it: pushing out samsara. Listening to it: engaging temporary wisdom. Structural function: establishing practical value of textual transmission. View register: the tantras as direct support for recognition. Translation risk: benefits may read as magical rather than pointing to natural functions. Preservation: the progression from holding to listening represents graduated engagement levels.
[4729-4738] Distinction between word-instruction and meaning-instruction. Verbal elaboration of instructions: missing the point through words. Essence-compressed meaning-instruction: awakening without relying on words. Structural function: establishing superiority of direct pointing over textual elaboration. View register: the ultimate instruction transcends its verbal form. Translation risk: appearing to contradict the previous emphasis on textual corpus. Preservation: this is not rejection of texts but recognition that they point beyond themselves.
[4739-4749] Technical definitions of key terms. Lung: unchanging and stable, producing confident faith. Rigpa: depending on that meaning, liberating into buddhahood. Salwa: clear knowing without abiding anywhere; clear senses distinguishing dharma and non-dharma. Entry: emptiness entering into appearance, appearance and mind mouth-joining; appearance entering emptiness, object and mind non-dual, self-liberated without correction. Structural function: precise terminology establishing conceptual foundation. View register: each term points to direct recognition rather than philosophical position. Translation risk: definitions may seem circular or tautological. Preservation: the Tibetan technical precision must be maintained—lung as authoritative scripture, rigpa as knowledge, salwa as clarity, 'jug pa as dynamic entry.
[4750-4755] Five types of expertise (mkhas pa). Expert in mother's time and crucial points: destroying the object of accomplishment through mere thought. Expert in activity and its completion: stealing the life of the object of accomplishment through mere contemplation without mantra or samadhi. Expert in mother's mantra and samadhi: deities become near, siddhis arise. Expert in mother's approach and accomplishment: one's desired aim is accomplished. Expert in substance and offering: prosperity increases, activities succeed. Structural function: establishing ritual mastery as corollary to textual study. View register: expertise as natural expression of recognition rather than acquired skill. Translation risk: ritual language may seem irrelevant to Dzogchen view. Preservation: the mother's yoga (ma mo) context establishes tantric foundation for Dzogchen.
[4756-4763] Graduated teachings for three capacities. Those delighting in mental elaboration: all is taught. Middling: accomplished through eight tantras gathered into eight sections. Superior: meaning condensed into tantras. Divided by method: two. Divided by nature: three. Five are sufficient. Moreover, for the excellent: tantras of meaning and words both taught. For the extremely excellent beyond elaboration: ground tantra rigpa alone accomplishes, because rigpa contains all tantras. Structural function: establishing graduated curriculum based on student capacity. View register: single intention expressed through multiple formats. Translation risk: hierarchical language may seem elitist rather than pedagogically necessary. Preservation: the five<span class="term">/two/</span>three numerical structure represents complete curriculum design.
[4764-4784] Scriptural citation from Thalgyur establishing the nature of tantra. Lines 4765-4783 enumerate eighteen named tantras with their specific functions, concluding that all arise from the ground. The structural function: comprehensive canonical enumeration providing textual authority. View register: all eighteen as expressions of single Dzogchen intention. Translation risk: the list format may seem tedious rather than demonstrating completeness. Preservation: each tantra name encodes specific teaching function—Thalgyur (Sound Transcendent), Senge Tsal Dzog (Lion Force Perfected), etc.
[4785-4797] Alternative enumeration by capacity. For those with elaboration: ground and heart tantras, all bindu cycles. Middling: seventeen. Superior: Self-Arising Seed Tantra alone. Summit: liberation through three—before, after, and simultaneous. Structural function: demonstrating that enumeration depends on student needs. View register: the same truth expressed through different scopes. Translation risk: numerical variation may seem contradictory. Preservation: citation from Ati Kopa Chenpo establishes this graduated approach as canonical.
[4798-4847] Explanation methodology framework. Three aspects: how to explain, enumeration of preliminaries, definitive prophecy. First has three: structural framework, method of explanation, letter meaning explanation. Generally, many explanation traditions but summarized as three: scriptural explanation, tantric explanation, instruction explanation. Scriptural: through five perfections. Tantric: through three definite locations. Instruction: through ground, path, and result. Here primarily tantric explanation with three locations: for sharp faculties through mentioning name, expressing tantra name meaning; middling through mentioning mere enumeration, expressing preliminaries through five perfections; dull through examples and meanings, extensively explaining the body. First: name explanation, signs, and samaya. Second: preliminaries of teacher, mother, retinue, father's request, omniscience. Third: body brief, extensive, very extensive, conclusion with rejoicing in meaning. Structural function: establishing hermeneutical framework for textual interpretation. View register: explanation itself as recognition support. Translation risk: methodological detail may seem pedantic. Preservation: the three-faculty schema represents standard pedagogical organization.
01 05 04 01
[4848-4878] Five-fold explanation framework. Grounded by five types: root meaning, yoga meaning, purpose meaning, word meaning, history meaning. Structural function: establish comprehensive exposition structure. Citation from Nyi zla kha sbyor tantra. Rtsa ba'i don: name-identity grasped. Yoga don: conclusion gate shown. Dgos ched don: one's place established. Tshig gi don: straight line connected. Lo rgyus don: minds satisfied. Each serves distinct pedagogical function.
[4879-4920] Defects of non-exposition. Five defects corresponding to five omissions. Without history: defect of non-belief in Secret Great Definite Teaching. Without root: dharmas not gathered into rigpa—defect of limitlessness. Without yoga: vehicle distinctions not divided—big and small ranks meaningless. Without purpose: toward Great Perfection without effort—defect of meaninglessness. Without word: when tantras ranked clearly—defect of not grasping letters. Structural function: establish necessity through negation.
[4921-4940] Benefits of good exposition. Abandoning defects, all qualities become perfect. Purpose articulation: protecting one's own view, refuting others' views. Structural function: positive motivation establishment. Citation from Rig pa rang grol. Dgos pa: both protective and polemical.
[4941-5000] Explanation methods enumeration. Twenty-three jewel examples. Five chapters of Wish-fulfilling Tree. Twenty-eight methods total. Structural function: illustrate pedagogical diversity. Tigress leap wisdom: cutting great earth. Garuda soaring: filling chests of meaning. Lion's roar: suppressing lower vehicles. Tortoise slow movement: grasping letters. Raven's claw: cutting error and obscuration. Wrestler's striking: gathering extensive meaning. Sleeping elephant: introducing and focusing view. Garuda's wheel: seeking meaning's focus. Vulture devouring: explaining without doubt. Young goat climbing: appropriate and inappropriate. Pearl string: gathering instructional meaning. Seasonal dragon-rain: refuting and expelling others. Blooming signs: gathering all doors. Wish-fulfilling tree: very great extensive. Each metaphor serves specific didactic function.
[5001-5060] Explanation methods continued. Clear sky sun: pervading all. Clear deep moon: samsara and nirvana. Lion's sitting: meditation meaning. Duck's harmonious: filling meaning's chest. Rainbow in space: dharmasphere adorned. Razor strike: cutting view's distinction. Mirror mandala: two causes and conditions. Lightning in space: words and meanings quickly. Empty sky: extensive end without limit. Penetrating roots: awareness-things shown. Coiled trunk: dharmas coiled into meaning. Spreading branches: instructional meaning impressed. Extensive leaves: twenty-one like explained. Clear flower: two types of lamps. Ripening fruit: results without return. Structural function: complete twenty-eight methods.
[5061-5120] Visualization protocol. Thus explained and heard. Teacher visualized as Kun tu bzang po, Vajra holder, or Vajra sattva. Dharma light-rays pervading sky. Dust-count fields of beings hear. Ignorance's sleep awakened. Wisdom meaning obtained. Liberation path entered. Structural function: establish blessing context. Listeners, heroes, mind-consorts, dakinis' appearance. Supreme clear light realization. Self and limitless sentient beings primordially Buddha. Bodhicitta generation. Structural function: complete visualization mandala.
[5121-5180] Dedication and purpose. Akanishtha's field: natureless mandala of five perfections. Dharma wheel arising. For beings and teachings to abide long. Dedication verses: may Buddha's teachings flourish. May all beings be blissful. May they practice dharma day and night. May self and other benefit arise spontaneously. Structural function: dedicating merit.
[5181-5240] Third topic: letters' sound and meaning. Two aspects: letter-cloud nature generally, abode-definite specifically. Four types of letter nature: abode-nature-meaning, body-abode-channel, expression-sound, result's ultimate. Structural function: establish letter taxonomy. First: mind-nature naturally clear light, self-arisen wisdom. Beyond eternalism and nihilism, coming and going. Sphere-ultimate reality letter. Citation from Sgyu 'phrul gsang snying.
[5241-5300] Body-abode-channel letters. Four channel-wheels' center, three heart-channels as three pillars. OM AH HUM: self-arisen letters three, colors white-red-blue. Outer: body speech mind. Inner: afflictions poisons three. Secret: body speech mind's support. Light-rays five's radiance. Channel-petals: father mother method wisdom letters. Vowels sixteen, consonants thirty-four. Singles, doubles, prefixes, branches: eighty-four thousand. Outer: aggregates elements sense-fields. Inner: afflictions thought-collections. Secret: dharma gates. Structural function: subtle body phonology.
[5301-5360] Root letters and pronunciation. Each consonant with vowel letters sixteen's sound. Letter's form is sound stacked. KA KA example: life A within. A is all letters' supreme. Within, arisen, birthless. KI KI, KU KU, KE KE, KO KO, KRA KRA patterns. RI RI, LI LI with life A. AM AH as KAM KAH. Root letters: doubles KKA great. GHA JHA DHA BHA thick. Triple, five-stacked: sphere's single letter. Suitable read as one, unsuitable separately. Structural function: phonetic system.
[5361-5420] Channels and winds in body. Channels exist thus: body speech mind wisdom five in different spheres. Letters and similar: light five's appearance. Brush-strokes, essence white-red, wind's center self-clear. Youth: root letters clear, mind sharp, sense-fields clear. Old age: root letters unclear, diminished. Structural function: physiological correlation.
[5421-5480] Sound's letters. Speech speaking ones. Cause: root letters wind-moved. Condition: tongue palate action. Within A-like arises. Throat KA etc. Tongue-tip TA THA etc. Tongue-tip and palate meet: crown called. RA LA-like: tongue palate strongly joined. TTA TTHA arise. Lips PA PHA BA BHA MA. All depending on locations. Structural function: articulatory phonetics.
[5481-5540] Result's ultimate letters. Buddha's speech sixty limbs' melody. Longs spyod rdzogs pa: pure channel-letters. Letters pervade space as dharma melody. Arising as Buddha bodies for beings' benefit. Longs sku and sprul sku root letters, wisdom five's appearance adorned. Through this: Buddha time, sutra tantra immeasurable for beings. Emanations for beings' benefit. Structural function: fruitional phonology.
[5541-5600] Abode-definite explanation: five aspects. Root letters brief presentation. Affixes and branches extensively divided. Samsara nirvana explanation definitively. Abode and enjoyment explained. Expression method shown. Structural function: comprehensive framework.
[5601-5660] Root letters: thirty-four consonants. YA and WA as one life. Affixes: YA to long, WA to single. Ring cha's A and different ni bsregs. Singles appearing as doubles through life. Separate arrangement: A KSA KHA GHA etc. Channels thus exist: body speech mind wisdom five different spheres. Letters with light five's appearance: brush-strokes, essence, wind center. Structural function: detailed letter arrangement.
[5661-5720] Root letter clarity. Clear root letters: memory clear, wisdom great. Sense-fields clear and unclear reverse. Youth: root letters clear, mind sharp, sense-fields clear. Old: unclear, diminished. Structural function: developmental correlation.
[5721-5780] Samsara nirvana explanation. Without affixes: samsara's dharmas. Rig pa reversed from that. Example: KA as samsara from original sphere confused. With ignorance etc. Affixes and branches: nirvana. If affixes arise: appearing emptiness etc. as two explained. Branches: five kayas etc. according to branch numbers. Structural function: interpretive framework.
[5781-5840] Rang shar citation: all letters' explanation two: nirvana explanation and samsara's letters. Nirvana's letters: affixes and branches explained. Samsara's letters: first MA explained. Through two explanation methods: all letters' meaning freed. Structural function: scriptural support.
[5841-5900] Abode and enjoyment. When affixes and branches complete: root letter's first MA as samsara part explained. From affix arising onward: nirvana's abode. Expression also: affix that together read. Letter's nature and affix branch: samsara nirvana's abode. Mother letters' enjoyment: affixes and branches arising. Structural function: cosmological phonology.
