The five intentions are: mountain-top intention for view practice, wisdom general anointing for ground-holding, thigle seeing liberation for investigating appearance's arising mode, sun moon equal measure for delivering to meaning's end, ocean expanse liberation for delivering awareness to the ground.
[3381-2688] The intention of mountain-top universal intention establishes the awareness nature of Great Perfection, luminosity without transfer, space-wisdom non-dual. When realized by sense faculty, space-awareness appears as field. The view for supreme faculty shows wisdom light spontaneously arising, realizing self-wisdom without form. Intention unmoving clarity like planets on ocean. Conduct ceaseless power-arising like sky-spear. Fruit seeing birthless self-arising.
[3461-2688] Middle faculty view realizes self-awareness without birth. Intention free from conceptual portions like flags on ocean. Conduct unblocked spontaneous like madman, without obstacle through all appearance. Fruit endowed with self-place intention, conquering signs. Last faculty view realizes appearance as illusion or emanation. Intention demonstrating self-appearance essence, wisdom arising like lion chick free from womb-egg. Conduct endowed grasping samsara-nirvana. Fruit abandoning body, breath reaches nature-emanation body field.
[3541-2688] Second, wisdom general anointing intention establishes awareness power naturally perfect from beginning. Three faculties' different realization modes: supreme faculty recognizes empowerment as unborn fruit self-place showing. Intention unmoved in great bliss equal to space through wisdom method pressing thigle. Conduct without pure-impure in white-red bodhicitta. Fruit sees family ground suchness.
[3621-2688] Middle faculty view recognizes appearances as awareness power. Intention rests unmoved like sun and moon united in space. Conduct in true nature yoga mode. Result obtains suchness without birth and death. Last faculty view recognizes empowerment qualities expanding. Intention relies on deity form with signs for meditation. Conduct moves in true nature display. Result obtains buddhahood through qualities doorway.
[3701-2688] Third, thigle seeing liberation intention establishes bardo wisdom self-arising awareness recognizing self-appearance as self-awareness, achieving buddhahood. Supreme faculty view sees wisdom power qualities appearing like shooting star moving in space, recognizing liberation in three moments. Intention dwells clear and pervasive like sun risen in space. Conduct enjoys wisdom body pure. Result becomes Buddha on primordial purity ground in three moments.
[3781-2688] Middle faculty view recognizes true nature bliss inexhaustible great appearing excellently arising. Intention sees each moment's distinct object, producing excellent recognitions, seeing each dharma body appearance. Last faculty view recognizes pure wisdom appearance with uncertainty about self and other. Intention rests without seeing. Conduct possesses doubt. Result obtains breath-release in nature-emanation body field.
[3861-2688] Fourth intention, sun moon measure equal, establishes appearance-emptiness exhausting equal recognition. Supreme faculty view recognizes wisdom penetrating completeness. Intention unmoved in unobstructed wisdom like river flow. Conduct plays with great wisdom activity unceasing. Fruit obtains method wisdom union, liberating bondage, four aspects without separation. Middle faculty recognizes method wisdom non-dual. Intention rests in method wisdom nature like sun moon appearing in space.
[3941-2688] Last faculty view recognizes father-mother union demonstrating bodhicitta appearing as result. Intention dwells in clear samadhi through remembering deity essence heart. Conduct enjoys five medicines five nectars. Result obtains pure appearance fruit by holding yidam deity maya body in bardo. Fifth intention, ocean expanse liberation, establishes dwelling in naturally clear equal true nature, innate concentration.
[4021-2688] Supreme faculty view recognizes great wisdom activity whatever appears as own appearance. Intention has little attachment to appearance, like intoxicated with beer. Conduct moves in samsara and nirvana. Fruit obtains wisdom singularly arising not abiding in appearance. Middle faculty recognizes clear penetrating wisdom body. Intention possesses brief fierce like waterfall. Conduct possesses object of wild beasts, not common object. Fruit obtains certainty completed in emptiness wisdom essence.
[4101-2688] Last faculty view desires abandoning deluded appearance excellently. Intention dwells in deity and human mind holding. Conduct possesses fabricated dualistic grasping. Fruit obtains divine and human status. Summary: these five intentions bind all Secret Essence yogins. The yogin's experience arises: mountain-top intention balances highest view without high or low; wisdom anointing holds its own abiding in true nature; thigle seeing investigates awareness liberation from space-appearance; sun moon equal delivers intention to exhausted phenomena expanse; ocean expanse delivers awareness to primordial purity ground.
[4181-2688] First, view washes the outside, suppressing deluded appearance's fear like lion's sport. Second, obtains self-power in true nature, like royal caste receiving empowerment from crown. Third, reaches purity sphere, like peacock chick emerging from egg. Fourth, expands great equal vastness, like sun moon non-dual union. Fifth, clears self-appearance as wisdom, like sun rising from Mount Meru's neck.
[4261-2688] Thus five requests each divided into three faculties makes fifteen, each with view, intention, conduct, fruit four by four, making sixty Dharma portions. This purifies beings' sixty eons' development and decline, afflictions, and view portions, showing the completely pure essence of wisdom. This is the twenty-fifth chapter establishing the key points of wisdom experience in spontaneous thogal.
[4341-2688] Thus having shown the methods of practice through guidance instruction, now extensive explanation of how to practice through direct introduction: general introduction procedure determining all phenomena, and particular determination extensively explaining mind and wisdom symbols. First, preliminary before introduction and actual introduction. The preliminary presents the preparation necessary for direct recognition.
[4421-2688] Actual introduction presents recognizing mind and nature as separate, recognizing wisdom and dharmata as separate, then introducing their inseparability. This establishes the graduated approach to recognition. The structural function moves from preparation to direct pointing. The view register maintains that recognition is not intellectual understanding but direct non-conceptual knowing.
[4501-2688] Mind is the moving, cognizing, grasping—this is the entity to be introduced. Nature is the abiding, empty, clear—this is the field in which introduction occurs. Wisdom is the knowing without grasping, the self-clear awareness. Dharmata is the suchness, the way things actually are. These four terms establish the complete framework for introduction practice.
[4581-2688] Introduction to mind involves looking at the present mind: where did it come from, where does it abide, where does it go? Not finding any of these, one recognizes mind's unborn nature. Introduction to nature involves looking at what remains when mind is not found—the empty clarity that is always present. This is the nature, the ground of all experience.
[4661-2688] Introduction to wisdom involves recognizing that which knows the looking—that which is aware of the search. This awareness is not separate from what it knows, yet it is not what it knows. This is wisdom, the self-recognizing awareness. Introduction to dharmata involves seeing that all appearances are of the same nature—empty yet appearing, appearing yet empty.
[4741-2688] The inseparability of these four is the actual introduction. Not that they become inseparable, but that they have never been separate. This is the great secret of Dzogchen. The view register emphasizes that introduction does not create something new but reveals what has always been the case. Translation must preserve the distinction between the four while showing their ultimate unity.
[4821-2688] The particular determination of mind and wisdom symbols presents the detailed analysis of how mind functions and how wisdom recognizes. Mind is symbolized by the ocean—vast, moving, containing all. Wisdom is symbolized by the sun—clear, illuminating, without movement. These symbols support recognition without becoming objects of fixation.
[4901-2688] The mind's six collections—eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, mental consciousness—are the conventional functioning. The wisdom's five doors—mirror-like, equality, discriminating, all-accomplishing, dharma sphere—are the ultimate display. The relationship between these two sets establishes the non-duality of conventional and ultimate.
[4981-2688] The eight consciousnesses transform into the five wisdoms—this is the promise of practice. Not that consciousnesses become wisdoms, but that their true nature is wisdom. This transformation is not a change in nature but a recognition of nature. The view register maintains the continuity between conventional mind and ultimate wisdom.
[5061-2688] The ground aspect of mind is the storehouse consciousness, the ground of all habitual patterns. The path aspect is the transforming consciousnesses, the dynamic functioning. The fruit aspect is the wisdoms, the recognized nature. This threefold division provides the framework for understanding the complete journey.
[5141-2688] The afflictions—desire, anger, ignorance, pride, jealousy—are the conventional display. Their true nature is the five wisdoms—discriminating, mirror-like, dharma sphere, equality, all-accomplishing. This correspondence demonstrates the fundamental purity of all experience. Nothing needs to be rejected; everything is the display of wisdom.
[5221-2688] The particular introduction of wisdom involves recognizing the five wisdoms in immediate experience. The wisdom that knows forms is mirror-like. The wisdom that knows equality is the wisdom of sameness. The wisdom that knows distinctions is discriminating. The wisdom that accomplishes benefit is all-accomplishing. The wisdom that knows suchness is dharma sphere.
[5301-2688] These are not different wisdoms but different aspects of the same wisdom. Like one sun reflecting in different waters, the wisdom appears differently according to the vessel. This analogy supports recognition without reification. The view register maintains the non-dual wisdom beyond one and many.
[5381-2688] The symbols for wisdom—sun, moon, jewel, lotus, sword—each convey specific qualities. The sun's clarity, the moon's coolness, the jewel's value, the lotus's purity, the sword's sharpness. These symbols are not arbitrary but point to actual qualities of experience. The practitioner uses these symbols to support recognition.
[5461-2688] The completion of introduction is not the end but the beginning. Having been introduced, one practices familiarization. The familiarization is not different from the introduction but its extension in time. The view register emphasizes that introduction is sudden but familiarization takes time.
[5541-2688] The signs of successful introduction include: decrease of attachment, increase of clarity, natural compassion, reduced conceptualization, dream practice, and meditative experiences. These are not goals but signs along the way. The practitioner does not pursue them but notices them as byproducts of practice.
[5621-2688] The obstacles to introduction include: doubt, conceptualization, distraction, dullness, agitation, and ordinary perception. These are not enemies but opportunities for recognition. Each obstacle, when recognized as such, becomes the path. The view register maintains that there is no obstacle to recognition other than not recognizing.
[5701-2688] The enhancement of introduction involves: repeated introduction by the teacher, self-introduction through recollection, introduction through signs and symbols, and introduction through the natural dissolution of obstacles. These four methods provide comprehensive support for recognition.
[5781-2688] The ultimate introduction is self-introduction—awareness recognizing itself without intermediary. This is the apex of Dzogchen practice. The teacher, the teachings, and the practice all point to this. When it occurs, there is nothing more to do. The view register emphasizes that self-introduction is always available but usually overlooked.
[5861-2688] The fruit of introduction is not something new but the recognition of what has always been the case. This is the great liberation—liberation from the need for liberation. The practitioner who has recognized this can engage in all activities without being bound by them.
[5941-2688] The summary verse from Rangshar: "Introduction to mind, introduction to nature, introduction to wisdom, introduction to dharmata—these four introductions are the supreme path of Dzogchen." This scriptural authority establishes the centrality of introduction to the tradition. The structural function demonstrates how all previous conduct instructions support this recognition.
[6021-2688] The integration of conduct and view completes the presentation. Conduct without view is binding; view without conduct is incomplete. Together, they form the complete path. The practitioner engages in conduct while maintaining view, in view while engaging in conduct. This is the Dzogchen way.
[6101-2688] The final dedication transfers merit for the benefit of all beings. This is not mere formula but the expression of the recognition that self and other are not separate. The merit of practice is shared because there is no one to possess it and no one separate from it.
[6181-2688] The colophon establishes this as the fourth chapter of the conduct section, completing the detailed presentation of conduct in the Great Perfection vehicle. The structural function marks the transition to the next major section. The view register maintains the continuity of Dzogchen teaching from beginning to end.
02 17 05 01
[2689-2710] Essence extraction practices are divided into reliance upon various essences and reliance upon wind. The various essences include extraction from the five elements, medicines, grasses, and nectar, among which precious jewel extraction is supreme and profound. The method for combined precious jewel and five-nectar extraction involves mixing five nectars when elements are in balance, using skilled composition, placing in a jewel vessel, adding honey and ushira, adding mercury droplets, and consuming a quantity the size of a pea kernel. Practiced thus, essence extraction becomes supreme and without doubt.
[2711-2738] Wind practice involves joining upper and lower winds, drawing into the roma channel, filling the throat wheel with nectar taste, concealing earth and water winds so all appearances become food, dissolving at throat and roma, and meditating that absorption bliss pervades, accomplishing food-yoga. Benefits include lifespan equal to sun and moon, immunity from weapons through various stone preparations, elimination of white hair and wrinkles through reliance on herbs, radiant youthfulness through essence combinations, bodily strength and vitality through flesh reliance, and wondrous essence extraction through wind reliance. This severs the torment of existence.
[2739-2743] The distinction between austerity and essence extraction is clarified. Austerity involves consuming slight amounts of stones, water, or other supports while merely employing mantra and visualization as auxiliaries. Essence extraction, whether with pills, powders, or without supports, constitutes wind and essence yoga properly engaged.
[2744-2771] Training in meditation sessions for cutting clothes fixation involves three practices. Deep dependent-arising includes flesh combination, stone combination, herb combination, and essence combination as explained in the Khandro Zod. Relying upon the fierce woman's fire heat involves sitting in vajra posture with joined winds, meditating fire blazing from ram at the navel pervading up to the great bliss wheel, conceiving wind through the central channel, holding wind through the left nostril with refinement, and accomplishing clothes-meditation. Wind reliance involves sitting cross-legged, drawing wind inside, holding when heat arises at the navel, slowly releasing, slightly holding wind at the feet while drawing again, generating heat, becoming free from carnivorous beings, and afflictions and concepts naturally ceasing.
[2772-2778] Cutting dream and habituation fixation through meditation session training involves six practices: channels-winds, dreams, illusory body, clear light, transfer, and union-intermediate state. This establishes the complete framework for transforming the deep-seated patterns that bind consciousness to ordinary perception through systematic engagement with subtle body practices and transitional states.
02 17 06 01
[2779-2783] Channel-wind practice focuses upon the essential point of channels at the navel. Below this lies the avadhuti, above the marma, at the hairline blue-black space, where red-white essence and fire seed red a-shad radiate from tactile heat, fire blazing within channels, warming to the crown haṃ, white-red bodhicitta dripping from which pervades the four wheels and entire body. The roma-channel wind is inserted through the central channel's lower aperture, refining channels-winds-drop-fluids as one within the four wheels' mandala. From this arises heat and wisdom, explained as supreme method of actual path main practice.
[2784-2786] As an auxiliary to this, relying upon wisdom, engaging another's body as method-path companion is done as previously explained regarding the four essential points. Without reliance, the great bliss drop's blazing and dripping is known through the experience of slowly pressing the two bliss channels with the little tongue movement.
[2787-2798] Engaging the definite essential point of clear light equality through wind practice has its ascertainment from Talgyur: relying upon wind, separate karmic mind, sever the three realms' escape hole, thoroughly reverse body-speech fixation, apply body-speech-mind essential points equally for the six migrations' precipice, ascend wind and cognition upward for mind-itself to blend with dharmas, familiarize constantly with wind for deluded appearance exhaustion.
[2799-2841] The method for triumphing over obstacles involves two essential points: nectar and element taste-equivalence. Nectar involves eating and drinking reversing clockwise, separating from foul odors, or using oil made from essence boiled in vases. As stated: the wondrous great essence extraction that cuts the body's arising continuum, reversing clockwise with feces, exhausts body's final outflows, or essence extracted oil used properly cuts element continua, elements ceasing so body holds no life, no feces or urine, outer-inner wind absent, the great yogin at this time pure in food and clothes, certainly accomplishing lifespan and enjoyment as desired.
[2842-2857] Element taste-equivalence involves holding earth-water-fire-wind winds, the body essence-extraction purifying so channels-winds-essence practices pervade the four wheels' mandala as before, accomplishing lifespan, enjoyment, food, and clothes. As stated: if elements are taste-equivalenced by the yogin, attending to earth-water-fire-wind essentials, mixing with body and concealing with wind, transforming through individual body elements and using that itself, mandala essential gathering and meditation, familiarizing to perfection, four powers equalized, abiding blissfully without fear, food and clothes accomplished, lifespan and enjoyment perfected.
[2858-2871] During this, liberating through inner mantra recitation or transferring to others through power, or through body yantras, as stated in Talgyur: not explained in other tantras, directly transfer and reverse element sicknesses. Wind, bile, phlegm, combinations of two, combinations of three, dividing into twelve portions, joining time and certainty, eight conditions from two causes, grasping hot and cold aspects, joining external-internal objects, dividing body and limbs skillfully, joining upper-lower reversal places, liberating sicknesses with threefold essential possession, various body yantras, binding and pressing final actions, drawing out all element essential points, joining body and limbs external-internal, certainly reverse mind.
[2872-2910] Three-gate yantras are presented: body involves various devices, lion, elephant, vulture, sheep, fox, human, insects, etc., various yantras for external-internal upper-lower body limbs, wind-bile-phlegm combinations as four element sickness components, hot and cold extremes dividing, liberating from sickness through respective practices. Speech involves various sounds, clearly pronounced ali-kali, letters present in own nature, sixfold articulation methods, joining respective places, gods, nagas, yakshas, rakshasas, garudas, Brahma, Indra, Vishnu, spirits, gods and nagas pure speech, kumbhandas, stomach-slitters, scents, also remaining beings' speech, joining respective languages for liberation. Mind involves various mindfulnesses, whatever agitated extremes, yogin's cognition distinguishes, also transforming through body-speech-mind, or mind's activities transforming through various concentrations, liberating from suffering extremes.
[2911-2965] Transfer involves those skilled in wind liberating their sickness into humans, animals, trees, stones, etc., and transferring others' sickness to others. At this time, transferring the teacher's sickness to others and to inanimate objects is done, but not to other beings because it contradicts the samaya of not harming sentient beings. Transfer is not done into natural states because self and other obscurations are purified by birth, and because sickness arises again even if transferred. As stated in Talgyur: transfer has two types, clarity and emptiness. Form encompassed as substance, trained in arising elements, familiarizing with wind, clarity inserted into any form moves it, beginning substance transfer. Emptiness mind-familiarization chief, dharmadhatu and dharmakāya, non-dual practice known through emptiness, mind abiding in clarity-emptiness nature, ritual completing dependent-arising, transferring through essential possession, known through verbal expression, individual arising-body contact, seeing merely transfers, joined with wind by the skilled. For actual accomplishment, invisible form accomplishes all activities. Seeing substance with fixation is taken through transfer for teacher offering, not done otherwise. Mounts and forms similarly, if commanded by teacher and hero, familiarizing with wind this too is taken, possessing attraction-mind, the yogin transfers. Master Padma transferred Mangyul's mountain, at Samye transferred Netang and the forest, remaining until today. This is supreme for yogins' desire-accomplishment.
[2966-2983] As stated in Talgyur: great-fortune yogin desiring transfer, gathering with cognition including signs, to appearing-form beings, through appropriate karmic changes, transfer own sickness to others, liberated from actuality through such transfer, others through dependent-arising combinations, from inanimate four elements, through dependent-arising becoming substance, through numbers, symbols, and languages, transforming visualization transferring sickness, sticks, stones, grass, rings, ruin-mounds, also water-earth-space, certainly grasping transfer activities, transformed through yogin mind-power.
[2984-3004] Dreams are divided into preliminary and actual main practice. Preliminary involves daytime prostrations, circumambulations, recitation, mind's emanation-gathering for complete exhaustion, refining body-speech-mind so many dreams arise as mastery measure. Then from these dreams, examining habituation's thickness, then daytime extremely relaxed with loose joints, grasping dreams, examining them, arising from one-pointed aspiration without distraction. If many previous fixation-objects appear in dreams, previous fixation-habits are thick and difficult to transform, medium difficulty. If current period mostly dreams, very easy, mastered in three or four days. Previous unvisited places, unmet people appearing in dreams are difficult to cut. All three randomly dreaming indicates three habituations gathered, extremely difficult to cut. Suppression is grasping dreams, one-pointed aspiration alone being the oral instruction's essential point, daytime thinking dreams arise here, sudden aspiration and certainty, night certainly grasped. During this, lacking power to emanate and transform, viewing realms, etc., training powers, suppressing appearance.
02 17 07 01
[3005-3056] This section presents dream yoga preliminary practices and main techniques, establishing the foundational training for recognizing and transforming the dream state. The structural function moves from preliminary recognition of dreams through the three techniques—training, transforming, and cutting—to establish the complete practice framework. The opening description of recognizing fear-inducing conditions as dreams establishes the basic capacity for dream awareness. The register operates in dream yoga technical terminology: dream recognition (rmi lam zin pa), training ('byongs pa), emanation (sprul pa), transformation (bsgyur ba), cutting (bcad pa), empty (stong pa), appearance-emptiness (snang stong). The preliminary practice of recognizing dreams through strong intention establishes the psychological foundation for subsequent techniques. Translation risks center on preserving the specific techniques without conflating them. The training technique involves daytime practice of viewing all appearances as last night's dreams, then looking back at the observing awareness to see appearances as groundless, rootless, and naturally clear. The transformation technique involves appearing and empty transformation through mirror meditation on deity bodies. The cutting technique involves releasing all appearance-mind connections without fabrication. The developmental progression described—from coarse dreams to subtle, then to forgetting, finally to nothing dreamed with awareness resting in clear samādhi day and night—establishes the complete path. The technical term "day-night union" (nyin mtshan kha sbyor) indicates the final integration of waking and dream states.
02 17 08 01
[3057-3061] The text introduces dream yoga as one application of illusory body practice, distinguishing between dreams that remain unmastered and those brought under conscious direction. The practitioner trains in recognizing the dream state while maintaining awareness that ordinary perception and dream perception share the same nature—both are manifestations without inherent existence. This recognition forms the foundation for subsequent techniques that transform the dream experience from unconscious wandering into intentional practice.
[3060-3065] Extracting dreams involves specific body postures and mental placements that concentrate attention at crucial energetic points. The throat center becomes particularly significant as the junction between higher and lower energy circuits. By concealing consciousness at this location through deliberate focus, the practitioner prevents dispersion into ordinary discursive thought while maintaining sufficient alertness to recognize the dream state as it arises. This method addresses the tendency for consciousness to either fall into dullness or scatter into distraction.
[3066-3071] The four wheels represent focal points where wind and mind are placed—typically the crown, throat, heart, and navel centers. These energetic locations serve as anchors for consciousness during the transition into sleep, allowing the practitioner to maintain continuity of recognition as waking perception dissolves. The lion's sleeping posture creates optimal conditions for engaging these points, with the body positioned to facilitate energy flow while maintaining alertness in relaxation.
[3072-3081] Binding wind and mind at the throat center involves visualizing a red AH syllable seated upon a white four-petaled lotus. The practitioner draws appearances of both cyclic existence and transcendence into the wheel of mindfulness at the nostrils, then internalizes this focus. As subtle energy withdraws and consciousness becomes concentrated, the descent of bindu from the crown syllable HAM creates a clear appearance in the heart center, like a reflection in a mirror—vivid yet without substantial nature.
[3082-3092] The results manifest according to the intensity of effort applied. With sharp diligence, dreams may cease before completing all contemplative focuses, as consciousness stabilizes in clear light. Moderate effort leads to rapid mastery of the dream state, while lesser diligence gradually transforms dreams into virtuous tendencies until they naturally subside. The progression moves from initially numerous dreams through diminishing frequency, paralleled by shifting from forgotten dreams to extraordinary clarity and finally to unclear residual traces.
[3093-3115] The Thalgyur tantra presents this system in verse form, emphasizing the complete path: preliminary empowerment directing the mind to essential points, purification of body, speech, and mind, recognition of signs indicating mastery, and application of the six techniques. The three latent tendencies—training, suppression, and transformation—represent progressive stages of integration where unconscious patterns are progressively brought under conscious recognition and transformed into supports for awakening.
[3116-3123] Dream yoga functions as guidance for transforming the fundamental confusion of habitual perception into the clarity of clear light. The text cites the practice's capacity to make delusion itself into the path, emphasizing that dream yoga does not reject ordinary consciousness but recognizes its true nature. This connects to broader illusory body practices, where daytime recognition and nighttime dream training mutually reinforce each other, dissolving the apparent boundary between waking and sleeping states.
02 17 09 01
[3124-3135] The practice begins with mirror contemplation—recognizing that external phenomena appearing in the mind share the nature of reflections: manifesting clearly without existing independently. The practitioner examines this by observing how appearances seem substantial yet lack inherent existence upon investigation. This recognition gradually extends from external objects to include all internal experiences, dissolving the apparent boundary between outer and inner, matter and consciousness, self and other.
[3128-3147] The comprehensive scope of illusory body practice encompasses every possible experience without exception. Self and other appearances, friend and enemy relationships, material necessities like food and clothing, all sensory enjoyments, pleasant and unpleasant sounds, philosophical positions of acceptance and rejection, the fundamental events of birth and death, emotional experiences of happiness and suffering, physical conditions of illness—all are brought within the scope of recognition. Nothing is excluded from this view, for exclusion itself would constitute a subtle form of reification.
[3148-3168] The text provides scriptural authority from the Inquiry of Bhadrapāla Sūtra and the King of Samādhi Sūtra. These citations employ three primary analogies: the water-moon (appearing clearly yet empty of substance), magical illusions (creations without inherent existence), and the plantain tree (lacking a solid core). Each metaphor points to the same recognition—that phenomena appear vividly while being empty of independent nature. The mirror itself becomes the primary symbol: it reflects all forms without being affected, modified, or limited by what appears within it.
[3160-3177] The recognition of birth and death as illusory dissolves the fundamental anxiety that drives cyclic existence. When the practitioner views these transitions as dream-appearances, the compulsive grasping that perpetuates rebirth naturally relaxes. The text cites the example of a young woman dreaming of giving birth to a son—her joy at his birth and grief at his death, both intense yet both equally unreal. All phenomena share this nature: manifesting clearly without existing as they appear.
[3178-3184] At this stage, qualities of the path of preparation may naturally manifest. The Ornament of Clear Realization describes twelve signs indicating the peak of the path of preparation: viewing all phenomena within dreams as dreamlike. This represents not imagination but the natural expression of recognition having permeated the mindstream so thoroughly that it operates regardless of the state—waking, dreaming, or meditative absorption.
[3185-3197] Through continuous daytime and nighttime training in illusory body, fixation on inherent existence dissolves. The body itself begins to manifest shadow-like—appearing clearly without substantial solidity. This recognition prepares the practitioner for the bardo illusory body, ensuring confidence in navigating the intermediate state. Historical examples include the precious guru Gyalwa Zhangton and the scholar Nyibum, who demonstrated this capacity through their own realization and manifestation.
02 17 09 02
[3198-3206] The clear-light four-times equal-application section opens as the fourth and final method for luminosity practice, building systematically on three previous approaches. The structural function introduces the culminating practice method, establishing the complete mandala of clear-light training. The view register presents Dzogchen clear-light ('od gsal) as foundational ground nature, not as produced state or achieved condition. Translation risk: this could be conflated with lower tantra clear-light practices focused on stage achievement, or treated as a yogic state to produce rather than recognition of ever-present nature. Preservation priority: the four-time structure (dus bzhi)—external, internal, secret, suchness—establishes a complete mandala covering all temporal conditions without exception, demonstrating how clear-light recognition operates across the full spectrum of experience.
[3207-3224] The root text citation establishes the comprehensive framework through verse structure covering yogi's physical training, verbal training, mental training, and integration. External time: four aspects training body's capacity, channels as source held as essential point. Internal time: four aspects training speech's capacity, cutting through verbal elaborations. Secret time: four aspects training mind's capacity, resting uncontrived mind in natural state. Suchness time: four aspects integrating body-speech-mind, mixing clear-light with sleep. The structural function presents concise encapsulation of complete path through four dimensions. The view register presents these as recognition supports, not progressive stages. Translation risk: the verse's brevity can obscure extensive practices it references, suggesting simpler method than actual content. Preservation: the citation structure—root verse followed by detailed exposition—follows standard Tibetan pedagogical form. The four key points (daytime, dusk, midnight, dawn) provide temporal structure organizing practice across the full day-night cycle.
[3225-3256] Daytime practice integrates samadhi and post-meditation with sleep yoga as continuous clear-light recognition. Lion-posture (seng ge'i nyal lugs) provides specific physical configuration: lying on right side, left hand supporting cheek, legs crossed in vajra position. Holding awareness on five-light sphere within heart center while external appearances gradually diminish, recognition of thought-free clarity emerges at the threshold between waking and sleep. Sleep itself becomes clear-light display without dream content—awareness abides in samadhi's nature, self-luminous. If awareness enters sleep, nearby forms-sounds-smells continue perceived without interruption; if awareness does not enter sleep entirely, conditions cause emergence from that state. Daytime appearances merely represent conceptual cessation while appearance-essence remains luminously present. The structural function provides detailed exposition of primary practice period demonstrating waking-sleep continuity. The view register presents integration of waking and sleeping states as seamless clear-light continuity, not separate practices. Translation risk: treating sleep yoga as separate practice from daytime recognition misses their identity; or treating sleep as merely another state to observe rather than clear-light display itself. Preservation requires maintaining precise phenomenological threshold: six-collection conceptual consciousness ceases while five-gate consciousnesses remain clear—this distinction establishes the exact recognition point.
[3257-3297] Three types of clear-light recognition provide analytical framework for what is actually unified recognition: bliss-clear-light, clarity-clear-light, non-conceptual-clear-light. These are pedagogical differentiations of the non-dual ground, not separate experiences to achieve. Bliss-clear-light: arises from blissful equipoise, coemergent joy, cannot be separated from samadhi, produces joy-bliss perception. Clarity-clear-light: produces smoke, mirage, fireflies, clouds, lightning, blazing, moon, eclipse, dark jewel forms, five-light appearances, bindus, deity forms, beings, pure lands, perception through coarse obstructions like walls and fences, clairvoyances. Non-conceptual-clear-light: samadhi-day-night indistinguishable, whatever appears meets thought-free spaciousness, whatever topic meets effortless thought-free flow, abiding continuously in sky-like expanse, immeasurable experiences. The structural function provides analytical differentiation of unified recognition. The view register presents pedagogical distinction of non-dual ground for recognition support. Translation risk: reifying the three as separate experiences rather than aspects of single recognition; or treating signs (smoke, mirage, etc.) as goals rather than natural recognition markers. Preservation: the signs of clarity-clear-light are standard Indian and Tibetan meditative phenomenology—these must be preserved as technical terms without reduction to metaphor or psychology.
[3298-3306] Post-meditation integration establishes continuity between formal practice and daily activity without separation. Rising from samadhi, external appearances are viewed as five-light forms, beings and elements as illusion, eight similes of illusion, sky-simile—whatever experience arises, integrated with emptiness-clarity appearance without fixation, unified evenly. The structural function establishes continuity between formal practice and daily activity. The view register presents Dzogchen view maintained without separation between sessions—recognition continues without distinction between meditation and post-meditation. Translation risk: "post-meditation" (rjes thob) terminology can imply something inferior to samadhi, or recognition that fades, rather than continuous recognition. Preservation: the eight similes of illusion (sgyu ma'i dpe brgyad) and sky-simile (nam mkha' ltar) are standard Madhyamaka-Dzogchen integration points, connecting analytical understanding with direct recognition. The dusk, midnight, and dawn sections follow this pattern with specific emphases appropriate to those times—dusk emphasizes sense-faculty gathering, midnight emphasizes objects entering vase, dawn emphasizes wisdom clarification.
02 17 10 01
[3307-3308] Clear light meditation: resting in AH syllable clarity, allowing focus to dissolve without following thoughts. Clear, pure, open awareness remains—half-clear, half-empty, appearing naturally without fabrication. Rest without suppressing or encouraging what arises. Direct experience requires diligent practice.
[3309-3312] Transference ('pho ba) three types by practitioner capacity: superior from clear light, intermediate from illusory body, lesser from body-speech. Distinctions reflect awareness-vitality (blo rtsal) levels, not destinations. Recognition capacity determines transition quality.
[3313-3324] Clear light mastered: awareness departs Brahma aperture into dharmadhātu. Illusory body mastered: departs into dharmatā divine body, mastering bardo illusory body, achieving awakening. Neither mastered: body, speech, mind depart with channels and winds through Brahma aperture.
[3325-3336] Body-speech transference: with support (channels, winds, sound, craft, illusory arts) and without support (mind's familiarity power alone). Brahma aperture as pathway. Vajra Seat citation: upper nine apertures projection carries liberation certainty.
[3337-3344] Severe transgressions reference functions as hyperbolic affirmation of practice's power, not ethical instruction. Transference transcends heaviest karmic patterns when accomplished properly.
[3345-3353] Union-bardo instructions: union crucial point realized in this life, actual guidance for bardo. Four bardos: birth-death, dream, dharmatā, existence. Encompass full transitional range.
[3354-3353] Developmental progression: practitioner may begin body-speech, progress to illusory body, stabilize clear light. Thalgyur citation confirms threefold structure by sense faculties (dbang po). Destination same: dharmatā recognition. Manner of arrival differs.
02 17 11 01
[3354-3389] Structural function: This section establishes the foundational training for bardo recognition through the union of daytime practice and dream-state familiarity. The text presents a graduated approach where practitioners first stabilize recognition of the illusory body and clear light during waking hours, then extend this recognition into the dream state. This methodological progression serves as the preliminary groundwork for the actual bardo instructions that follow. The arrangement reflects the standard Dzogchen pedagogical structure: establishing the view through daily practice before addressing the intermediate state.
[3389-3432] Structural function: The second major section addresses the actual bardo instructions proper, presenting the dissolution sequence of elements at death. This follows the standard progression from preliminary training to direct application. The text describes the sequential dissolution of earth into water, water into fire, fire into wind, wind into space, and finally space into clear light, culminating in the recognition of the four wisdoms. This structural arrangement mirrors the universal Buddhist presentation of the death process while incorporating Dzogchen-specific recognitions of the clear light mother-and-child union.
[3432-3516] Structural function: The third major section turns to the Sugata intention meditation, presenting the ocean-settling method as the culmination of meditation practice. This section establishes the framework for continuous practice without distinction between day and night. The structural progression moves from the metaphorical basis (ocean eye water essence), through the method (unblinking gaze), to the result (six sense-fields liberated into vastness). This arrangement serves as the practical application manual for the view previously established.
[3517-3574] Structural function: This section presents the result of the Sugata intention meditation: the arising of dharmatā as the ground-settled view. The structural arrangement presents the fruition as the spontaneous liberation of afflictions into pristine wisdom. This represents the completion phase of the meditation framework, demonstrating how the practice matures into recognition. The multiple quotations from the Six Expanses establish the textual foundation for this spontaneous liberation view.
[3575-3599] Structural function: The fourth major section addresses the view of cutting the continuum of the city, establishing the recognition of one's own view as the foundation for continuous practice. This section presents four subdivisions: the view itself, its essential point instruction, its intention, and its result. This fourfold structure provides a comprehensive framework for view recognition that can be applied throughout all activities. The progression from view to result establishes the complete path within this single recognition.
[3616-3599] View register: The perspective here presents the threefold recognition: outer phenomena as appearance without self-nature (seen through the vajra eye), inner dharmatā as absence of self-nature (seen through the wisdom eye), and secret rigpa as non-duality of expanse and rigpa. This threefold schema encompasses the complete Dzogchen view—from the conventional appearance of phenomena to the ultimate recognition of non-dual awareness. The metaphor of the mountain peak view captures the comprehensive scope: from the summit, all lower valleys are visible simultaneously, while from below, the summit remains unseen.
[3693-3599] Translation risk: The term "secret rigpa" here refers to the non-dual recognition of expanse and awareness, not to any hidden or esoteric teaching. This technical usage requires precise rendering to avoid misinterpretation as referring to concealed instruction. The threefold liberation outcomes—superior practitioners achieving buddhahood in this life, intermediate in the bardo, last as natural emanation bodies—represent a standard soteriological framework in Dzogchen literature. These categories establish a graduated path while maintaining the view that all are equally expressions of natural liberation.
[3765-3599] Structural function: This section presents the essential point instruction of the mountain peak settling method, demonstrating how the comprehensive view enables simultaneous recognition of all vehicle intentions. The structural arrangement establishes the practitioner as one who sees all from the peak while others cannot see this perspective. This metaphor captures the Dzogchen self-understanding as the summit of all paths. The subsequent presentation of the great liberation of the three realms establishes the scope of this recognition.
[3852-3599] View register: The perspective here presents the spontaneous liberation of afflictions without abandonment or transformation. This "afflictions settled in their place" view represents the Dzogchen approach to emotional transformation—not through suppression or transformation, but through recognition of their empty nature. The multiple quotations from the Six Expanses enumerate how various afflictions and perceptions self-liberate when recognized as mind's display. This establishes the non-dual ethics of the tradition where conventional distinctions dissolve into natural purity.
[3901-3599] Preservation note: The catalog of self-liberating phenomena—desire, hatred, ignorance, and the various sense objects—follows traditional Buddhist enumerative structures. These lists serve as meditation supports and recognition frameworks, requiring preservation of their comprehensive scope. The concluding identification of this as "the person who has abandoned dharmas" refers not to nihilistic rejection but to the transcendence of fixation that characterizes complete recognition.
02 17 12 01
[3600-3623] Verbal view discriminations (tshig gi lta ba) enumerate seven conceptual formulations: primordially free from action, naturally liberated without effort, progressive guidance through superior intelligence, transcendence of virtue and vice, great non-doing and non-arising, unmodified self-purity, and self-arisen self-liberation. Each captures a dimension of Dzogchen view through progressive refinement. These formulations serve as navigational tools—accurate descriptions that point toward recognition without constituting recognition itself.
[3624-3638] The seven discriminations represent comprehensive classifications of Dzogchen Great Perfection view. Verbal view encompasses conceptual formulations that approximate direct recognition through philosophical precision. Meaning view refers to the actual face-to-face encounter with awareness itself, beyond conceptuality. The boundary between them marks the transition from intellectual understanding to direct perception.
[3639-3669] Nine progressive views correspond to the nine yānas, organized in fourfold schema: outer, inner, secret, and unsurpassed. Outer view examines phenomena (chos can) through eight stages of mind's discrimination. Inner view recognizes nature and characteristics as illusion. Secret view perceives karmic connections as chains of dependent origination. The unsurpassed view recognizes the suchness of expanse and rigpa as non-dual. This structure demonstrates Dzogchen as culmination while maintaining the validity of progressive refinement.
[3670-3693] The four aspects of nature view include: abiding view—samsara and nirvana primordially beyond suffering; pure-seeing view—transcending cause, effect, effort, and achievement; nature view—appearance and existence naturally liberated; and unfabricated view—great expansive openness beyond extremes. Each aspect addresses a specific dimension of fixation, demonstrating completeness through multiple entry points rather than single philosophical formulation.
[3694-3705] The boundary of general view relates to individual realization versus verbal formulation. The boundary of verbal view is mental discrimination (yid dpyod). The meaning view transcends discrimination entirely. The Thalgyur citation establishes this framework: words function as causes of expression and thought, leading to conceptual understanding that must eventually be transcended through direct perception.
[3706-3708] Recognizing one's own view as action-free spontaneous accomplishment means recognizing what is primordially present rather than achieved. This innate recognition dissolves the duality between practitioner and path. The view is not something to be attained but something to be acknowledged—always already the case, requiring only the removal of obscuring misconceptions.
02 17 13 01
[3709-3731] Threefold view recognition progresses from outer to inner to secret. Outer recognition perceives phenomena lacking self-nature through the vajra eye of discriminating wisdom. Inner recognition perceives dharmatā lacking self-nature through the eye of pristine awareness. Secret recognition perceives the non-duality of expanse and rigpa. This structure moves from conventional appearance to ultimate recognition, addressing progressively subtler dimensions of fixation.
[3732-3743] Outer view examines phenomena as appearance without inherent existence. The eight similes of illusion—dream, magical illusion, mirage, echo, reflection, city of gandharvas, optical illusion, and water-moon—dissolve reification that generates cyclic existence. No doubt remains about returning to the three realms when the empty nature of phenomena is fully recognized. This confidence emerges naturally from seeing through the apparent solidity of experience.
[3744-3763] Inner view recognizes dharmatā through the wisdom eye. The nature of mind is unborn and self-arisen; self-awareness lacks even the mind that grasps. This recognition transcends effort and achievement, existing beyond the duality of doing and done. The Self-Arisen citations describe this as great meditation—rigpa that does not fall into any partiality, beyond acceptance and rejection, affirmation and denial.
[3764-3787] Secret view recognizes expanse and rigpa as non-dual. This transcends the subject-object duality that structures outer and inner views. The liberating function is described as "cutting the continuum of the city"—interrupting the cyclic flow of existence from womb to womb, preventing return to the three realms. From this recognition, buddhahood can be achieved in this very lifetime without further rebirth.
[3788-3815] Scriptural citations from Sun-Moon Union and Self-Arisen establish authoritative basis for these recognitions. Graduated capacities determine results: the superior practitioner achieves without passing through the two births (ordinary birth and bardo birth), the intermediate practitioner achieves in the bardo state, and the lesser practitioner achieves at exhalation of the final breath. These distinctions reflect preparation levels rather than fundamental differences in potential.
[3816-3841] The mountain peak settling method (ri bo cog gzhag) demonstrates how comprehensive view encompasses all vehicle intentions. From the summit, all valleys are simultaneously visible; from below the summit, the summit itself remains unseen. Dzogchen operates as the summit of all paths—the nine yānas are recognized within its system, while other systems cannot fully comprehend its intention. This is not superiority in a competitive sense but completeness of perspective.
[3842-3851] The view encompasses all nine yānas, recognizing their intentions as aspects of its own complete understanding. The three realms are completely liberated into great purity—nothing exists outside recognition, no realm remains to be purified. This is not achieved through effort but recognized as always already the case. The practitioner who recognizes this finds nothing unliberated, no bondage to escape, no liberation to achieve.
[3867-3851] The intention of view manifests as great liberation of the three realms. For the recognizing yogin, nothing remains unliberated—all has transcended the duality of bondage and liberation from the very beginning. This fruition is recognition of what always was, not attainment of something new. The Six Expanses citations describe appearances as baseless self-arisen great expanse display—like dreams, illusions, and sky. Equal purity pervades all phenomena.
[3893-3851] Six Expanses passages elaborate this recognition: mind without arising or feeling, appearance without superior contemplation, consciousness without going or coming; mind without grasping, appearance as pure unceasing display, great play as samadhi; mind without fixation, self-arisen great appearance, non-ceasing non-conceptual intention; mind without affliction, appearance free of self-concept, great settling intention; mind without eternalism or nihilism, appearance free of good and bad, intention free of acceptance and rejection; mind without adopting or rejecting, appearance as directionless self-liberation, vast pervasion intention.
[3918-3851] Result of view manifests as afflictions settled in their place without abandonment or transformation. This spontaneous liberation operates like clouds clearing in the sky or silt settling in water—the natural resolution of disturbance without deliberate intervention. Three temporal dimensions describe this: initially confusion is not experienced as substantial, presently confusion is not abided in as a state, finally confusion becomes impossible as a basis has been thoroughly recognized.
[3943-3851] The person who has abandoned dharmas has not rejected phenomena but transcended fixation upon them. This completes the fourfold structure: view, essential point, intention, and result. View transforms experience directly rather than merely providing philosophical understanding. The Dzogchen practitioner does not accumulate new knowledge but recognizes the nature of what already is—afflictions as wisdom, confusion as clarity, cyclic existence as transcendence.
[3968-3851] The final sections describe fruition through recognition. Virtue and vice, acceptance and rejection, effort and achievement—all dissolve into the single sphere of awareness. The practitioner who recognizes this does not become something other than what they were but realizes what they always were. This recognition is not an event in time but the timeless nature of awareness itself, suddenly and completely revealed.
02 17 14 01
[3852-3921] Royal caste empowerment analogy. First simile: spyi bo nas dbang bskur—head empowerment conferring royal status. Rig pa rang sa zin—rigpa taking its own place—as parallel to king taking throne. Key point: chos nyid las mi 'gyur—unchanging from dharmatā. The analogy establishes self-recognition as enthronement without alteration of nature. Translation risk: literal rendering may suggest achievement rather than recognition of primordial status. Preserve the taking-place metaphor as self-existing, not accomplished. Three royal analogies sequential. Second: king's army to frontier, king-subject circle changes without fixed location. Sgo lnga'i rnam shes—five gate consciousnesses—dawning while ground empty. Samsara nameless because ground empty of inherent existence. Third: minister captured by foreign king, original king must listen to other's commands. Yi kyi rnam par shes pa—mental consciousness continuum—ceasing. Rig pa obtains rang dbang—self-power<span class="term">/autonomy. Structure traces progressive release from conditioned consciousness to self-existing awareness. Fruit irreversibility. 'Bras bu rgyur mi ldog—fruit non-returning to cause—like sandalwood fruit. Rtsol bas byas pa—effort-made arisen—negated. Ye nas de ltar gnas—primordially thus abiding. Tha snyad—mere designation—applied to 'bras bu. This is crucial Dzogchen point: fruition is recognition, not production. Translation must preserve the negative formulation: not like effort-result, rather primordial thusness arriving at what was already the case. Cog gzhag instruction and kLong drug pa citation. All rigpa nature: ye nas rang shar rang gnas rang grol—primordially self-arisen, self-dwelling, self-liberated. Thag chod—definite decision/</span>decisive certainty—as view. Gang shar—whatever dawns—de nyid shar sa der—at that very dawning-place. Bcos bslad med par—without fabrication or alteration—phyal yas su 'jog pa—set openly<span class="term">/spaciously. Citation enumerates five aspects: sems nyid as basis, re dog bral—free from hope-fear, rtsol sgrub bral—free from effort-accomplishment, sku gsum tshang—complete three kayas, theg pa so sor rang shar—vehicles self-arisen individually. Ka dag exposition with citation. Srid gsum ka dag—three realms primordially pure—sgom gsum—three gates—zhen rtog—grasping-thought—dang bag chags thams cad—all action and imprints—rang sangs chen por dag—purify as great self-purification. 'Khor 'das re dog dang bral—free from samsara-nirvana hope-fear. Second citation emphasizes: ya ngad med pa—without suffering, re dog bral—hope-fear free, ye gzhag gdeng ldan—primordially settled with confidence, as dgongs pa—intention/</span>meaning. Snying po yang gsang—heart essence great secret—as designation. Nyon mongs ngar grol—afflictions naturally liberated. Whatever arises, tshugs mi thub—unable to remain<span class="term">/fixate—zung med—without grasping—thad drang du rang zhig rang grol—directly self-liberated. Water-mirror and snake-knot analogies: dissolve naturally without intervention. 'Khor 'das kyi 'dzin pa dang bral—free from samsara-nirvana grasping. Chos las 'das pa—gone beyond dharma. Rnal 'byor pa—yogin—as title for one who has passed beyond. Systematic rang sar dag—self-purification enumeration. Klong drug pa citation traces twelve-fold purification: dmigs pa/</span>perception, tshor ba<span class="term">/feeling, 'du shes/</span>perception, gzugs<span class="term">/form, rnam shes/</span>consciousness, 'byung ba<span class="term">/elements, tshor ba/</span>sensation, 'du shes<span class="term">/discrimination, nyon mongs/</span>afflictions, dran pa/mindfulness. Each dawns from sems nyid—mind itself—and purifies rang sar—at its own place. Structure demonstrates all aggregates, elements, and afflictions as self-purifying when recognized as sems nyid display. Chapter colophon. Damigs pa yul gyi blo rim can—those with mind levels of objects and aims—'jug pa'i lam—path of entering. Zab rgya che—profound and vast. Rim khang bcu bdun pa—seventeenth stage. Spros pa la dga' ba—those delighting in elaboration—as target audience. Structural marker concluding elaborate path section before transitioning to beyond-elaboration. Preserve the pedagogical framing: this was path for those needing elaboration.
02 18 01 01
[3922-3941] Structural function: Establishes the chapter's organizing principle through seven excellences that distinguish this vehicle from common paths. The opening frame introduces the "secret great display of the good path of rigpa's self-appearance" as the topic, immediately signaling a Dzogchen view context. The seven excellences function not as hierarchical claims but as pedagogical distinctions pointing to recognition beyond effort-based attainment. View register: Recognition operates independently of faculty sharpness or dullness. Unlike gradual paths where superior intellect accelerates realization while dull faculties impede it, this approach establishes that recognition manifests equally regardless of effort intensity. The faculties do not transform—recognition simply occurs. Translation risk: "Superior" (khyad par 'phags) risks sectarian interpretation. The Tibetan emphasizes functional distinction rather than ontological hierarchy. The phrase "not depending on conceptual assessment" (yid dpyod la mi ltos pa) is critical—preserving the non-conceptual nature of recognition prevents reading this as philosophy rather than direct perception. Preservation: The seven excellences form a complete framework: (1) faculties without sharp-dull distinction, (2) no dependence on conceptual assessment, (3) single-syllable recognition of meaning, (4) no dependence on intellectually fabricated ground-path-result, (5) no dependence on karmic cause-effect, (6) no age distinction for youth-elder, (7) three kayas as path-appearances. These are not additive achievements but simultaneous recognition aspects.
[3942-3978] Structural function: Situates this teaching within Dzogchen's own typology by comparing with Atiyoga's three divisions—Mind, Space, and Instruction. The dialectical structure responds to potential objection: if this is Atiyoga, how does it exceed Ati? The answer distinguishes recognition depth rather than claiming sectarian superiority. View register: Even within Atiyoga, limitations exist. Mind Division establishes confidence in the unfabricated ground but remains at conceptual assessment. Instruction Division with its three cycles of outer, inner, and secret focuses on intermediate state timing. This teaching contains the excellence of light-body liberation, distinguishing it functionally without hierarchy. Translation risk: The jewel-lamp simile (3972-3977) requires careful handling. The citation from Pramanaviniscaya establishes that although wrong awareness and jewel-light-perceiving awareness are equally "awareness," they differ functionally in accomplishing purpose. This is not about "better awareness" but about recognition's efficacy. Preservation: The three Atiyoga divisions each have specific orientations: Mind Division toward vast ground-free confidence, Space Division toward unfabricated spontaneity, Instruction Division toward intermediate state timing. This teaching transcends these limitations through direct light-body recognition, not by negating them but by including their scope within immediate perception.
[3979-3993] Structural function: Canonical seal through Talgyur citation encapsulating the seven excellences in verse form. The structural movement from prose exposition to canonical citation provides authoritative closure to the superiority presentation. View register: Primordial purity recognized through direct perception (chos nyid mngon sum). The verse emphasizes that wisdom sees through faculties, not through intellect—preserving the non-conceptual core. Common vehicles fail to accomplish meaning not through deficiency but through depending on words and concepts rather than direct recognition. Translation risk: "Three kayas as path-appearances" (sku gsum lam snang) is easily misconstrued as achieving kayas through path practice rather than recognizing kayas as intrinsic display. "Not reversing the three realms" (khams gsum ldog pa min) requires context—this refers to non-rejection, not non-transformation. Preservation: The verse structure mirrors the seven excellences: direct perception of dharma-nature, no good-evil in karma, Heart Essence definitive summary, faculties without dull-sharp, conceptual thought and words ended, wisdom not intellect, words do not see dharma-nature, common vehicles do not accomplish meaning, three kayas as path-appearances. This encapsulation serves as mnemonic and transmission vehicle.
[3994-4021] Structural function: Transitions from theoretical superiority to practical prerequisites—empowerment and samaya. The structural division into ripening empowerment and liberating instruction establishes the two-phase pedagogical model. This section covers empowerment, leaving samaya for subsequent lines. View register: Empowerment as ripening (smin pa), not conferring what is absent. The four empowerments transform body, speech, and mind into their natural states through recognition, not fabrication. Outer empowerment with elaboration: body transforms into deity body through mandala and vase support. Inner without elaboration: speech transforms through the unexpressed meaning of the syllable A. Secret: mind arrives at its own nature. Most secret: all three transformed simultaneously through posture and gaze. Translation risk: Standard tantric terminology (empowerment, vase, mandala) risks interpretation through lower vehicle frameworks. The phrase "obtaining power over body" (lus...dbang thob pa) could imply acquisition rather than recognition. Preservation requires emphasizing that these are supports for recognition, not constructions. Preservation: The four empowerments have distinct effects: body as deity body, outer container as palace; speech as deity recitation, inner inexpressible meaning experienced; mind arrives at entity nature, experiences clear-light meaning; posture liberates into three kaya postures, speech-cutting liberates sound power, mind blessing stimulates clear-light. These are descriptions of natural state, not achievements.
[4022-4057] Structural function: Detailed exposition of empowerment effects and the necessity of samaya as supporting condition. The structural movement from empowerment effects to samaya establishes dependency—ripening requires maintenance through observance. View register: Ripening of body, speech, and mind corresponds to generation stage, uncommon power, and completion stage signs. When all three ripenings complete, the direct perception path of dharma-nature fully manifests. Samaya as root of accomplishment—pleasing the guru generates all siddhis. This is not transactional but recognition-based: the guru represents the nature of mind, so devotion to guru stabilizes recognition of nature. Translation risk: "Pleasing the guru" (bla ma mnyes pa) carries risk of cultic interpretation. The Tibetan context emphasizes recognizing the guru as manifestation of awareness, not personality worship. Physical, verbal, and mental service each have specific modes—not arbitrary devotion but recognition-supporting practice. Preservation: Samaya has three gates: body through respectful service (rising, mandala offering, washing feet, anointing, gazing homage, seeing homage), speech through focusing on qualities not faults, mind through emulating activity and generating faith in others. The canonical citations from Damtsig Chenpo and Drwa Ba Sengden establish the authoritative foundation. The key principle: never transgressing the guru's mind-intention.
[4058-4080] Structural function: Transition from samaya to instruction proper. The structural formula "having ripened, liberating" (smin pa grol ba) establishes the sequence—empowerment and samaya prepare the vessel, instruction pours the contents. The threefold instruction typology (khrid, ngo sprod, tsang sprugs) maps to trekcho, thogal, and intermediate state teachings. View register: Instruction as direct pointing, not explanation. The three types—guidance system, direct introduction, and challenging the guest—represent different pedagogical approaches to the same recognition. Trekcho as direct introduction hitting all-at-once; thogal as challenging completion; intermediate state instruction as guiding through transition. Translation risk: Instruction terminology (gdams ngag) risks interpretation as information transfer. The phrase "cutting through" (khregs chod) and "direct leap" (thod rgal) require preservation as technical terms with specific phenomenological referents, not merely poetic language. Preservation: The three instruction types have distinct applications: guidance system for systematic practitioners, direct introduction for those with sharp faculties, challenging completion for intermediate state preparation. All three serve the same function—triggering recognition of what is already the case. The structural inclusion here anticipates detailed exposition in subsequent sections.
[4081-4093] Structural function: Preliminary practice section opening—establishing the necessity and nature of preliminary practices. The structural question-answer format (what precedes, how it precedes, simile, purpose, classification) provides comprehensive coverage. View register: Preliminaries as "clearing fears"—like investigating dangerous terrain before travel, preliminary practice removes obstacles to main practice. The essential point: without preliminaries, main practice recognition cannot stabilize; without main practice, preliminary practice produces no result. They function as mutual supports. Translation risk: Preliminary practice risks being dismissed as "lesser" or "preparatory" in a hierarchical sense. The Tibetan emphasizes functional necessity rather than temporal sequence. The metaphor of king's summons or horse saddling indicates inevitability and preparation, not subordination. Preservation: Preliminary practice has five aspects: what precedes (transcending worldly mind), how it precedes (purifying body-speech-mind of accumulated obscurations), simile (unavoidable preparation), purpose (easy main practice, confidence, no obstacles), classification (three introductions—kaya, rigpa, mind). The male-female agricultural partnership simile establishes that both are necessary, neither sufficient alone.
[4094-4120] Structural function: Detailed preliminary practice exposition—the three introductions. The structural organization follows the classification: body introduction through element yoga, rigpa introduction through samsara-nirvana distinction conduct, mind introduction through body-speech-mind nature practice. View register: The three introductions progressively refine recognition: body through element sound training establishes pure perception of environment; rigpa through distinction conduct separates samsara from nirvahana recognition; mind through body-speech-mind nature stabilizes recognition of natural state. Translation risk: "Element yoga" ('byung ba'i rnam 'byor) risks confusion with Hindu yoga or other Buddhist element practices. The specific reference is to training in the sounds of earth, water, fire, wind—the four elements' qualities as support for recognition. Preservation: Body introduction: training in four element sounds with emphasis on earth, water, fire, wind. Rigpa introduction: distinction conduct separating samsara from nirvana—without this distinction, body-speech-mind cannot connect to meaning. Mind introduction: training in body-speech-mind nature. Canonical citations from Talgyur and Gyutrul establish lineage continuity.
[4121-4155] Structural function: View section detailed exposition—stillness, movement, and awareness as dharmakāya. The structural progression from conduct to view follows the standard sequence, but here with emphasis on recognition rather than cultivation. View register: Ordinary mind (tha mal gyi shes pa) as technical term for rigpa in natural state. Stillness without thought, movement with thought, and naked awareness—each recognized as dharmakāya establishes non-dual view. This is not intellectual understanding but direct recognition. Translation risk: "Ordinary mind" risks confusion with conventional consciousness. The Tibetan specifies unmodified, unfabricated awareness—not the ordinary mind of delusion but the ordinary nature of awareness. "Dhramakaya" here refers to nature, not achievement. Preservation: The three aspects—stillness, movement, awareness—each have dharmakāya nature. Stillness: no thought, empty essence. Movement: with thought, clear nature. Awareness: knowing, unobstructed compassion. These are not sequential stages but simultaneous aspects of recognition. The threefold structure serves as recognition support, not graduated path.
02 18 02 01
[4156-4169] Structural function: Opening of body conduct section with authoritative citation from Sangye Sechik. The structural function establishes scriptural foundation for the twenty-one fold conduct practice. The verse enumerates body activities that will serve as the basis for distinction practice. View register: Conduct as spontaneous expression of recognition, not discipline imposed from without. The activities enumerated—running, lying, rising, limb movement, circling, prostration, limb circling, head rolling, remembered actions, dance, mudra transformation, envisioned actions—all become vehicles for recognition when distinction is made. The key phrase body manifest attachment self-ceases indicates natural cessation through recognition, not forced restraint. Translation risk: The phrase body manifest attachment self-ceases could imply a process of cessation rather than recognition of natural cessation. The twenty-one aspects begin here with body, and the animal similes that follow map to specific qualities requiring preservation. Preservation: The citation establishes the complete range of body activities that can serve as recognition support. The distinction ru shan is the operative verb—making clear divisions between ordinary and enlightened activity, not between acceptable and prohibited. The translator activity body that transforms indicates this is about recognition of transformation, not cultivation of transformation.
[4170-4192] Structural function: Talgyur citation elaborating the conduct framework with tantric authorization. The structural movement from general enumeration to tantric source establishes lineage continuity and method authority. View register: Tantric conduct as means, not end. The enumeration of body activities—moving, sitting, gathering, various exercises, limb extending and withdrawing, various activities, mind of mindfulness grasping manifestly—provides comprehensive inventory. The six realms form conduct—all taken by mind, enacted by body. The two purposes establish dual benefit structure: common purification of body karma, supreme preparation for illusory body practice. Translation risk: The list of activities can read as mere inventory rather than comprehensive coverage. Grasping with mind of mindfulness could be interpreted as deliberate control rather than recognition-based engagement. Preservation: The Talgyur citation provides tantric authorization for the conduct approach. The Great Array Sutra citation at line 4184 grounds the practice in canonical authority. The key phrase whoever is able to enact conduct, like that thought later continuity ceases establishes that recognition in conduct interrupts samsaric continuity. This is not about activity cessation but fixation cessation.
[4193-4214] Structural function: Detailed exposition of body distinction practice—the first of three gates. The structural function provides practical instruction with time periods and result markers. View register: Body as foundation—since attachment arose through body initially, body must be starting point for reversal. The time periods are calibrated to individual capacity: seven days, eleven days, or half month. The three results establish progressive markers: external attachment reversed, internal body pacified, secret illusory body liberated. These are recognition signs, not achievement milestones. Translation risk: The time periods could be read as arbitrary or mandatory rather than calibrated indicators. Illusory body could be interpreted as visualization rather than recognition of body's natural state. Preservation: The Golden Essence Tantra citation provides lineage continuity. The three results correspond to three gates: external body attachment reversed, internal body pacification, secret illusory body clear-light liberation. The method body conduct done, afterward body karma exhausted, not delighting in doing, body misdeeds purified establishes the function—not activity accumulation but fixation exhaustion.
[4215-4260] Structural function: Transition to speech conduct section—completing body, moving to speech as middle gate. The structural function maintains architectural consistency with body section while addressing speech's unique characteristics. View register: Speech as connective tissue between body and mind. The diversity of languages—god, naga, yaksha, smell-eater, mermaid, pervader—represents comprehensive communication range, not exotic enumeration. Speech distinction cuts samsara-nirvana through the diversity of expression, not through silence. Translation risk: The diversity of languages could be exoticized or dismissed as mythology rather than understood as comprehensive communication range. The twenty-one fold structure continues from body section and requires recognition as systematic coverage. Preservation: The Secret Conduct Seed Tantra citation establishes the twenty-one fold structure continues. The Talgyur citation elaborates: having reached signs and measure, yogin begins speech conduct. Understanding expressed nature, various speech sounds, whatever spoken not reversed—this establishes that recognition in speech is not about what is said but about fixation on expression. The two purposes parallel body section: common cutting of three realms wheel, supreme liberation into three kayas.
[4261-4303] Structural function: Mind conduct section completion—culminating the three gates with mind as fruit. The structural function establishes mind as root of samsara and therefore key to liberation. View register: Mind conduct cuts the root of samsara. The enumeration of mental states—joy and displeasure, happiness and suffering, permanent and impermanent, view and meditation conduct intention, dharma and non-dharma, attachment aversion delusion, virtue and non-virtue—establishes comprehensive range. The essential point: body and speech free from attachment allows mind root to be cut. Translation risk: Three realms wheel ceases could be read as achievement rather than recognition of natural cessation. The comprehensive enumeration of mental states risks being read as checklist rather than recognition that all mental states are equally empty in essence. Preservation: The Sangye Sechik citation establishes authoritative foundation. The Talgyur citation elaborates: having reached measure, yogin trains mind. Past future present, memory thought gathering-dispersing wheel—this establishes that mind conduct encompasses temporal and cognitive range.
