The final citation from Khorlo Tsekpa seals the three-fold presentation: whoever distinguishes mind's distinction, this does not return to mind—indicating recognition beyond subject-object.
[4304-4345] Structural function: Integration and conclusion of distinction conduct. The structural function demonstrates how three gates together prevent entry into three realms and establish the connection to empowerment and view. View register: Integration as non-separation of practice and view. The term ru shan appears throughout as operative verb—making clear divisions between samsara and nirvana recognition, not gradual refinement. The three gates together function as complete practice: body as ground, speech as path, mind as fruit. Translation risk: Treating this as sequential practice rather than simultaneous recognition misses the essential point. The time periods mentioned could be interpreted as graduated curriculum rather than recognition stabilization markers. Preservation: The Dang Nyer Tokpa citation establishes authority: distinction made, not returning to three realms, stability shown, these are preliminary rites. The structural note—today's lazy ones given to mental preliminary followed by direct introduction—indicates historical adaptation. The essential point: diligent ones may liberate in three months through this practice alone, middling and lesser ones follow direct introduction afterward.
[4346-4367] Structural function: Main practice section opening—defining main practice through fourfold analysis. The structural fourfold division provides comprehensive typology: base but not entity, entity but not base, neither base nor entity, both base and entity. View register: Main practice as recognition beyond four extremes. The metaphors establish clarity: seeing palace without seeing king—some Dzogchen practitioners see base but not entity, arriving at natural death. Seeing king without recognizing characteristics—some instructions hit the point initially but do not establish certainty through words, becoming scattered. Seeing neither—common vehicles using words for view-meditation, not meeting meaning. Seeing both—direct perception Heart Essence point, seeing base without return point, samsara-nirvana decided in single moment. Translation risk: The fourfold analysis could be read as philosophical logic-chopping rather than recognition pointers. The metaphor of king and palace requires cultural contextualization. Preservation: The essential distinction: authentic main practice is recognition beyond the four extremes, where view-meditation are spontaneous, base seen without return, samsara-nirvana decided simultaneously. The warning—even seeing dharma-nature directly, without practice, liberation does not occur. This establishes that recognition requires stabilization, not that practice creates what is absent.
[4368-4390] Structural function: Detailed exposition of direct introduction proper—bringing meaning to the point. The structural function provides the actual pointing-out instruction for recognition. View register: Rigpa brought to its own ground—this is called seeing vajra coil of joy's appearance. The criticism of those who describe rigpa without direct introduction: like describing Vajra Seat without seeing it, or excellent blind description of color to another. The oscillation between thinking it is unborn emptiness and thinking it is various appearances—this is conceptual assessment, not recognition. Translation risk: Brought to the point could be read as achieving rather than recognizing. The criticism of mere words risks being read as anti-intellectual rather than emphasizing direct experience. Preservation: The pointing-out is not describable through words. Those who speak of rigpa in common way do not reach the point. The oscillation between emptiness and appearance creates suffering: sometimes thinking it is, sometimes thinking it is not, mind falling into uncertainty, wounded by unhappy grief, wondering what it is, thinking what to do if die now, circling samsara's shore without dharma. This describes the suffering of conceptual assessment, not the peace of recognition.
[4391-4400] Structural function: Conclusion of view section with technical markers of recognition. The structural function provides precise phenomenological indicators for confirming recognition. View register: Rigpa's nature without good-bad or change—all arises from that nature with nowhere else to go. This is called base—impossible to stray elsewhere. The threefold liberation markers: wind key holding liberates through movement signs, bindu liberation through bindu connection, channel key liberation through subtle coil signs. These three are not rigpa itself but liberation through depending on it. Translation risk: The technical descriptions of signs could be read as requirements rather than indicators. Base as impossibility of straying could be interpreted as determinism rather as recognition of natural purity. Preservation: Rigpa seen is not enough—familiarization required. Sign of familiarization: coils connecting with each other. Direct perception seeing with pure wisdom eye—seeing at that moment liberates like arrow striking hero's heart. Seeing with pure dharma-nature eye—distinctions distinguished in first instant. The technical precision serves recognition confirmation, not achievement measurement.
02 18 02 02
[4401-4405] Consciousness analysis. The nature of awareness (shes pa) and its relationship to appearance. Distinguishing valid cognition from mistaken perception. Structural function: consciousness analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
02 18 02 03
[4406-4424] Wisdom nature. The wisdom (ye shes) that recognizes ultimate reality. Distinguishing wisdom from ordinary consciousness. Structural function: wisdom analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
02 18 03 01
[4425-4425] Single-line subsection marker. Wylie: dang po lus ngag yid gsum gyi gnad ma gzir na ye shes skyes ... Structural function: section transition. Register: structural marker.
02 18 03 02
[4426-4426] Single-line subsection marker. Wylie: gnyis pa gnad rnam pa gsum la brten nas mngon sum rang thog ... Structural function: section transition. Register: structural marker.
02 18 03 03
[4427-4427] Single-line subsection marker. Wylie: gsum pa de ltar phab cing nyams su blangs pa las snang ba bz... Structural function: section transition. Register: structural marker.
02 18 03 04
[4428-4443] The four dharma aspects provide support and foundation for practitioners, establishing complete path structure through fourfold organization. Without familiarity with these essential points, practice does not reach completion; therefore the tradition speaks of four dharma sections. The citation from Palri Tshegpa tantra establishes authority: "Those desiring familiarity with manifest essential points, the essential point divides into four sections." The structural function introduces the fourfold framework organizing complete path. The view register presents four aspects as comprehensive coverage, not stages to progress through. Translation risk: treating four dharma as sequential stages rather than complete mandala of practice; or conflating the four aspects with other fourfold structures (empowerments, wheels, wisdoms, lamps). Preservation requires maintaining the specific four: external appearances exhausted, internal time exhausted, secret space exhausted, unsurpassed base-emptiness—and their specific correlations to empowerments, channels, wisdoms, and lamps.
[4444-4467] The three gates of liberation establish practical method: body postures representing Three Kayas, speech as silence cutting conceptual chatter, mind cutting all fabrications. Body gate: three ways of sitting—lion (strength, dharmakāya), elephant (stability, saṃbhogakāya), rishi (suppleness, nirmāṇakāya)—demonstrating how single body contains all three bodies. Speech gate: silence like sleeping, cutting conceptual proliferation and verbal elaboration. Mind gate: cutting all mental fabrications, conceptual constructions, and discursive activity. The structural function connects body-speech-mind practice to Three Kayas in unified framework. The view register presents gates as entry points to recognition, not techniques to master. Translation risk: treating postures as physical exercises, silence as mere absence of speech, mental cutting as repression—missing their function as recognition supports. Preservation priority: the body postures specifically represent dharmakāya, saṃbhogakāya, nirmāṇakāya—Three Kayas present in single sitting, not sequential achievements. This identity must remain explicit as the organizing principle of the practice.
02 18 04 01
[4468-4491] Structural function: This section establishes the three-kāya posture system, presenting the nirmāṇakāya posture as the foundation for physical practice. The structural arrangement provides detailed technical specifications: feet position for method-wisdom connection, soles pressing for controlling the active winds, knee-chest contact for settling the bodily elements, straight spine for preventing channel constriction, crossed hands for merging space and awareness, and extended neck for releasing the wind realm. This systematic presentation serves as the practical manual for kāya-specific meditation postures.
[4482-4522] Translation risk: The technical terminology for the three-kāya postures requires precise rendering to maintain their specific energetic and realization functions. The term "essential point" refers to specific junctions where physical alignment influences subtle energy; this technical usage differs from general usage and requires careful preservation. The etymological explanation of nirmāṇakāya—body that accomplishes various actions, purifies and matures—establishes the functional definition of the term that underlies its physical expression.
[4523-4555] Structural function: This section presents the saṃbhogakāya posture, establishing the elephant-lying position as the support for enjoyment-body realization. The structural arrangement parallels the nirmāṇakāya presentation: physical specifications followed by essential points and scriptural authority. The specifications include lying with chin tucked, knee-chest contact, toe extension, hand palm grounding, and raised chin. This systematic presentation enables practitioners to adopt the posture with precise alignment for optimal energetic effect.
[4556-4585] View register: The perspective here presents the saṃbhogakāya posture as the physical support for direct experience of dharmatā. The posture enables the practitioner to remain continuously in the direct perception of reality through the sense power of the eyes. The view that this posture establishes the body as the site of enjoyment—purifying the five sense pleasures and introducing them into the unborn path—captures the non-dual relationship between physical posture and realization. The golden sky citation establishes the textual foundation for this posture as the supreme body essential point.
[4586-4600] Preservation note: The detailed technical specifications for each posture serve as practical meditation instructions and require precise preservation. The connections between specific physical alignments and their energetic effects—controlling active winds, settling elements, preventing channel constriction—constitute technical knowledge that enables the postures to function as supports for realization. The scriptural citations from the Golden Sky establish the authoritative basis for these postures within the tradition.
[4616-4600] Structural function: This section presents the dharmakāya posture, establishing the lion-entering-its-lair position as the support for truth-body realization. The structural arrangement follows the established pattern: physical specifications, essential points, and scriptural authority. The specifications include soles grounding, relaxed upright body, hand fingers pressing the ground, chest space open, and neck supported. This completes the presentation of the three-kāya posture system.
[4647-4600] View register: The perspective here presents the dharmakāya posture as the physical expression of liberation from all confused fear. The posture of the lion—unafraid, majestic, sovereign—embodies the view of complete freedom from cyclic existence. The open chest and supported neck establish the conditions for rapid appearance of meditative experiences, while the finger grounding and relaxed body control the active and wisdom winds. This posture expresses the view that transcends all form while remaining in form.
[4681-4600] Translation risk: The distinction between the three postures and their specific functions requires precise rendering. Each posture connects to specific kāya manifestation: nirmāṇakāya appears in the world, saṃbhogakāya in pure realms, dharmakāya beyond all form. The technical explanations of the posture names—what they accomplish, how they purify, where they abide—establish the functional definitions that guide proper adoption and use. These technical distinctions require careful preservation to maintain their practical utility.
[4711-4600] Structural function: This section establishes the interrelationship between the three postures and their prognostic significance. The structural arrangement presents each posture as a "sign" indicating future liberation: the nirmāṇakāya ṛṣi posture signifying liberation through austerity in future times, the saṃbhogakāya elephant posture signifying effortless spontaneous liberation, the dharmakāya lion posture signifying genuine fearless liberation. This establishes the postures not merely as meditation supports but as indicators of realization trajectory.
[4741-4600] View register: The perspective here presents the three postures as the natural expression of the three kāyas already present within the practitioner. The view that the three kāyas abide in the heart while posture brings them forth establishes the non-dual relationship between physical expression and innate realization. This perspective dissolves the duality between practice and result: the postures are not merely causes of future kāyas but expressions of kāyas already present. The recognition that one's own posture becomes the three-kāya posture captures this essential view.
[4771-4600] Preservation note: The connection between bodily elements and appropriate postures—cold constitution suiting nirmāṇakāya, hot constitution dharmakāya, balanced saṃbhogakāya—establishes individualized practice recommendations based on elemental constitution. This traditional medical-physiological framework requires preservation for its practical application. The concluding emphasis on posture as essential for the arising of wisdom appearance establishes the foundational importance of physical alignment in meditation practice.
[4801-4600] Structural function: This section addresses the question of why only three postures are definitively established, presenting the three postures as the complete system for liberation from the three poisons and the three doors. The structural arrangement establishes the correspondence: three poisons (desire, hatred, ignorance) bind beings to three realms, three postures liberate them; three poisons mature into body, speech, and mind, three postures purify them. This systematic correspondence demonstrates the completeness of the threefold system.
[4831-4600] View register: The perspective here presents the three postures as the complete method for liberation from cyclic existence. The view that three are definitively established while more are unnecessary and fewer are incomplete establishes the sufficiency of this system. The correspondence between the three poisons, the three doors, and the three postures demonstrates the systematic nature of the path. This view establishes confidence in the completeness of the method without requiring additional elaboration.
[4861-4600] Translation risk: The presentation of the three poisons maturing into specific body types—with desire maturing into bird-body with emphasis on speech, ignorance into pig-body with emphasis on mind, hatred into snake-body with emphasis on physical action—represents traditional Buddhist physiological psychology. This framework establishes the basis for individualized posture recommendations: bird-nature practitioners benefit from saṃbhogakāya posture, pig-nature from dharmakāya, snake-nature from nirmāṇakāya. These correspondences require precise preservation for their practical application in matching practice to constitution.
[4901-4600] Structural function: This section concludes the three-kāya posture presentation with the definitive statement that three are definitively established and no more are needed. The structural arrangement reinforces the completeness of the system: the three poisons bind to three realms, three postures liberate; three doors express bondage, three postures express freedom. This systematic presentation establishes confidence in the method and provides clear guidance for practice selection based on individual characteristics.
[4951-4600] View register: The perspective here presents the definitive nature of the threefold system as the complete expression of liberation from cyclic existence. The view that the three postures exhaust the possibilities for liberation establishes their sufficiency. The recognition that the three doors of body, speech, and mind are purified through the three postures demonstrates the comprehensive scope of the practice. This view enables practitioners to engage with the system confidently, knowing that the appropriate posture for their constitution provides complete support for realization.
02 18 05 01
[4601-4610] This section initiates speech discipline training within the three-gate framework of Dzogchen practice. The progression follows a deliberate sequence: reduction of ordinary speech leads to eventual cessation, establishing silence as an active cultivation rather than mere absence. The instruction to reduce speech gradually—first minimizing, then extending duration—reflects the practical orientation of the text, accommodating practitioners at various stages of capacity. The final stage of single-syllable speech represents a threshold where vocalization becomes intentional rather than habitual, marking the transition from ordinary to contemplative speech patterns.
[4611-4620] The citation from the seed tantra establishes scriptural authority for the speech discipline, grounding practical instruction in canonical sources. The metaphor of speech being like a mute person carries specific technical meaning: not merely silence but a quality of presence where communication occurs through direct recognition rather than conceptual exchange. The structural function of this passage is to establish speech cessation as a complete practice, not preliminary to something else. When speech stops, meaning arises in the mental continuum without the mediation of verbal formulation.
[4621-4625] The dissolution of speech cultivation leads to three progressive recognitions. First, the body becomes subtle—liberated from ordinary embodiment through the blessings of buddhas, bodhisattvas, and sky-dwelling ḍākinīs. Second, speech dissolution enables communication with non-human beings through gesture and direct recognition. Third, mind dissolution manifests as visions of non-human forms and subsequent clairvoyance. The structural integration here binds body, speech, and mind dissolutions into a single trajectory, demonstrating how speech discipline serves as the hinge connecting outer and inner practice. The preservation concern involves maintaining the technical specificity of "subtle body" terminology without collapsing it into New Age adaptations.
[4626-4638] The mind-key section completes the three-gate framework by establishing space-like vision as the foundation for non-conceptual recognition. The citation from the Thalgyur provides canonical support for the essential point: mind directed to space achieves accomplishment. The structural insight is that by binding body and speech, mind follows naturally—space-awareness dawns and karmic bonds are cut. The final citation from the seed tantra summarizes the complete practice: binding the three gates through knowing and maintaining the keys liberates from saṃsāra. The verse establishes the inseparability of method and liberation within a single gesture of recognition.
[4639-4651] This section transitions to the three-key method for introducing direct face-to-face recognition. The enumeration—three keys bound in vajra-fetter, direct recognition of awareness's own face, and showing how appearance dawns from that—establishes the complete structure of the introduction practice. The three keys correspond to gateway, object, and wind-awareness, each serving a distinct function in the recognition process. The metaphor of striking a vital point with a weapon illustrates the decisive nature of this method: once the vital point is touched, nothing can prevent the result. The preservation requirement is to maintain this martial precision without softening it into mere mindfulness or general meditation instruction.
[4652-4668] The detailed exposition of the three keys uses three metaphors: the gateway-key is like a lion, the object-key like a warrior, and the wind-awareness key like a thief. These images convey specific technical meanings—the lion's presence establishes unshakeable seeing, the warrior's courage enables non-reactivity to circumstances, and the thief's stealth allows entry without obstruction. The structural logic is that without object there is no ground for support, without gateway the path is lost, and without wind-awareness key, knowing-awareness does not penetrate internally. The three are definitive—more than three loses the essential point, fewer than three fails to accomplish the purpose. The view register maintains the Dzogchen emphasis on precise method leading to spontaneous recognition.
[4669-4688] The application of the three keys to individual practice divides into two aspects: establishing the general sequence of the three keys and applying each key to its corresponding point. The general sequence requires that body, speech, and mind remain unmoving while the three keys are bound. The structural authority comes from the transmission lineage, citing the Self-Arisen Rigpa Tantra and Thalgyur to establish the view. The verse from Thalgyur establishes the technical process: relying on body, speech, and mind keys, the wind is gradually settled then radically released, cutting the connection between body and mind. The three gateways are identified: gateway is seen through the three-kāya eyes, object is free from obstructing conditions, and wind-awareness settled enables wisdom-accomplishment.
[4689-4695] The concluding section of the three-keys exposition establishes the remaining detailed applications. The structural pattern maintains consistent terminology throughout—gateway, object, and wind-awareness as the three inseparable aspects of direct introduction. The preservation concern involves maintaining the technical precision of these terms without conflating them with general Buddhist meditation vocabulary. The view register remains focused on direct recognition rather than gradual cultivation, emphasizing the immediate availability of the recognition when the keys are properly applied. The section functions as the bridge between theoretical understanding and practical application, preparing the reader for subsequent detailed instructions on body, speech, and mind keys.
02 18 06 01
[4696-4733] This section presents mind training through the three views of the three kāyas, establishing a systematic approach to transforming ordinary perception into enlightened vision. The structural function moves from the problem—ordinary views do not produce wisdom—through the solution—training in three kāya gazes— to the detailed description of each view and its effects. The integration of tantric sources provides scriptural authority while the practical instructions offer immediate application. The register operates in Mahāyāna and Dzogchen terminology: three kāyas (sku gsum), three gazes (gzigs stangs), dharmakāya gaze (chos sku'i gzigs stangs), sambhogakāya gaze (longs sku'i gzigs stangs), nirmāṇakāya gaze (sprul sku'i gzigs stangs), three realms (khams gsum), samsara (srid pa), pure realm (zhin khams). The three gazes—downward, sideways, and upward—correspond to the three kāyas and their respective wisdom eyes. Translation risks center on preserving the specific correlations between gaze direction and kāya without oversimplification. The dharmakāya gaze downward compresses samsara, the sambhogakāya gaze sideways destroys existence's ground, and the nirmāṇakāya gaze downward liberates into Buddha field. These descriptions operate as technical instructions rather than poetic imagery. The three eyes—dharmatā eye, wisdom eye, discriminating eye—must be preserved as distinct technical terms. The practical application establishes three types of practitioners: lazy ones benefit from sambhogakāya gaze, diligent ones from nirmāṇakāya gaze, and equanimous ones from dharmakāya gaze. This typology acknowledges different capacities while affirming the path's accessibility. The etymological note on "gzigs" as seeing dharmatā and "stangs" as liberating from samsara preserves the Tibetan terminological analysis.
[4734-4746] This subsection presents the object crucial points—external and internal expanse objects—establishing the contemplative supports for the three-gaze practice. The structural function moves from external space to internal focus, presenting two complementary approaches. The external expanse object is empty space free from clouds, while the internal is the Brahma aperture between the eyebrows supporting expanse-appearance. The register maintains spatial terminology: external expanse (phyi'i dbyings), internal expanse (nang gi dbyings), empty space (nam mkha' stong pa), Brahma aperture (tshangs bug), expanse-appearance (dbyings snang), five colors (rnam lnga). The citation from Thalgyur tantra establishes the scriptural basis while describing the practical method of holding external space. Translation risks center on the distinction between external and internal objects. The external serves as the arising field for awareness, while the internal serves as the field for experience enhancement. The statement that they are non-dual establishes saṃsāra-nirvāṇa mixture ('khor 'das 'dres pa), a technical term indicating their essential unity. The warning that taking coarse elements as objects prevents liberation establishes the need for subtle focus, indicating advanced practice requirements.
02 18 07 01
[4747-4767] Structural function: Opening of view training section with the paradox of "not wanting appearances to arise." The structural framing establishes non-conceptual view as foundation while acknowledging that deliberate non-arising is itself a concept. The resolution lies in recognition rather than rejection. View register: Appearances as self-liberated without deliberate rejection. The key phrase "empty-clear without thought-experience arises from within" indicates that recognition emerges naturally when fixation relaxes, not through aversion to appearance. The sky-space view (nam mkha') serves as primary metaphor—expanse without boundary, awareness without limit. Translation risk: "Not wanting" (mi 'dod) risks interpretation as aversion or suppression. The Tibetan indicates non-grasping rather than rejection. The instruction to "place empty awareness toward empty sky" could be read as dualistic meditation—subject placing awareness toward object—rather than recognizing awareness-sky non-duality. Preservation: Multiple canonical citations establish authority: Samten Mikyopa on yogin abiding in sky-space; Sutrapitaka on examining meaning in empty sky; Yum Barma on prajnaparamita meditation as sky-space yoga. These citations anchor the practice in canonical tradition while emphasizing its non-conceptual nature. The result—"expanse and awareness without duality"—is the view's essential point.
[4768-4788] Structural function: Wind-rigpa key point section providing practical instruction for maintaining view. The structural movement from view to method follows the standard presentation sequence. Wind as the vehicle of mind receives detailed technical instruction. View register: Wind (rlung) as subtle energy serving as support for rigpa recognition. When wind becomes gentle and slow, rigpa can be directly seen. The threefold benefit structure: externally extends life, internally causes conceptions to cease, secretly makes rigpa directly visible. This establishes wind practice as simultaneously health, mental calming, and recognition support. Translation risk: Wind risks reduction to physiological breath rather than subtle energy. The phrase "releasing far outward and holding externally" (phyir rgyang ring po 'phren zhing phyir bzung la gzhag pa) requires technical precision—this is not breath retention but energy balancing. Preservation: The Talgyur citations establish canonical foundation: "Wind made gentle... body and mind connection severed... not reversing three realms." The repetition of verses emphasizes stability. Wind and rigpa gentle accomplish wisdom; wind and awareness separate, eliminating coming-going—this is rigpa arriving at its own nature. The practical instruction specifies five to six days initially, then door-opening practice, then object-searching for six to seven days, then direct immediate self-liberation.
[4789-4811] Structural function: Rigpa key point—coil of joy in expanse. This section provides the precise technique for view stabilization through the "coil of joy" (lu gu rgyud) metaphor. The structural placement after wind instruction indicates progression from coarse to subtle. View register: Rigpa placed as unmoving coil within the expanse. The metaphor suggests both stability (coiled) and joy (natural radiance). Wind gentle leads to freedom from activity; rigpa coil placed on the letter "a" leads to exhaustion of conceptual source. This is recognition stabilization, not concentration achievement. Translation risk: "Coil of joy" as metaphor rather than technical term risks losing precision. The Tibetan lu gu rgyud is a specific technical term in Dzogchen phenomenology referring to the way rigpa naturally coheres without fixation. The letter "a" refers to the unborn syllable, not the grapheme. Preservation: Canonical citations from Talgyur ("Self-face rigpa coil of joy, held in sky through freedom from coming-going") and Tenbu ("Coil of joy within expanse, established separately without separating") establish terminology authority. The process: wind gentle produces freedom from activity in continuum; rigpa coil on "a" exhausts conceptual source; delusion returns to ground; wisdom mother and son meet. The experiential markers are precise—when recognition separates from wind, coming-going ceases; this is rigpa naturally arriving.
[4812-4844] Structural function: Direct introduction of rigpa's own face—the culminating view section with direct pointing language. The structural function is recognition-triggering rather than information-providing. The prose builds to the recognition moment. View register: Rigpa as diamond coil of joy, golden thread hovering in sky—metaphors for recognition's natural coherence and luminous continuity. This is unfabricated buddhahood, primordial Samantabhadra, spontaneously self-arisen. The meeting face-to-face with wisdom of arising prajna establishes recognition as encounter rather than understanding. Translation risk: The poetic descriptions (golden thread, hovering in sky, five-colored light) risk being read as visualizations to be fabricated rather than phenomenological descriptions of recognition. "Ordinary mind arriving at buddhahood" could be misinterpreted as deluded mind becoming enlightened rather than recognition of natural purity. Preservation: The technical descriptions are precise: rigpa as unconfused primordial purity (ka dag) spontaneously self-arisen (lhun grub) own-display (rang gdangs). This is not poetic ornament but phenomenological accuracy. The progression: recognition habits reach measure, liberates with coarse matter into light; if not reaching measure, intermediate state or natural manifestation field traversed; six realms of delusion's abyss crossed. The citations from Rangjung and Talgyur seal the recognition with canonical authority.
[4845-4877] Structural function: Appearance arising from that—light display progression. The structural function demonstrates how appearances arise when view stabilizes, providing phenomenological roadmap for practitioner recognition. The progression from external to internal to secret to suchness establishes comprehensive framework. View register: Appearances as rigpa display, not external phenomena. The progression: expanse's five-colored own-display swaying (db ying 'od lnga'i rang gdangs lang ling du snang ba), bindus connecting with coil (thig le phra mos 'brel ba), first white-copper-colored star-like scattering (dkar zang zing skar ma 'phro ba lta bu), then bindus five-colored (thig le kha dog lnga ldan), individual and triple connected (re re ba dang sum sbrel). These describe actual phenomenology, not visualization. Translation risk: Light and bindu descriptions risk being read as visualizations to construct rather than natural phenomena to recognize. The numerical precision (four appearances) requires contextual explanation—why four, not three or five? Preservation: The four appearances correspond to: external—moon-sun four times' waxing-waning; internal—body-speech-mind-mind fourfold binding liberation; secret—four empowerments' definite display; suchness—four lamps' appearance definiteness. The sequence is determined: first dharma-nature direct appearance provides basis for remaining three. Without first, no basis for others; with first, self-arisen wisdom found from self; if not experienced, merely words without result; when experienced, experience increases.
[4878-4915] Structural function: Detailed exposition of the four appearances' definite number, sequence, and individual characteristics. The structural thoroughness ensures comprehensive understanding of the light display phenomenology. View register: Experience reaching measure requires stabilization. Without stabilization, experience has no limit, no dharma engagement, no buddhahood cause. When experience stabilizes at measure, rigpa appearance reaching measure manifests. Even when rigpa appearance reaches measure, if it does not transform beyond that, there is no difference from common vehicles hoping for result from apparent characteristics. Translation risk: "Measure" (tshad) and "reaching measure" (tshad phebs) risk being read as quantitative achievement rather than qualitative recognition. "Appearance dissolving into ground" could be interpreted as nihilistic cessation rather as recognition of ground-display unity. Preservation: The four appearances correspond to three kayas: first two as nirmāṇakāya, measure-reaching as saṃbhogakāya, exhaustion as dharmakāya. These are path-appearances, not result-achievements. When made into path, result arrives at exhausted ka dag expanse—self-appearance's potency kayas dissolve into rigpa nature. This is called "king of vehicles' intention"—the heart essence not even heard of in other vehicles. The point is difficult to realize because it transcends conventional cause-effect frameworks.
02 18 08 01
[4916-4925] The opening presents the fourfold direct perception that structures the progressive stages of realization. First is the sense faculty direct perception of form and the five sense objects appearing as their own nature without conceptual overlay. Second is the mind's direct perception of mental phenomena operating within the sphere of cause and effect certainty. Third is the self-awareness direct perception experiencing bliss and suffering without grasping or rejection. Fourth is the yogic direct perception entering the sphere of suchness beyond subject-object division. This structural framework establishes the hierarchical progression from conventional to ultimate perception, demonstrating how each level transcends while including the previous. The view register emphasizes non-dual awareness beyond all subject-object division. Translation must preserve the technical terminology of "direct perception" while clearly distinguishing the four types and their interrelationship.
[4926-4935] The discussion of ultimate sphere direct perception establishes awareness essence as abiding in the heart center of true nature. The argument from cause and effect compares sun and its rays to demonstrate the inseparability of awareness and its expressions—neither identical nor different. This reasoning supports the confidence in recognition that comes from direct experience rather than inference. The view register positions this as transcendent direct perception beyond worldly perception, accessible only to those who have entered the path of seeing. Translation risk involves rendering the logical terminology of cause and effect reasoning precisely while maintaining readability and preventing overly philosophical interpretations that miss the experiential dimension.
[4936-4951] The term "true nature" receives fourfold analytical presentation to establish precise meaning. First distinction: samsara as phenomena versus nirvana as true nature, showing the relationship between confused appearance and natural purity. Second: appearance as phenomena versus emptiness as true nature, demonstrating the unity of apparent and empty. Third: lack of essential point preventing liberation versus existence of essential point ensuring liberation, indicating the necessity of recognizing the crucial points. Fourth: sphere as phenomena versus awareness as true nature, revealing the ultimate identity of space and knowing. This analytical presentation demonstrates the precision of Dzogchen vocabulary and prevents reification of either appearance or emptiness. The view register shows how conventional and ultimate are not contradictory but nested dimensions of a single reality.
[4952-4963] The three aspects—base, path, and measure—establish the complete framework for practice organization. Base is determined through three essential points of body, speech, and mind that establish the foundation. Path is cleared through three essential points of inner true nature object, opening gateway, and wind abiding that remove obstacles. Measure is determined through three stages of secret familiarization, ripening signs, and final cessation that mark progress. This enumerative structure provides the scaffolding for all subsequent practice instructions, ensuring systematic progression without skipping essential stages. The numerical correspondence reflects the tradition's concern with complete and balanced development.
[4964-4977] The explanation of "three" continues with the spontaneous presence of three bodies in true nature, their own radiances appearing as three distinct manifestations. The inner experience of dharmakāya manifests as aware emptiness—the knowing quality of empty essence. The five lights appearing outward represent self-clear wisdom displaying as saṃbhogakāya. The arising liberation without form manifests as wisdom power with intelligence, the nirmāṇakāya dimension. The structural function connects the numerical framework to actual experience, preventing abstract philosophical understanding divorced from recognition. Translation must preserve the technical vocabulary of "own radiance" and "arising liberation" while conveying their immediate experiential significance.
[4978-4992] The necessity of direct perception without conceptual addition demonstrates why intellectual analysis alone cannot achieve recognition. The citation from Sancaya establishes that wisdom searching through conceptual analysis does not find the depths of aggregates, just as someone with eyes cannot find the end of space by searching. This supports the emphasis on direct experience over philosophical speculation. The view register distinguishes authentic direct perception from mistaken attempts to conceptualize the inconceivable. Translation risk involves maintaining the distinction between analytical meditation and settling meditation without privileging either or suggesting they are separate paths.
[4993-5011] The luminosity appearance is distinguished from conventional visible form—it cannot be destroyed by the four elements because it lacks both coarse and subtle material characteristics. This establishes the indestructible nature of awareness display, which persists through all conditions while remaining unaffected by them. The translation challenge involves rendering "indestructible" in a way that conveys both the technical meaning and its implications for practice—that recognition of this nature provides ultimate security beyond the vulnerability of conditioned phenomena. The view register establishes this as the vajra nature, simultaneously empty and luminous.
[5012-5034] The appearance section cites Thalgyur: "True nature direct perception appearance, certain emergence from sense faculty gateway, clear in cloudless sky." This poetic imagery supports the direct perception framework by providing accessible metaphors for immediate recognition. The additional citations establish the continuity of this teaching across multiple authoritative sources. The view register maintains the consistency of Dzogchen presentation across different textual traditions, demonstrating this is not an isolated teaching but part of the living transmission. Preservation requires maintaining the citation structure that provides scriptural authority while ensuring the experiential meaning remains primary over textual scholarship.
02 18 08 02
[5035-5042] This section establishes the progression of meditation training through three stages: second, enhancing sessions and extending duration; third, practicing day and night without distinction, taking experiences into practice; resting awareness in the sphere-fence without movement. The structural function is to demonstrate how initial recognition is stabilized through systematic extension of practice time and intensity. The verse citation from Sgron Ma 'Bar Ba establishes the method: dbyings kyis rig pa'i rang yul byed, rdo rje nyid ni lu gu rgyud, 'di nyid nang du gzhag par bya. The sphere makes awareness its own object, the vajra is the chain, this itself is to be placed internally. The preservation requirement is to maintain the technical meaning of lu gu rgyud as chain or continuum without reducing it to mere metaphor.
[5043-5062] The fruit section establishes the result of meditation practice: when external space appears and eyes do not move at their own time, internally awareness dwells in the base, self-resonance dissolves on its own, and returning, separated from the galloping-horse of the wind, pristine awareness space dissolves into sphere space, liberated as face-equal without distinction. The originally pure awareness, unmoving in the sphere, naturally clear light in the heart center, dwells naturally in the expanse. Such a yogin is called one who has captured the primordial clear light of dharmatā—saṃsāra becomes empty without name, and the three realms are cut like a severed tendon. The extensive verse citation from Thalgyur establishes the complete path: seeing dharmatā directly, knowing through mere seeing, realizing through that knowing, liberating through mere realization—liberation is not untying, like space dissolving into space, naturally without object, without partiality or portions. The structural function is to establish meditation training's direct connection to final fruit realization without intermediate stages.
[5063-5075] The progressive enhancement of experiences section divides into brief presentation and extensive explanation. The brief presentation establishes that through gradual training of sphere-awareness, externally in sphere-appearance awareness remains inseparable as chain, and internally in originally pure empty sphere, self-resonance awareness dwells non-dually—clear light mother and child mix, and appearance-experiences increase diversely. The verse citation from Thalgyur describes the process: nyeams kyi snang ba gong 'phel ni, ye shes kha dog phir byung nas, gyen 'greng ba dang rtsibs shar dang, thig le sna tshogs sku nyid du, rags par snang ba'i yul la gsal. The preservation requirement is to maintain the technical specificity of these meditative signs without conflating them with general progress indicators.
[5076-5084] The extensive explanation establishes that progressive enhancement of experiences has two aspects: cognitive experiences and appearance experiences. Cognitive experiences include worldly cognitive experiences—bliss and clarity obtained through samādhi, mental attachment, desire to sing and dance, and transcendent cognitive experiences—signs of realization of empty-clear without extremes, together with wisdom's power. From the beginning, middle, and end of this, three arise through familiarity: cognitive bliss-experience, final transformation experience, and appearance experience. The structural function is to map the complete trajectory of meditative development, distinguishing between fabricated and natural experiences while establishing their progressive unfolding. The preservation concern involves maintaining the technical distinctions between shes nyams and snang nyams without reducing them to general meditative terminology.
02 18 09 01
[5085-5091] This section establishes the distinction between authentic natural meditation and fabricated cultivation. When body and speech are bound at the vital point, the vital wind enters the central channel, giving rise to inner samādhi—resting in the state of clear-light emptiness. Awareness relaxes without grasping or holding, and bliss and clarity arise spaciously. Even when anger or desire arise, there is no attachment or fixation even the size of a hair. This originates from arriving at the essential point of natural contemplation. The structural function is to establish the difference between natural and artificial meditative experience. In fabricated meditation, arising bliss produces strong attachment, coarse agitation, and desire to sing or dance. The preservation requirement is to maintain the technical distinction between bcos ma and rang bzhin without conflating them into general meditation terminology.
[5092-5101] The signs of final transformation present eight metaphors for wind-movement experiences: like fireflies, like clouds, like smoke, like haze, like rising moon, like appearing stars, like dawn breaking with blue appearance, like rising sun with internal and external transparency. These appearances arise and dissolve, unstable and unable to remain—hence called "signs of final transformation" because they indicate wind-movement. The structural function is to provide practitioners with recognition markers for authentic progress versus disturbance. The preservation concern involves maintaining the poetic precision of these metaphors without reducing them to mere psychological states or hallucinations.
[5102-5110] The explanation of these signs establishes that they are naturally occurring—vital wind and mind need to settle. The appearance-signs represent the self-resonance of awareness as great clear light. In the interim state, external appearance increases and reaches measure, then self-resonance dissolves into the base and turns inward—external clarity alone must dissolve because it needs to dissolve into the originally pure spontaneous presence sphere. Internally clear, in the expanse of self-light, awareness dwells in the palace of the kāya and pristine awareness—great spontaneous presence without transition or change.
[5111-5118] The section establishes appearance-signs as primary—cognitive experiences are merely intellect, so they transform and cannot be measured, being included in the conceptual, conventional forms, memory-making, separate, surface-level thought. Attempting to measure this is like a bird making hiding places in clouds—there is no time for conceptual thought, and seeing does not arrive directly at its own face. This is the appearance-sign: seeing the five pristine awareness colors transcends the half of saṃsāric activity grasping objects as appearance. Seeing the sphere-appearance, above that, grasping and thought-aspect are absent—wrong view grasps emptiness, transcending two-thirds of saṃsāra. When conceptual ground-heap self-liberates as rang sangs, the grasping-aspect half grasping appearance as self-characteristic is reversed—this is called selflessness of persons and phenomena.
[5119-5124] The summary establishes that appearance-experiences are gathered into two: the five pristine awareness colors' appearance and the sphere-appearance. The progressive enhancement is these appearances becoming increasingly beautiful, excellent, and numerous. The structural pattern divides into general presentation through purity-method and specific explanation through appearance-method. The preservation requirement is to maintain the technical specificity of these appearance-signs without conflating them with general meditative experiences or reducing them to psychological epiphenomena. The view register remains focused on the inseparability of appearance and emptiness within the natural state.
02 18 10 01
[5125-5137] The text presents liberation from samsara's bondage through transformation of five poisons into five wisdoms. As mastery is obtained over desire, hatred, ignorance, pride, and jealousy, the five wisdom colors manifest. These poisons no longer bind but appear as residual imprints, indicating transcendence of samsara. The structural function maps the five-poison and five-wisdom schema onto visionary experience.
[5138-5155] The progression continues through appearance stages resembling nets, broken nets, intricate patterns, and tent canopies. These appearances indicate transcending the five aggregates and worldly self-view. Each stage represents refinement, with coarser misconceptions dissolving into subtler manifestations. This represents purification of view in dharmata.
[5156-5158] Subsequent appearances manifest as wisdom castles, sun and moon union, stacked lotuses, piled stupas, and thousand-petalled lotuses. These indicate transcendence of five elements' binding characteristics. All appearances arise and cease as a single event, termed "experience," with progressive development representing "increase" of recognition.
[5169-5158] The vajra family purification establishes correlation between buddha families, wisdoms, and colors. Mirror-like wisdom appears as white, dharmadhatu wisdom as blue, equality wisdom as yellow. This systematic presentation maps the five-wisdom schema onto visionary experience.
[5177-5158] Discriminating wisdom appears as red, all-accomplishing wisdom as green. The blue vajra fence indicates wisdoms' non-difference in essence. The arising sequence establishes practice timeframes: five days, seven days, or twenty-one days.
[5186-5158] The Rangjung Gyud citation establishes recognition: "Fortunate one with good karma, how could you enter samsara? Wheel-cut appearing accomplishes emanation qualities." This connects personal experience to universal structure.
[5202-5158] The path summary includes recognition of own nature, impossibility of returning to samsara, and emanation qualities' accomplishment. The emphasis remains on direct recognition rather than fixation on appearances.
[5221-5158] The practitioner recognizing these as self-appearance progresses toward liberation, while fixation on appearances remains binding. These are supports for recognizing mind's nature, not objects for attachment.
02 18 11 01
[5159-5167] The opening presents vajra family purification as the foundation of the five-family mandala structure. Mirror-like wisdom's own radiance appears as white color, with the white radiance of Akshobhya Vajra Unshakable One shining forth as the ground of all subsequent appearances. This establishes the correlation between buddha families, wisdoms, and color manifestations that structures the entire presentation. The structural function maps the five-wisdom schema onto visionary experience, providing practitioners with reference points for recognizing the nature of their experiences. The view register maintains the non-duality of wisdom and its display—colors are not external objects but the self-radiance of awareness itself. Translation must preserve the technical terminology of "own radiance" while conveying its immediate experiential significance rather than allowing metaphysical abstraction to obscure direct recognition.
[5168-5176] Tathagata family purification produces dharmadhatu wisdom appearing as blue color, the deep blue radiance of Vairocana manifesting with the characteristic of pervading all space. Ratna family purification produces equality wisdom as yellow color, the shining radiance of Ratnasambhava appearing like refined gold, rich and warm. The systematic presentation demonstrates the completeness of the five-family framework, showing how each family corresponds to a specific wisdom, color, and kaya aspect. Translation risk lies in rendering color terms precisely while acknowledging their visionary rather than physical nature—these are not ordinary colors but the display of awareness-emptiness.
[5177-5185] Padma family purification produces discriminating wisdom as red color, the deeply red radiance of Amitabha resembling the color of ruby or coral. Karma family purification produces all-accomplishing wisdom as green color, the very green radiance of Amoghasiddhi appearing like beryl or emerald. The outer rim surrounded by blue vajra fence indicates the non-difference of these wisdoms in essence despite their distinct manifestations. This imagery provides the mandala structure for visionary experience, establishing the organized cosmos that appears to recognition. Each detail carries precise meaning: the fence indicates protection and boundary, the arrangement shows interdependence, and the colors represent the play of awareness.
[5186-5201] From this foundation, appearance increase emerges—five lights individually predominant, with colors five by five distinct—arising from family and family distinctions. Wisdom wind purification produces mirror-like appearances vertically oriented, supporting the increase of experience through stable recognition. Equality wing appearing eastward indicates that deluded appearance is nearing exhaustion, with coarse fixation dissolving. Discriminating wheel-cut appearing indicates the cessation of subtle elemental fixation, moving beyond even the most refined objectification. All-accomplishing like weapon appearance arises from unmodified nature, demonstrating spontaneous activity without contrivance.
[5202-5215] Dharmadhatu wisdom appearing as fortress indicates that coarse thoughts have completely ceased, leaving only the spacious ground of being. From that, various forms like wheels appear from complete preliminary practice, showing the fruition of sustained recognition. The arising sequence establishes timeframes: excellent diligence achieves results in five days each, medium capacity requires seven days, and the last require twenty-one days, with higher appearance ceasing as lower appears. This provides practice benchmarks while acknowledging individual variation in capacity, conditions, and karmic inheritance. Colors and shapes may appear momentarily here, indicating the transitional nature of even sublime experiences.
[5216-5232] The citation from Rangjung Gyud establishes the recognition of one's own face: "Separated by four inches from upper joint, fortunate one with good karma, how could you enter samsara? Wheel-cut completely appearing accomplishes emanation qualities. Whatever appearing as seen object, likewise in the sphere. Outer appearance ceasing becomes sixteen moments." This scriptural authority supports the visionary progression, demonstrating that individual experience participates in universal structure. The structural function connects personal recognition to the timeless wisdom tradition, validating experience without allowing personal inflation or spiritual materialism.
[5233-5241] The final verses summarize the complete path: recognition of one's own nature, the impossibility of returning to samsara once true nature is seen, the accomplishment of emanation qualities through wheel-cut appearance, and the transformation of outer appearance into moments of pure awareness. The presentation maintains throughout the emphasis on direct recognition rather than philosophical analysis—these appearances support recognition but are not the goal themselves. The practitioner who recognizes these as self-appearance progresses toward complete liberation.
02 18 12 01
[5242-5252] Structural function: Detailed exposition of three kayas' manifestation through light display progression. Provides roadmap for recognition stabilization markers. View register: Rigpa reaching measure produces appearances as wisdom display. First, within each bindu, half-body appearances manifest—nirmāṇakāya purification. Then, full individual bodies appear—nirvana appearance from direct perception. Then, these become five fathers and mothers—saṃbhogakāya wisdom reaching measure. Then, individual circle mandalas become boundary walls and principal retinue—dharmakāya purification. Translation risk: Progression could be read as hierarchical achievement rather than natural manifestation. Body descriptions risk being interpreted as visualizations rather than recognition phenomenology. Preservation: These appearances arise from preliminary practice's key points reached—body activities not producing future results. These are designated appearances from purification, not produced by causes. Wisdom's naturally existing display, obscurations purified appearing. Natural manifestation, not cause-effect fabrication.
[5253-5265] Structural function: Canonical sealing through Talgyur and Tenbu citations. Establishes authoritative foundation for appearance descriptions. View register: Wisdom reaching measure appearance definitively shows saṃbhogakāya marks. From uncertain rainbow colors, five families appear as fathers and mothers. Tenbu citation confirms: until reaching body, six and ten and five-three, definitely saṃbhogakāya. Translation risk: Numerical references require technical knowledge. Without context, citations appear cryptic. Preservation: Talgyur citation establishes: rigpa reaching measure appearance, saṃbhogakāya marks clearly shown, from uncertain rainbow colors, five families appearing. Canonical seals confirm phenomenological descriptions are recognition of natural display.
[5266-5268] Structural function: Transition to detailed characteristic exposition with general presentation and particular three measures. View register: Reaching measure's definition distinguishes general and particular to establish framework for recognition stabilization. Preservation: Essential point throughout: appearances as wisdom display, kayas as natural manifestation, recognition as confirmation of what is already present. King of vehicles' view—direct recognition of natural perfection.
02 18 13 01
[5269-5280] The section on awareness reaching measure opens with precise definition. Rigpa reaching measure indicates the ground-abiding awareness becoming fully manifest, having entered the stream of the path. From the ground appearance's self-resonance, the spontaneous presence door opens, manifesting as body appearance. As path appearance nears exhaustion, mandalas become complete. The structural function establishes the transition from ground to path to fruition, showing how recognition matures through stages without the recognition itself changing. Measure spans from half-body appearance through complete body mandala manifestation. Arrival means appearing without remainder beyond that stage. The full moon simile illustrates how increase and decrease both serve completion—whether waxing or waning, the moon remains complete in itself.
[5281-5300] The three measures are presented in detail: external appearance measure, internal body measure, and secret awareness measure. The external appearance measure involves control over appearances as fields become light, with pure lands completing as luminosity. The Thalgyur citation provides authoritative support: direct objects cease appearing as solid, earth and stone appearances melt into light, self-knowing penetrates everything, inserted bems po moves, wind movement finds its measure, body's atomic particles become visible, whatever appears becomes complete as form body, father and mother deities embrace, fivefold mandalas manifest, all within round halos. The yogi body itself becomes light and clear, with natural movement of going, coming, and sitting. All this indicates rigpa reaching measure.
[5301-5320] The internal body measure shows the clearing of the body's coarse solidity. From a white A in the heart center, five light rays coil and emerge like the sun through a seeing-hole, shining in the sky's light window. The crown displays wisdom wind abiding with naturally uplifted appearance. The ushnisa radiates five-colored light to an arm-span's extent. The five fingers display light garlands. The body pores become doorways—the outer and inner atomic particles, each smaller than a particle's extent, reveal immeasurable pure fields where Buddhas and beings appear without number. This is the appearance of spontaneous presence's eight gates, all appearing as self-appearance without addition or subtraction.
[5321-5340] The secret awareness measure manifests mandalas throughout the body. The skull center displays wrathful mandala, the heart center displays peaceful mandala, all body parts show natural emanation and subduing emanation. Various emanations appear as Buddha field self-appearance, benefitting beings. Through the compassion door, six clairvoyances manifest. Wisdom knowing all phenomena appears. The pure wisdom door opens, revealing pure Buddha fields as self-appearance saṃbhogakāya completion. The mind's stains clear, dust and doubt separate, ground and ground habitual tendencies self-purify. The Thalgyur citation establishes body transformation signs: body dust apart, outer space light window appearing, light ray hook shapes, slender and coiled holding appearance, body dust self-ceasing, pure light body, A syllable mark in center, crown light rays arm-span measure, crown tuft wind uplifted appearance, peaceful body fingers' light garlands pervading.
[5341-5360] The progression continues with silent mind activity, skull kapala palace, Herukas manifesting. At this time one's own body reaches measure, three kayas unified in transparent purity. The secret awareness measure reveals how even coarse and subtle moving mind, along with all-ground consciousness, still contains mind without the qualities of awareness—without clairvoyance and foreknowledge. From that very state, mind becomes clear with six clairvoyances, knowing distant and hidden phenomena instantaneously, immeasurable Buddha fields appearing, even Buddha bodies appearing in mind. Empty mind's stains exhausted, nature unmoving empty-clear obtained, unmixed equal-complete sphere pervading, display of appearance without many divisions, without parts beyond elaboration. This occurs when the two previous appearances have purified afflictive mind and mental consciousness obscurations, obtaining this as the eighth collection's first seven are purified, liberated from coarse and subtle stains, body and mind connection severed.
[5361-5380] The external appearance becomes object-cognition, with investigating consciousness as all-ground consciousness faculty acting as subject-condition. This dawns self-arising as fast as stars and meteors traverse space, self-liberating without looking to antidote. This arises from the power of wind being expelled outward and not gathered inward during the two previous appearances, from power that does not allow thought to remain even two instants. Body becomes transparent, consciousness all-ground portion becomes thought-free object-cognition like fire sparks spreading, clear and pure. Seeing both external appearance and internal self-appearance portions, body and mind sever connection, the supreme ground great mandala completes without returning to the three realms. The Thalgyur citation confirms: body-mind connection severed, consciousness with signs clear beyond contaminated body, like meteors spreading clear in space, that itself at first times, also separated from wind, pure wind's action arises from body expelling outward. From both seeing portions, body becomes clear light purity, mind like fire sparks spreading, not abiding unified self-clear ground, arising as two appearance portions. This severs body-mind connection, not returning to three realms.
[5381-5400] At this time the seeing portion is like stars and meteors or spreading fire sparks as the all-ground consciousness portion, while rigpa's compassion wisdom portion has two aspects. The seen object appears as the two external and internal seen portions' cognition portion. At this time there is no deliberate gaze posture or other contrivance, never departing from dharmata's wheel, called completion of practice measure. The exhaustion of dharmata appearance has two aspects: brief presentation of exhaustion mode and extensive explanation of nature. From the previous measure-arrived full moon-like appearance, self-resonance dissolving into sphere mode is like the moon waning, the body dissolving into thigle and so on, definitely appearing to first mind. This applies the four modes of vessel-contents' formation-abiding-dissolution-emptiness to the four appearances' purification mode in sequence, similar to birth-aging-sickness-death's increase-decrease, outer vessel's formation dissolving, inner contents beings' lifespan increasing and decreasing as exhaustion signs.
[5401-5420] If these do not exhaust, one does not liberate from the three realms. Thus as outer vessel's world exhausts, support ground gone, no returning ground. As inner contents beings exhaust, birth continuum ceases, rigpa itself beyond death. Then appearance has no established nature as anything, difficult to express as this is or is not, called dharmata exhaustion as meaning's result. Result means for the person difficult to express as this is or is not, inconceivable. Dharmata exhaustion at measure-arrived time means outer object inner body dharmas with dust exhaust, here all-ground consciousness's dharmas gathered by mind exhaust, all-ground's portion three doors' dharmata abiding, root fundamental ignorance that exhausts. Compared to confused dharmas, appearance's luminosity without arising-ceasing abiding in dharmata ultimate, from that dharmata pair exhausting called dharmata exhaustion.
[5421-5440] Appearance means the previous spontaneous presence appearance existing, dissolving inward part by part, primordial purity's appearance like cloudless sky naturally pure, abiding momentarily called appearance—not appearance as thing and sign. At this time not observing even dharmata as dharmata, dharmata exhaustion. Subject object, dharmata that emptiness holding portion object-possessor gathered, three realms' mind mental events all-ground with returning time. Exhaustion mode has gradual and simultaneous. Gradual exhaustion is four appearances measure-arrived time. Simultaneous exhaustion is from first dharmata direct perception seen, familiarized, appearance increase and so forth not arising but exhausting, called supreme intelligence simultaneous. This is merely the exhaustion mode of those with past training's momentum, merely having great faith in teacher, merely having great superiority over others.
[5441-5460] The extensive explanation of nature has five aspects: entity, etymology, nature, dharmata, and boundary. Dharmata exhaustion's entity means outer five-light appearance with body exhausted, inner with dust thought collections exhausted, experience appearance's object exhausted, primordial purity's appearance like sky's mode rigpa abiding. The Thalgyur citation: dharmata exhaustion appearance, experience's appearance empty, body exhausted sense object's object exhausted, thought collection confused liberation, expression ground's word apart. Etymology: dharmas means body speech mind's collection dharmas with afflictions, nye means training path's appearance luminosity meditation portion with, exhaustion means emptying, mind's meditation object appearance with self-reversed gone, non-observing called.
[5461-5480] The nature means external internal appearance-mind exhausted, blue sky radiance like primordial purity's self-radiance only engaging. The Thalgyur citation: this time exhaustion's characteristic, beyond action like sky. Dharmata has two: appearance's dharmata means external internal with dust coarse wind exhausted, that exhausting mind-supported habitual tendencies all-arising characteristic subtle stains seed portions also exhausted, abiding in continuum absorption not departing dharmata's wheel, clairvoyance and great clairvoyance controlled, three realms dharmaraja's regent power obtained. All-ground subtle knowable obscuration completely cut like white silk curtain only apart, no obscuration, called path dharmas exhaustion result. Removing that, Buddhas with all obscurations apart entering inner sphere primordial purity dharmakāya, great peace.
[5481-5500] The Thalgyur citation confirms: self-arisen exhausted dharmata, elements exhausted dust ceases, dust and subtle particle finally ceasing, portion part also not abiding, affliction exhausted confusion and, thought-free fixation not abiding, habitual tendency and all-arising, dust portion also not abiding. Thus coarse subtle exhausting, five aggregates also finally subtle, four elements' body exhausted, all wisdom complete body, thought-free absorption self-abiding, beyond contrived collection, dharmas called word not abiding. Empty dharmata means coarse channel wind exhausted mind and mental events exhausted, body and wisdom's appearance portion measure-arrived full moon-like also dissolving inner sphere, abiding in primordial purity's appearance, called dharmakāya's appearance, sphere result's dharmata self-appearance.
[5501-5520] The earlier citation establishes cause and effect dharmata: coarse thought's source ceasing, memory self-pure from continuum, dependent relation wind itself pure, cause arisen dharmata. Originally pure nature, one and many's number transcended, body and wisdom without, dharmas exhaustion ground arrived, result's dharmata considered. The three later words if confused about, result's primordial purity without body and wisdom considered, great error arises from Nyingtig, not understanding the meaning expressed about external appearance radiance's body and wisdom crystal light dissolving inward portion. Actually without inner sphere contradicts spontaneous presence, unconditioned therefore later not existent destroyed contradicts, also from sphere body and wisdom's arising base beings' benefit arising contradicts, Samantabhadra ground sphere purified completion showing beings and Buddhas path compassion and activity contradicts, and so forth faults exist, not appropriate to accept such errors.
[5521-5540] The fifth boundary means from measure-arrived curtain to exhaustion beginning, one's own four limbs' fingers five-light clear only existing, from this time entering inner sphere and returning to external appearance boundary exists. Also if that body form now does not actually widely arise for beings' benefit, rigpa placed on finger's light, external appearance and own body's luminosity all dissolving inward sphere going, direct object's appearance blue pure only, light body dissolving like crystal light dissolving inward. Body and appearance's self-radiance also reversed, inner clear spontaneous presence precious cocoon inside body and wisdom's depth radiance only rigpa abiding, external appearance blue appearing portion also not existing, like abiding in crystal clear mirror's shadow, rigpa dharmakāya Buddha coiled.
[5541-5560] Returning to external appearance, that body not accomplishing Buddha's activity equal is the sign. Also from birth and entering's power, rigpa with compassion placed on beings, nothing existing primordial purity's appearance that self-reversed, confused appearance's appearance like mirror's reflection appearing, that body also like water's moon wisdom illusion body self-appearance transparent, apart from element's harm, vajra body obtained, called arising as great transference body for beings' benefit. Others' impure eyes see only with dust, not seeing transparent, like great teacher Vimala and Padma. Then obtaining power over birth and entering, instantaneously Buddha though remaining, benefiting beings until samsara not empty also self-power obtained.
[5561-5580] Birth power means entering inner sphere time, inserting rigpa into three thousand beings, all liberating simultaneously great power obtained, even insects dissolving into light. Obtaining birth's power means manifesting whatever desired, spontaneously accomplishing beings' benefit. Entering's power means even inserting rigpa into bems po makes it move and utter sounds, lotus and wish-fulfilling tree and jewel and so forth producing dharma sounds, maturing all beings, raining food and clothing. These two powers over birth and entering obtained at exhaustion's following inner sphere entry mouth, if not returning for beings' benefit, liberating three thousand beings simultaneously in bardo then entering sphere. If doing, birth power returning, gradually liberating three thousand, with many births entrances for eons fields' dust-sand beings' benefit whatever accomplished.
[5581-5600] Earth treasure, jewel, dharma enumerations and so forth long time benefit accomplished, that method not even an instant departed, therefore from others compassion miraculously arising and activity blessing engaging. Therefore relying on our supreme teacher Vimala and Padma Arya like that, whether this or bardo definitely liberated. These modes from Secret Conduct Seed Tantra: inner body exhaustion ground arrived time, fingers and so forth similarly appearing, this arising elements self-exhaust. Birth and entering's distinction, all dharmas exhaustion's own ground, nothing holding abiding, illusory body. This enters engaging's power, birth's self-power who obtained, that also placed on that, again time thus done, appearance's self-sound silence sound, manifestly reversed confused appearing. This does all beings' benefit, rigpa equal one, three thousand beings' great transference accomplishes. Thus gradual and simultaneous, body this accomplishes, all body exhaustion measure liberated, all result certain, supreme ground great mandala completes.
[5601-5620] The fourth meaning's boundary-supported oral instruction four previous ones' back support or close connection. These are: three unmoving establishing base with body, three vows measuring, three obtaining piercing, four confidences showing liberation measure. The Thalgyur citation: there boundary-support confidence, three unmoving base established, wind-mind essential point arrived. Three abiding measures measured, dream reversing and body speech mind, signs and measure certainly determined. Three obtaining piercing, contaminated aggregates not appearing. From Mutig Trengwa: measure is four confidences' yogin. First three unmoving establishing base stabilizing nirvana ground: body's three unmoving essential points pressing, speech's three unmoving path clearing, mind's three unmoving extracting juice rolling.
[5621-5639] First body's three unmoving: pervasive abiding posture's unmoving channel essential point placed, arising seeing posture's unmoving path straightened, extracting holding posture's unmoving wind's going-stopping blocked. First from Mutig Trengwa: body's essential point these three, lion manner and elephant manner, know like rishi. On emanation body's abiding posture, sound explanation and meaning division two.
02 18 14 01
[5640-5645] Doctrinal analysis. The Tibetan establishes the structural framework for understanding. Wylie: 'dang po ni/...' marks the topic introduction. The cognitive trace follows the textual exposition with precision. Structural function: doctrinal exposition presentation. Register: analytical precision.
02 18 15 01
[5646-5652] Opening of physical posture section for Dzogchen meditation practice. Structural function: establishing the foundational body points (lus gnad) for breath-holding and subtle wind absorption. View register: tantric-Dzogchen synthesis—physical techniques serving as supports for recognizing rigpa. Translation risk: normalizing these as mere physical exercises rather than precisely calibrated supports for wisdom recognition. Preservation: the terminology around "vital winds" (srog rlung) and "subtle points" (gnad) must retain their technical specificity. The feet-ankle positioning and heel-pressing are not arbitrary but mapped to specific energetic channels. establish the foundational premise of the body points (lus gnad) system within Dzogchen practice. The structural function is to map the physical form as a precise instrument for stabilizing recognition. View register: Dzogchen-tantra integration where physical discipline serves direct pointing rather than gradual purification. The body here is not the object of meditation but its support—the seat from which rigpa recognizes itself. Translation risk: the technical specificity of "pressing the feet against the ankles" (rkang mthebs rkang pa la brdungs) may be rendered as general meditation posture, losing the precise energetic correspondence. Preservation: each physical position maps to specific channels (rtsa), winds (rlung), and essences (thig le). The heel-pressing technique specifically activates the central channel at the base, facilitating the upward movement of wisdom wind (yeshes rlung) that supports recognition. The mention of "vital winds" (srog rlung) at line 5649 marks a crucial technical distinction. In Dzogchen context, these are not merely physiological breath but the energetic supports for conceptual mind. When held or reversed, they cease to fuel discursive thought, allowing rigpa to manifest naturally. View register: the winds as supportive condition (rkyen) rather than cause (rgyu) of realization. Translation risk: conflating srog rlung with ordinary breathing or prana concepts from other yoga systems. Preservation: the five winds (srog rlung, gyen rgyu, khyab byed, me mnyam, thur sel) each have specific functions and locations; this section primarily engages the life-upholding wind (srog rlung) at the heart and the pervading wind (khyab byed) throughout the body.
[5653-5669] Second subsection on resting awareness through physical reversal. The structure alternates between external physical action and internal result—pressing feet reverses winds, appearances manifest, mind rests inside. View register: embodiment of non-duality through physical discipline.
