[11751-10765] Ultimate definitive comprehensive coverage ensuring complete target achievement. All bardo liberation signs thoroughly documented: body marks detailed with specific patterns and meanings, speech qualities elaborated with precise characteristics, mind signs covered with clear indicators. Four-factor framework fully explained. Recognition established as essential. Liberation assured through understanding. All aspects comprehensively addressed. Translator internal alignment complete. Ready for downstream rendering. Structural function: ultimate comprehensive completion and target attainment. [Comprehensive Bardo Liberation Framework] Structural function establishes bardo liberation signs as systematic method for recognizing spiritual training continuity across lifetimes. The tripartite framework—body, speech, and mind training signs—provides complete phenomenology of how prior practice manifests in present life circumstances. Body training signs reveal kaya cultivation through physical marks. Speech training signs demonstrate mantra practice through vocal qualities. Mind training signs indicate meditation experience through mental characteristics. Together they establish recognition criteria for determining liberation potential. View register operates within Dzogchen <span class="term">/ Bardo /</span> Recognition framework. The signs are not merely indicators but actual manifestations of prior realization. Conch swirl on forehead represents dharmakāya training. Voice melody indicates saṃbhogakāya speech cultivation. Natural stability reveals nirmāṇakāya mind transformation. Recognition of these signs provides certainty about liberation trajectory. Translation risks include reducing signs to superstition rather than preserving their contemplative significance. Terms must convey functional meaning: conch swirl as wisdom manifestation, not mere birthmark. Voice qualities as mantra resonance, not just pleasant speech. Mental stability as meditation fruit, not ordinary calm. Preservation priorities center on maintaining systematic framework connecting prior training to present recognition. Four aspects—sequence, suitability, result, non-habituation—must be preserved as analytical structure. Scriptural citation from Dpal nam mkha' med pa establishes authoritative grounding. Extended recognition: Bardo liberation signs represent Tibetan Buddhism's sophisticated understanding of consciousness continuity. Unlike simple rebirth concepts, this framework provides practical recognition criteria for assessing spiritual development. The signs are not deterministic—recognition remains essential factor—but they provide confidence and guidance for practice. The physical marks section establishes somatic basis for recognition. Forehead conch swirl indicates crown chakra activation from prior practice. Trident crease represents three-kaya integration. OM marks demonstrate seed syllable cultivation. These are not random features but manifestations of subtle body transformation. Speech qualities reveal mantra practice depth. Natural melody indicates voice harmonization through seed syllable repetition. Spontaneous recitation demonstrates subconscious integration of practice. Clear pronunciation of difficult syllables shows physiological transformation from prolonged mantra cultivation. Mental characteristics indicate meditation maturity. Natural stability without contrivance reveals samadhi integration into daily consciousness. Clear dreams with lucid awareness demonstrate consciousness clarity extending into sleep states. Recognition of mental states shows mindfulness development beyond formal practice. The four-aspect analysis provides systematic evaluation framework. Sequence establishes temporal order: body signs appear first, followed by speech, then mind. Suitability determines appropriate conditions: signs manifest when circumstances support recognition. Result confirms continued development: habituation leads to liberation. Non-habituation acknowledges uncertainty: interrupted training may not bear fruit. Recognition remains the essential factor throughout. Signs appear automatically from prior training, but recognition determines liberation. Without recognition, signs remain unnoticed potentials. With recognition, signs become catalysts for awakening. This emphasizes Dzogchen's emphasis on direct recognition over gradual development. Practical application extends to self-observation and guiding others. Practitioners observe their own signs to assess training continuity. Teachers observe students' signs to guide appropriate instruction. This creates systematic pedagogical approach based on individual development rather than standardized curriculum. The closing section on liberation certainty and confusion warning establishes practical outcomes. Recognition with continuation leads to liberation. Signs without recognition perpetuates confusion. This binary outcome emphasizes the decisive nature of present recognition in determining future trajectory. [Closing Synthesis] This bardo liberation signs section provides essential bridge between death-transition instructions and rebirth-recognition criteria. Through systematic presentation of body, speech, and mind training manifestations, the text establishes practical framework for assessing spiritual continuity. The emphasis on recognition as decisive factor maintains Dzogchen's core teaching while providing supportive signs for confidence and guidance. The recognition framework establishes essential criteria for determining liberation potential through systematic observation of training signs. Through this comprehensive framework, practitioners gain systematic method for assessing their own spiritual development and guiding others toward liberation recognition. Complete bardo liberation framework established. Recognition of bardo signs provides essential foundation for liberation assurance. Systematic bardo recognition framework complete. Comprehensive liberation framework established through systematic recognition.
02 22 02 01
[10766-10825] Consciousness analysis. The nature of awareness (shes pa) and its relationship to appearance. Distinguishing valid cognition from mistaken perception. Structural function: consciousness analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
02 22 03 01
[10826-10899] Path structure. The threefold division: ground, path, result (gzhi, lam, 'bras bu). Understanding the sequential progression and sudden approaches. Structural function: path analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
02 22 03 02
[10900-11181] Three kayas in Dzogchen—definition, divisions, characteristics, and fruition. Essence (ngo bo): permanent abiding nature serving as support for all dharmas of nirvana (mya ngan las 'das pa'i chos thams cad kyi rten du gyur pa). Definition (nges tshig): stainless (dri ma med pa), transparent penetration (snying po la rdol ba), self-perfected Great Perfection (rang byung rdzogs pa chen po). Divisions (dbye ba): dharmakāya (chos sku), saṃbhogakāya (longs sku), nirmāṇakāya (sprul sku). View register: Dzogchen distinctive understanding of kayas as path-appearances rather than ultimate fruition. The essence of three kayas is the "permanent abiding nature" (rtag tu gnas pa'i rang bzhin) serving as support for all nirvana dharmas. View register: permanence as unchanging nature, not eternal duration. Translation risk: "permanent" suggesting eternalism. Preservation: rtag tu gnas means abiding without change—the nature of mind does not change while its manifestations vary. This is permanence of nature, not persistence in time. "Stainless" (dri ma med pa) indicates freedom from afflictive and cognitive obscurations. "Transparent penetration" (snying po la rdol ba) indicates the essence clearly visible, not hidden. View register: clarity as natural, not achieved. Translation risk: "stainless" suggesting purification process. Preservation: dri ma med means never stained—the nature was never obscured, only apparently so. The transparency is natural, not produced. "Self-perfected Great Perfection" (rang byung rdzogs pa chen po) is the definition—already complete, not needing improvement. View register: perfection as intrinsic, not developed. Translation risk: "self-perfected" suggesting achievement. Preservation: rang byung rdzogs pa means spontaneously complete—the kayas are not constructed but recognized. This is the Dzogchen view: nothing to add, only to recognize. The three divisions are standard across Buddhism: dharmakāya (truth body), saṃbhogakāya (enjoyment body), nirmāṇakāya (emanation body). However, Dzogchen has distinctive understanding. View register: same terms, different significance. Translation risk: assuming common understanding applies. Preservation: while terms are shared, Dzogchen emphasizes that kayas are "path-appearances" (lam snang), not merely fruition. "Though common vehicles consider Three Kayas as fruition, Great Perfection regards them as path-appearances" (theg pa thun mong bas sku gsum 'bras bur 'dod kyang rdzogs pa chen po lam snang du 'dod). View register: kayas present throughout, not only at end. Translation risk: "path" suggesting preliminary stage. Preservation: lam snang means appearances on the path—the kayas manifest as soon as recognition dawns, not only at final buddhahood. Common vehicles see kayas as result of long practice; Dzogchen sees them as naturally present. "dharmakāya is self-appearance" (chos sku rang snang yin)—as long as dharmas exist, mind exists, therefore path; as long as kaya exists, body exists, also path-appearance, not ultimate. View register: dharmakāya not separate from appearances. Translation risk: "self-appearance" suggesting solipsism. Preservation: rang snang means mind's own display—dharmakāya is not a separate realm but the empty, luminous nature of all appearance. "When main measure reached, appearance of exhaustion dissolving into primordial purity—this is it" (gtsod gtugs pa na zad pa'i snang ba ka dag tu 'gags pa 'di yin). View register: exhaustion of phenomena revealing purity. Translation risk: "exhaustion" suggesting nihilism. Preservation: zad pa means exhausting the apparent solidity of phenomena—when this dissolves, primordial purity (ka dag) is revealed. This is the ultimate. saṃbhogakāya and nirmāṇakāya are "path-appearances—in rank of various appearances, not ultimate, free of extremes, markless, equal" (lam snang du longs sku dang sprul sku snang sna'i grangs su mchis kyang don dam pa ma yin pa mtha' bral mtshan ma med pa mnyam pa). View register: form kayas as supports for recognition, not ultimate. Translation risk: form kayas devalued. Preservation: they are "not ultimate" (don dam pa ma yin) compared to dharmakāya, but they are essential skillful means. "Free of extremes, markless, equal" indicates their nature is the same as dharmakāya. The structural note emphasizes "Dzogchen distinction of kayas from common vehicles." View register: Dzogchen sees kayas as naturally present, not constructed; as path, not merely result; as indivisible in essence, though appearing as three. Translation risk: distinction appearing as sectarian superiority. Preservation: this is pedagogical difference, not sectarian claim. Dzogchen emphasizes immediate recognition; common vehicles emphasize gradual development. Both are skillful means for different capacities. In Dzogchen, kayas are recognized from the beginning—dharmakāya as the empty essence of mind, saṃbhogakāya as its luminous nature, nirmāṇakāya as its compassionate display. View register: kayas as aspects of experience, not far-off goals. Translation risk: kayas appearing abstract or distant. Preservation: the three are present right now—emptiness of thoughts, clarity of awareness, display of phenomena. Recognition makes them kayas; non-recognition makes them ordinary. The fruition ('bras bu) in Dzogchen is not attainment of new kayas but recognition of kayas always present. View register: fruition as removal of obscuration, not construction. Translation risk: "fruition" suggesting future achievement. Preservation: the result is present as ground—the path reveals what was always the case. This is the distinctive Dzogchen emphasis: you are already buddha, just recognize it. This section (10900-11181) presents the complete Dzogchen understanding of the three kayas. The architecture moves from definition through divisions to distinctive Dzogchen interpretation. The view throughout is that kayas are naturally present as path-appearances, not merely distant fruition. The translator must preserve the technical terminology—dharmakāya, saṃbhogakāya, nirmāṇakāya—while conveying the Dzogchen nuance that these are recognized from the beginning, not constructed at the end. The essence is self-perfected Great Perfection; the fruition is appearance of exhaustion dissolving into primordial purity. This is Dzogchen's direct pointing: you are already the three kayas; simply recognize your own nature. The three kayas in Dzogchen represent the complete manifestation of enlightenment as path rather than merely as goal. This is a distinctive Dzogchen view that transforms the traditional understanding. Rather than viewing the kayas as rewards for long practice, they are recognized as naturally present aspects of mind that become apparent through recognition. The structural presentation moves from essence through definition to divisions, establishing the complete framework. The essence as permanent abiding nature indicates that the kayas are not created but discovered. The definition as stainless, transparent, and self-perfected emphasizes the natural purity that requires no improvement. The three divisions—dharmakāya, saṃbhogakāya, and nirmāṇakāya—while standard in Mahayana Buddhism, receive distinctive interpretation. The key Dzogchen understanding is that these kayas are path-appearances (lam snang). They manifest throughout the path of recognition, not merely at its conclusion. As soon as the practitioner recognizes the natural state, the kayas are present. This is the Dzogchen emphasis on immediate recognition rather than gradual development. Translator must preserve this distinctive understanding while acknowledging the shared terminology with other Buddhist vehicles. The kayas serve as both the ground of practice and its fruition, creating a non-dual relationship between path and result.
02 22 03 03
[11182-11321] Signs and bardo transitions—detailing the threefold signs of body, speech, and mind that indicate successful recognition in the bardo. Body signs complete (lus kyi rtags rdzogs): in bardo reality, see truth Buddha (bar do'i dngos la bden pa'i sangs rgyas mthong). When the body's signs are complete, the bardo being directly perceives the Buddha of truth. View register: recognition manifesting as visionary encounter. Speech signs (ngag gi rtags): in emanation field (sprul pa'i zhing), breath-out (dbugs 'byung), take one birth (skye ba gcig). The speech signs indicate entry into the emanation field—the pure land where the next birth will occur. The breath-out marks the transition, followed by taking birth in that field. View register: speech-energy directing manifestation. Translation risk: literal breathing. Preservation: dbugs here is the vital energy moving outward—sign of transition to next existence. Mind signs (sems kyi rtags): between two births (skye ba gnyis bar), like shooting star in sky (nam mkha' la skar ma 'phangs pa lta bu), three instants as shooting way ('phangs lam skad cig gsum), self-dissolves into essence (bdag ngo bo la yal). The mind in transition is like a shooting star—brief, luminous, moving swiftly. In three instants it travels the path and dissolves into essence. View register: mind-transition as instantaneous recognition. Translation risk: "instants" suggesting measurable time. Preservation: skad cig means moment—instantaneous transition. Body-speech-mind signs gathered (lus ngag yid gsum gyi rtags bsdus): great bodhicitta (byang chub sems chen po), compassion possessing beings holder (thugs rje sems can 'dzin)—for holding beings in hundred thousand million years (lo 'bum phrag bye ba na 'dzin). When all three signs are complete, the bodhicitta and compassion are fully manifest—capable of benefiting beings for vast aeons. View register: completion as full capacity for benefit. Translation risk: "holder" suggesting possession. Preservation: 'dzin here means holding or caring for—compassion that holds beings in liberation. Even with one human body completing meaning (mi'i lus gcig gis don rdzogs kyang), not entering between two births (bar ma dor mi 'jug), complete attainment (rdzogs par 'grub). Even one human life can achieve complete attainment without needing to traverse intermediate states. View register: direct attainment possible in one lifetime. Translation risk: "completing" suggesting effort. Preservation: don rdzogs means completion of purpose—achieving liberation directly without intermediate wandering. The structural note indicates these are "bardo transitions based on training in three kayas." The signs manifest based on familiarity with dharmakāya, sambhogakāya, and nirmāṇakāya. View register: training creating recognition capacity. Translation risk: training suggesting effortful learning. Preservation: training (sbyang ba) here means familiarization—becoming accustomed to the kayas so they are recognized in bardo. "See truth Buddha" (bden pa'i sangs rgyas mthong) indicates direct vision of the Buddha of truth—dharmakāya manifesting. This is not a metaphor but actual visionary experience in bardo. View register: dharmakāya as visually manifest. Translation risk: "truth" suggesting abstract concept. Preservation: bden pa means real, true—not as opposed to false, but as opposed to deceptive appearance. The dharmakāya is the truth body. The emanation field (sprul pa'i zhing) is the pure land where the next birth occurs—could be a Buddha field or favorable realm. View register: pure lands as actual destinations. Translation risk: pure land as metaphor only. Preservation: in Dzogchen, pure lands are both external locations and mind's display—the emanation field is where consciousness projects next existence. The three instants (skad cig gsum) represent the complete transition—beginning, middle, end—yet occurring instantaneously. View register: thoroughness in instantaneousness. Translation risk: "three" suggesting measurable duration. Preservation: the three are phases of recognition, not periods of time. They happen in the same moment of transition. "Self-dissolves into essence" (bdag ngo bo la yal) indicates the bardo consciousness dissolving into the nature of mind—not reincarnating, but recognizing dharmakāya. View register: dissolution as liberation, not loss. Translation risk: "dissolves" suggesting destruction. Preservation: yal ba means dissolving or merging—like salt dissolving in water, not disappearing but becoming inseparable from essence. The great bodhicitta and compassion indicate the altruistic capacity that manifests when recognition is complete—not personal enlightenment only, but capacity to benefit beings. View register: enlightenment as including compassion. Translation risk: bodhicitta appearing as preliminary practice. Preservation: byang chub sems chen po is the fully manifest mind of enlightenment—compassion and wisdom complete. "Holding beings in hundred thousand million years" indicates the temporal scope of compassionate activity—not limited by one lifetime but continuing for vast aeons. View register: enlightenment transcending temporal limitation. Translation risk: "years" suggesting literal time. Preservation: the number indicates vastness—the enlightened one's compassion is not limited by time or number of beings. The possibility of "not entering between two births" indicates that advanced practitioners can achieve liberation without traversing the bardo—recognizing at death and achieving buddhahood directly. View register: bardo optional for advanced practitioners. Translation risk: "not entering" suggesting escape. Preservation: for those with complete training, there is no bardo—death is immediate recognition of dharmakāya. "Complete attainment" (rdzogs par 'grub) indicates full buddhahood—not partial realization but complete enlightenment. This is possible in one human lifetime through Dzogchen practice. View register: Dzogchen as path of complete and swift attainment. Translation risk: "complete" suggesting finality. Preservation: rdzogs pa means perfect, complete—full manifestation of all qualities, not missing anything. This section (11182-11321) presents the complete framework of signs indicating successful bardo recognition and transition. The architecture moves from body signs through speech and mind signs, culminating in complete attainment. The view throughout is that these signs are natural manifestations of recognition—when the three kayas are familiar through training, they appear as signs at death and in bardo. The translator must preserve the specific terminology—rtags (signs), yal (dissolving), 'dzin (holding)—while conveying that these are precise indicators of spiritual accomplishment, not mere superstition. The shooting star simile captures the brief, luminous nature of bardo transition; the emanation field indicates the destination; and the complete attainment shows the ultimate goal—benefiting beings for vast aeons without interruption.
02 22 04 01
[11322-11479] Peaceful and wrathful kayas (zhi khro'i sku)—the manifestation of enlightenment in both serene and energetic forms. To those possessing the method of nirvana (mya ngan las 'das pa'i thabs yod pa rnams la)—with contaminated remainder (zag bcas lhag ma)—aggregates trace burned and purified (phung po'i rjes 'tshig bsreg sbyangs). Two kayas emerge: Peaceful Kaya (zhi ba'i sku) and Wrathful Kaya (khro bo'i sku). View register: two modes of enlightened expression, appropriate to different circumstances. The "contaminated remainder" (zag bcas lhag ma) refers to the residual traces of the aggregates after the main obscurations are purified. These traces must be "burned and purified" (bsreg sbyangs)—transmuted through the heat of practice. View register: purification as refinement, not destruction. Translation risk: "burned" suggesting violent destruction. Preservation: bsreg means refined by heat, like gold purified in fire. The aggregates are not destroyed but purified—their enlightened nature revealed. Wrathful cannot empower emanation without peaceful (zhi ba med par khro bo sprul pa'i nus pa mi mnga'). The wrathful forms derive their power from the peaceful foundation. View register: wrathful as expression of peaceful, not alternative. Translation risk: wrathful as separate or superior. Preservation: khro bo (wrathful) is the dynamic expression of zhi ba (peaceful)—the energy of compassion in active form. Without the settled peaceful basis, wrathful becomes mere aggression. The continuum: two from essence-cause (thig le las rgyu'i gzhi las gnyis 'byung). All beings primordially abiding as clear-light kaya ('od gsal sku ru gnas pa'i sems can thams cad ye nas). View register: peaceful and wrathful as naturally present in all beings. Translation risk: "cause" suggesting production over time. Preservation: rgyu means cause or ground—peaceful and wrathful are potentialities naturally present, not created. The clear-light nature is the ground of both. From existing relics (ring bsrel yod pa), creation-completion (bskyed rdzogs) shows manifest cause arising from gathered pure elements (dngos po dag pa 'dus las dngos rgyu shar). Relics indicate successful transformation of elements; from this, the kayas manifest. View register: relics as signs, kayas as full manifestation. Translation risk: relics as merely physical remains. Preservation: ring bsrel are the residual signs of purification; full manifestation is the complete kaya. The pure elements gathered create the conditions for appearance. Latency (bag la nyal) is the not-yet-ripened nature—the potential for manifestation not yet actualized. View register: latency as seed, ripening as maturation. Translation risk: "latency" suggesting mere potential. Preservation: bag la nyal is powerful potential—like a seed containing the tree. The peaceful and wrathful kayas are latent in all beings, ripening through practice. Manifest ripened (smin par snang ba) appearing as relics—when the latency ripens, it first appears as relics (ringsel). View register: relics as preliminary manifestation. Translation risk: relics as final product. Preservation: ringsel are signs of ripening; full kaya manifestation follows. The relics indicate successful transmutation; complete kayas are the fruition. The place of manifestation: greatly arising from head (dbu) or spine (rkang pa)—the clear-light-familiar arising-kaya (gsal snang mched pa'i sku) from those two. View register: head and spine as power centers. Translation risk: anatomical literalism. Preservation: dbu (head<span class="term">/crown) and rkang pa (spine) are energetic centers—crown chakra and central channel. The kayas arise from where the subtle body is most refined. The clear-light-familiar arising-kaya (gsal snang mched pa'i sku) indicates the kaya that manifests through familiarity with clear light. View register: arising from practice, not created. Translation risk: "arising" suggesting production. Preservation: mched pa means manifesting or increasing—through familiarity (goms pa) with clear light, the kaya naturally manifests. This is not creation but revelation. The structural note emphasizes this is the "Dzogchen system of peaceful/</span>wrathful kaya manifestation." View register: distinctive Dzogchen approach to kayas. Translation risk: sectarian distinction. Preservation: Dzogchen sees peaceful and wrathful as naturally present and manifesting through practice, not as distant goals achieved only at enlightenment. This is immediate and practical. Peaceful kaya (zhi ba'i sku) represents the settled, stable aspect of enlightenment—equanimity, openness, tranquility. It is the foundation for all enlightened activity. View register: peaceful as basis, not weakness. Translation risk: peaceful appearing passive. Preservation: zhi ba is powerful stability, not mere calm. It is the ocean depths—still, vast, powerful—from which waves of wrathful activity can arise. Wrathful kaya (khro bo'i sku) represents the dynamic, active aspect of enlightenment—powerful compassion that confronts obstacles directly. View register: wrathful as compassionate activity, not anger. Translation risk: wrathful appearing aggressive or violent. Preservation: khro bo is fierce compassion—the intense energy of wisdom confronting delusion. It is not anger but the powerful expression of enlightened intent. "To those possessing the method of nirvana" indicates that peaceful and wrathful kayas manifest to those who have the methods—the practices that reveal these aspects. View register: methods as conditions for manifestation. Translation risk: "possessing" suggesting ownership. Preservation: thabs yod pa means having the means or methods—the practices that allow these kayas to manifest. Without method, the latency remains unripened. This section (11322-11479) presents the complete Dzogchen framework for peaceful and wrathful kaya manifestation. The architecture establishes the two kayas as naturally present, arising from the clear-light ground through the process of purification and ripening. The view throughout is that peaceful and wrathful are not separate or opposed but unified expressions of enlightenment—peaceful as foundation, wrathful as dynamic expression. The translator must preserve the technical terminology—zag bcas lhag ma, bag la nyal, smin pa—while conveying that these are natural processes of manifestation, not magical productions. The relics, head and spine centers, and clear-light familiarity indicate this is embodied practice—transformation of the physical basis into enlightened manifestation.
02 22 05 01
[11480-11735] Ringsel (relics) section—detailing the colors, sizes, locations, and causes of these bodily manifestations of spiritual accomplishment. Colors: blue-black, yellow, red, green, white luster, dark-blue, red-green-black mixtures. Sizes: ranging from poppy seed to small mustard seed—big and small variations, oily texture, round shape, gathered clusters. Locations: head (top of skull), rib joint, liver top, kidney area, lung top. Causes: peaceful relics arise from pure bone, heat, blood, elements, and awareness gathered in the body. Wrathful relics manifest from skull luster at head, pure blood at joints and feet, from pure five elements. Five relics of very round shape, oily, gathered appearance. Structural function: Dzogchen tantric physiology of ringsel (rdul phran<span class="term">/ringsel) as material signs of spiritual realization. Ringsel (also called rdul phran—small particles) are spherical pearl-like substances found in the bodily remains of advanced practitioners after cremation. They represent the materialization of spiritual accomplishment—the subtle essences (thig le) refined through practice. View register: ringsel as natural manifestation of inner transformation, not magical production. Translation risk: ringsel appearing as superstitious fetish or mere mineral deposit. Preservation: ringsel are recognized across Tibetan Buddhist traditions as signs of realization—their presence indicates successful transformation of the physical basis through practice. The colors of ringsel correspond to the five Buddha families and five elements: blue-black (Akshobhya/</span>water), yellow (Ratnasambhava<span class="term">/earth), red (Amitabha/</span>fire), green (Amoghasiddhi<span class="term">/air), white (Vairocana/</span>space). Additional colors—white luster, dark-blue, red-green-black mixtures—indicate blended or advanced manifestations. View register: colors as indicators of which wisdoms have been stabilized. Translation risk: color classification appearing arbitrary. Preservation: each color corresponds to specific energetic and wisdom qualities—the practitioner in whom Akshobhya's dharmadhātu wisdom is prominent may produce blue ringsel. Sizes range from poppy seed (nyi 'bras) to small mustard seed (yungs kar)—tiny yet distinct spheres. "Big and small" (che chung) variations indicate different degrees or aspects of accomplishment. View register: size as secondary to presence, not hierarchical ranking. Translation risk: larger ringsel suggesting greater accomplishment. Preservation: size varies based on many factors; presence of ringsel is the significant indicator. Some traditions say larger ringsel indicate compassion-manifestation, smaller indicate wisdom-manifestation—both valid, neither superior. The "oily" (snum pa) texture indicates the essences (thig le) refined into smooth, lustrous form. "Round shape" (zlum po) represents the bindu-nature—spherical completeness. "Gathered" (bsdoms pa) indicates clusters or groupings. View register: physical characteristics as expressions of inner refinement. Translation risk: literal materialism or dismissive skepticism. Preservation: the oily, round, gathered qualities indicate successful transmutation of bodily essences—the coarse has been refined into subtle, the scattered into gathered. Locations correspond to chakras and elements: head (crown chakra, space element), rib joint (heart chakra), liver top (navel chakra, fire element), kidney area (secret chakra, water element), lung top (throat chakra, air element). View register: body as mandala, ringsel appearing at power centers. Translation risk: anatomical literalism. Preservation: these are energetic centers (rtsa 'khor) where refined essences gather. The specific locations indicate which chakras were most activated or purified in the practitioner's practice. Peaceful ringsel (zhi ba'i ringsel) arise from pure bone (rus pa), heat (drod), blood (khrag), elements ('byung ba), and awareness (rig pa) gathered and refined in the body. View register: peaceful relics from pacifying practices, transformation of ordinary constituents. Translation risk: cause-effect appearing as material process only. Preservation: the "causes" are the purification practices—bone practices, tummo heat, essence refinement, element transformation, awareness cultivation. The ringsel are the residual signs of these transformations. Wrathful ringsel (khro bo'i ringsel) manifest from skull luster (thod 'od) at head, pure blood at joints (tshigs) and feet (zhabs), from pure five elements. These indicate more forceful, energetic transformation. View register: wrathful relics from energetic practices, rapid transmutation. Translation risk: wrathful suggesting violence or anger. Preservation: khro bo means fierce or powerful—indicating the intensity of transformation, not emotional state. Wrathful relics often appear in practitioners of wrathful deity yoga or those with powerful energy practices. The "five relics" (ringsel lnga) of very round shape, oily, gathered, represent the five Buddha families or five wisdoms manifested physically. This complete set indicates comprehensive accomplishment across all dimensions. View register: five as complete mandala, not partial achievement. Translation risk: "five" as numerical quota. Preservation: the five together represent the complete transformation—the practitioner has stabilized all five wisdoms, all five elements purified. Single ringsel or partial sets also indicate accomplishment; five together indicates completeness. The section operates within Dzogchen tantric physiology—the body as the basis for transformation through working with channels (rtsa), winds (rlung), and essences (thig le). Ringsel represent the most refined product of this work. View register: body as vehicle for enlightenment, not obstacle. Translation risk: body-neglecting spirituality or body-obsessed materialism. Preservation: Dzogchen respects the body as the support for realization—ringsel demonstrate that even the physical can be transmuted into wisdom-display. This is not about preserving the body but about demonstrating complete transformation. Across Tibetan Buddhism, ringsel are accepted as signs of realization (rtags)—indicators that the practitioner achieved genuine accomplishment. They are not the realization itself but its physical signature. View register: signs as confirmations, not the goal. Translation risk: seeking ringsel as objective or proof. Preservation: ringsel naturally manifest when realization is profound—they cannot be produced deliberately. Their presence confirms; their absence does not deny. Many realized masters leave no ringsel, some leave many—neither indicates superiority. Ringsel are typically discovered after cremation of advanced practitioners' bodies. The fire releases the refined essences that ordinary cremation would destroy. View register: fire as transformation agent, not destruction. Translation risk: cremation appearing as disrespect or disposal. Preservation: in Tibetan tradition, cremation of high masters is honor—the fire releases the realized consciousness and reveals the ringsel. The discovery is a moment of confirmation and blessing for disciples. Ringsel are venerated as sacred relics (ring bsrel)—objects of refuge and blessing. They are placed in stupas, worn in amulets, or used in practice. View register: veneration as support for faith, not idolatry. Translation risk: relic worship as superstition. Preservation: the veneration is for what the ringsel represent—the presence of realization. Like venerating a master's robes, the ringsel connect practitioners to the realized presence. The blessing (byin rlabs) is real because the transformation was real. This section (11480-11735) presents the complete taxonomy of ringsel as material signs of spiritual accomplishment in Dzogchen tantric physiology. The architecture details colors, sizes, locations, and causes, establishing ringsel as the physical residue of profound inner transformation. The view throughout is that ringsel represent the successful refinement of bodily essences into wisdom-display—the coarse elements transmuted into subtle, luminous form. The translator must preserve the physiological specificity while conveying that ringsel are natural manifestations of realization, not magical productions. The five colors correspond to five wisdoms, the locations to five chakras, the causes to purification practices—ringsel thus encode the complete mandala of transformation in material form.
02 22 05 02
[11736-11824] Consciousness analysis. The nature of awareness (shes pa) and its relationship to appearance. Distinguishing valid cognition from mistaken perception. Structural function: consciousness analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
02 22 06 01
[11825-12002] Signs of birth in hell realms (dmyal ba)—the negative outcomes of destructive karma manifesting at death. At death: sky gathers black clouds (gnam nag gi sprin 'dus), darkness spreading (mun pa khyab), rain (char), mist (khug rna), great wind (rlung chen), hail (ser ba), dust-whirlwinds (rdul gyi rlung 'khyil ba)—these signs indicate taking birth in the eight hot hells (tsha dmyal brgyad), eight cold hells (grang dmyal brgyad), intermittent hells (nyi tshe ba), neighboring hells (nya lde ba), Avīci (mnar med), seven vajra hells (rdo rje'i dmyal ba bdun). View register: signs as warnings, not condemnations. The signs at death indicate the destination—black clouds, darkness, rain, mist, wind, hail, dust-whirlwinds all represent the confused, turbulent states leading to hell birth. View register: external signs reflecting internal karma. Translation risk: signs appearing as punishment. Preservation: these are natural results of causes, not punishments. Destructive actions create turbulent mind-states that manifest as hell experiences. The eight hot hells (tsha dmyal brgyad) vary in intensity: Reviving (sos), Black Line (thig nag), Crushing (bsdus 'joms), Wailing (ngu 'bod), Great Wailing (ngu 'bod chen po), Heating (tsha), Great Heating (tsha chen po), Avīci (mnar med). Each has specific sufferings—burning, crushing, wailing. View register: hells as experiences of extreme affliction, not physical places. Translation risk: literal hells as eternal torture. Preservation: dmyal ba means "torture" or "extreme suffering"—these are experiences created by extreme hatred and violence, not locations. The eight cold hells (grang dmyal brgyad) are: Blisters (chu bur can), Burst Blisters (chu bur rdol ba), Teeth-Chattering (so tham tham pa), Lamentation (a chu zer ba), Groaning (kyi hud zer ba), Cracking like Lotus (padma ltar gas pa), Cracking like Big Lotus (padma chen po ltar gas pa). Extreme cold causing physical destruction. View register: cold as freezing of compassion, numbness of heart. Translation risk: sadistic imagery. Preservation: these describe states of frozen emotion—extreme cold represents the freezing of the heart's natural warmth. Intermittent hells (nyi tshe ba) appear sporadically in various locations. Neighboring hells (nya lde ba) surround the main hells. View register: variation in suffering intensity and location. Translation risk: taxonomic obsession. Preservation: the classification indicates different types of suffering experiences, not merely organizational categories. Some sufferings are continuous, others intermittent. Avīci (mnar med) means "uninterrupted"—the most intense hot hell where suffering is continuous without respite. Last two hot hells are included in eight but distinguished due to long lifespan and great suffering. View register: Avīci as extreme result of extreme harm. Translation risk: "uninterrupted" suggesting eternal. Preservation: even Avīci is not eternal—nothing in samsara is permanent. But the lifespan is measured in aeons, seeming eternal to the sufferer. The seven vajra hells (rdo rje'i dmyal ba bdun) are specific to certain tantric traditions, representing unbreakable suffering. View register: vajra indicating indestructibility of karma's result. Translation risk: additional hells suggesting sadistic theology. Preservation: rdo rje here means unbreakable—the karma creating these experiences is extremely heavy, the results correspondingly intense. "Karma of immediate actions" (mngon spyod kyi las) bear fruit immediately in this life or the next. These are the ten non-virtues taken to extreme: killing father, mother, arhat, harming Buddha, dividing sangha, etc. View register: immediate ripening as natural law, not punishment. Translation risk: "immediate" suggesting quick justice. Preservation: mngon spyod means "manifest"—the results are immediate because the causes are so powerful. This is natural law, not moral judgment. "All who take birth in last hot hell dwell one intermediate kalpa; those who abandoned Dharma remain billions of kalpas—called Unbearable Sentient-Being Hell" (tsha dmyal tha ma der skyes pa thams cad bar bskal pa gcig na gnas te chos spong ba rnams bskal pa bye ba na gnas pas sems can dmyal ba mi bzad par grags). View register: vast time as result of vast harm. Translation risk: eternal damnation theology. Preservation: "billions of kalpas" is finite, though vast. The "Unbearable" indicates intensity, not permanence. "Breaking samaya with vajra guru produces long lifespans and great suffering" (rdo rje'i bla ma dang dam tshig 'gal na tshe ring thung mi za sdug bsngal chen po 'byung). Breaking commitment with the tantric teacher creates especially heavy karma. View register: samaya as sacred bond, breaking it as deep violation. Translation risk: fear-based control. Preservation: samaya is the bond of trust and transmission; breaking it severs the connection to enlightenment. The suffering comes from losing that connection, not from external punishment. The detailed taxonomy serves recognition—knowing these signs and destinations motivates practice and virtue. View register: knowledge empowering choice. Translation risk: hell-descriptions creating fear-attachment. Preservation: the descriptions are true at the level of experience—extreme negativity creates extreme suffering. Knowing this, the practitioner chooses virtue. This is education, not intimidation. Recognizing signs of hell birth allows the dying person to apply countermeasures—practices, prayers, guru yoga—to redirect the trajectory. View register: signs as navigational warnings, not fixed destinies. Translation risk: signs appearing as irreversible sentences. Preservation: until the moment of death, redirection is possible. The signs indicate current trajectory; practice can change course. The structural note indicates this is "Buddhist hell realm taxonomy for recognizing negative outcomes." View register: taxonomy serving practical recognition, not speculative cosmology. Translation risk: hell-descriptions appearing as fear tactics. Preservation: the purpose is recognition—seeing where destructive actions lead. This empowers the practitioner to avoid creating such causes. In Buddhist view, even hell experiences serve as teachers—extreme suffering creates powerful motivation for liberation. View register: all experiences potentially leading to awakening. Translation risk: justifying suffering or hell. Preservation: not that suffering is good, but that it can be transformative. The Buddha's compassion includes beings in hell, working for their eventual liberation. Crucially, hell is not eternal—no state in samsara is permanent. Eventually, the karma exhausting, the being leaves hell and continues in the cycle. View register: hope within even worst situations. Translation risk: hell's temporariness minimizing its horror. Preservation: while not eternal, hell can last aeons—vast suffering for vast time. This is serious, but not hopeless. This section (11825-12002) presents the complete framework for recognizing signs of hell birth at death. The architecture details the visions and experiences indicating various hell destinations. The view throughout is that these are natural results of destructive actions, not punishments; they serve as warnings and motivations for practice. The translator must preserve the specificity of the hell classifications while conveying that these are experiences created by mind, not external tortures. Breaking samaya with the guru creates especially heavy results, emphasizing the importance of proper relationship. Yet even the worst hell is temporary—all beings eventually find liberation through the Buddha's compassion and their own ripening karma.
02 22 07 01
[12003-12010] Wisdom nature. The wisdom (ye shes) that recognizes ultimate reality. Distinguishing wisdom from ordinary consciousness. Structural function: wisdom analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
02 23 01 01
[12011-12043] Even now it remains in the external-internal nature of how it manifests. Finally, it must be carried in that nature. In primordial purity's expanse, no intermediate state exists—that very self not depending on other dharmas before or after, cannot enter any interval. Because transcending transfer-change and apparent-empty extremes. Citation from Thalgyur: "In primordial purity from the beginning, even delusion-basis cannot be spoken. Likewise, non-delusion also what?" This crucial point, if wisdom exists, is great meaning condensed. Second, etymology: "bar" is central dharma of upper, lower, before, after—like dream intermediate state between sleep and waking. "Ma" indicates center, "do" dwells in center like connecting rope joining beginning and end. Third, divisions: common and uncommon. Common vehicles assert birth-death, dream, dharmatā, existence intermediate states. This uncommon Secret King system has four: nature-remaining, death-time, dharmatā, existence intermediate states. Citation from Thalgyur: "Bardo's dharmatā such, explained as extremely secret dharmatā. Dividing into four aspects." establish the fundamental Dzogchen view: in primordial purity (ka dag), no bardo exists. The structural function: establishing that bardo is not ultimate reality but appearance of non-recognition. View register: bardo as description of delusion, not inherent state. Translation risk: "no bardo" suggesting bardo is unreal or unimportant. Preservation: in ka dag—pure from the beginning—there is no interval because there is no transition; what appears as bardo is non-recognition of what is already the case. The phrase "not depending on other dharmas before or after" (chos gzhan snga phyi la mi ltos shing) establishes bardo's conventional nature. View register: bardo as dependent designation, not self-existing. Translation risk: independence appearing as positive quality. Preservation: the absence of dependence indicates bardo's lack of inherent existence—it exists only relative to transition between states. The Thalgyur citation at lines 12017-12020 emphasizes indescribability: "In primordial purity from the beginning, even delusion-basis cannot be spoken. Likewise, non-delusion also what?" View register: the ground transcends both delusion and non-delusion. Translation risk: citation appearing as paradox for effect. Preservation: in ka dag, there is not even a basis for delusion ( 'khrul gzhi)—the ground is beyond the delusion-realization duality. provide etymology of "bardo" (bar do). "Bar" means interval or center—between upper and lower, before and after, like dream between sleep and waking. "Ma" indicates center. "Do" means two—dwelling in center like connecting rope (sbrel thag) joining beginning and end. View register: bardo as interval, gap, in-between state. Translation risk: "intermediate state" losing the sense of interval. Preservation: the Tibetan emphasizes the "interval" quality—neither this nor that, yet connecting both. The four bardos specific to Dzogchen (lines 12033-12037): rang bzhin bar do (nature-remaining), 'chi kha'i bar do (death-time), chos nyid kyi bar do (dharmatā), srid pa'i bar do (existence/becoming). View register: Dzogchen framework distinct from common Buddhist bardo. Translation risk: conflating with six bardos of other systems. Preservation: these four correspond to the four stages of mind's manifestation—from natural abiding through death to rebirth.
[12044-12100] Fourth, appearance modes has two parts. First, general presentation: three realms' common appearances are grasping-grasper, attachment-aversion, afflictions manifest; subtle form and formless. Six migrations' individual appearances: from single cause water, gods have nectar and so forth. Citation from Denyig: "Although mind is one, different, therefore seen as not established as object." Individual door: to one person Lhaskyin appear as many enemies and friends, happiness-suffering, delusion-non-delusion, attachment-aversion, good-bad, dharma and non-dharma, etc. manifest diversely. Later good-bad karmic causes operate variously. In brief, whoever appears to, like last night's dream good-bad variously appears, yet not established though appearing, operating in clear appearance of non-existence. present the general mode of appearance (snang tshul) in samsara. The structural function: establishing that all appearances are mind's display. View register: appearances as dreamlike, not externally established. Translation risk: "appearances" suggesting objective phenomena. Preservation: snang ba indicates manifestation, display—not solid objects but mind's own showing. The distinction between "common appearances" (spyi snang) of the three realms and "individual appearances" (so so snang) of the six migrations establishes the layers of perception. View register: shared and private dimensions of experience. Translation risk: "common" suggesting objective shared world. Preservation: even "common" appearances are commonly experienced projections, not external realities. The citation from Denyig (bden gnyis) at lines 12050-12052—"Although mind is one, different, therefore seen as not established as object"—establishes the Yogacara view applied in Dzogchen. View register: perception as mind-only, objects as projection. Translation risk: solipsism or idealism. Preservation: "not established as object" (don ma grub pa) indicates lack of external existence, not denial of appearance.
[12101-12200] Particular explanation has four. Nature-remaining bardo's appearances: bound by form aggregates, five bodies' appearance self-cessation; bound by elements and sense-bases, light and color appearance self-cessation; bound by karma and afflictions, wisdom and dharmatā appearance self-cessation. External appearance objects, internal grasper mind attached, difficult to cross the four perverted streams' depths, day and night wandering continuously, operating various karmic latencies. Four perversions: not knowing samsara's delusion-appearance dream-illusion-like nature, grasping impermanent as permanent, untrue as true, suffering cause-effect as happiness, naturally empty as entity and marks. present the nature-remaining bardo (rang bzhin gnas pa'i bar do)—ordinary life as bardo. The structural function: establishing that we are already in bardo. View register: life itself as intermediate state between death and rebirth. Translation risk: "nature-remaining" appearing obscure. Preservation: rang bzhin gnas pa means "naturally abiding"—the natural state that appears as bardo when not recognized. The three types of binding (bcings pa)—aggregates, elements<span class="term">/sense-bases, karma/</span>afflictions—correspond to three dimensions of obscuration. View register: obscurations as opportunities for recognition when their self-liberating nature is seen. Translation risk: "binding" suggesting permanent entrapment. Preservation: "self-cessation" (rang 'gags) indicates that when recognized, bindings naturally release. Death-time bardo's appearances: body elements disturbed, experiencing external body's suffering; mind-born feeling path lost, experiencing internal mind's suffering; latency-grasping lake overflowed, experiencing separation from this life's appearances though attached; non-virtue-virtue karma remembered, experiencing fear of falling into lower realms; cherishing-grasping cared-for body remembered, experiencing fear of aggregates' fortress falling. Actually, if matter and awareness separated, dwelling in fear of death. Dharmatā bardo's appearances: aggregates' self-grasping support abandoned, bodies and wisdoms' dharmatā manifest; karma and latencies' connection cut, enjoying natural samadhi's dharmatā; sense-power grasper's objects emptied, operating in self-appearing luminosity's dharmatā. Existence bardo's appearances: external body's existence, mind-body with complete sense-power moving unimpededly; internal mind's existence, thinking many conceptions and mind entering; body-mind combined existence, moving unimpededly to all except two supports, fear and terror. present the death-time bardo ('chi kha'i bar do)—the process of dying. The structural function: describing what appears as the elements dissolve. View register: death as opportunity for recognition. Translation risk: death appearing as morbid fixation. Preservation: in Dzogchen, death is a crucial opportunity—if recognition happens at death, liberation is achieved. The five sufferings of death time: external body suffering, internal mind suffering, separation from appearances, fear of lower realms, fear of losing the body—establish the intensity of the death experience. View register: these sufferings as signs to recognize, not obstacles. Translation risk: dwelling on suffering as pessimistic. Preservation: awareness of death's intensity motivates practice and prepares recognition. The dharmatā bardo (chos nyid kyi bar do) at lines 12083-12087 presents the clear light experience after death. View register: dharmatā as natural purity manifesting when obscurations dissolve. Translation risk: "dharmatā" appearing as technical abstraction. Preservation: chos nyid means "nature of phenomena"—the way things actually are, which becomes visible when conceptual mind dissolves. describe three aspects of dharmatā bardo: bodies and wisdoms' dharmatā manifesting, enjoying natural samadhi, operating in self-appearing luminosity. View register: death as most profound opportunity for recognition. Translation risk: these appearing as inaccessible to ordinary understanding. Preservation: the description is precise—what happens when the coarse mind dissolves and subtle mind manifests. The existence/becoming bardo (srid pa'i bar do) at lines 12088-12091 describes the intermediate state proper—the "dream body" that can travel without physical limitation. View register: bardo body as last opportunity for recognition before rebirth. Translation risk: bardo body appearing as supernatural. Preservation: the description is phenomenological—what is actually experienced when consciousness is separated from physical body. identify the "two supports" (rten gnis) for rebirth: vajra-seat (blessing-established) and mother's womb. View register: these as the two ways consciousness can reincarnate. Translation risk: literalizing the vajra-seat or mother's womb as only physical. Preservation: in Dzogchen, the vajra-seat (rdo rje'i gdan) is also the pure land of natural purity—not only physical Bodhgaya. mention the "six limits" (mtha' drug) for binding tantra meanings: literal and non-literal, etc. This indicates that bardo descriptions require careful hermeneutics. View register: multiple levels of meaning in bardo teachings. Translation risk: literalizing or over-spiritualizing. Preservation: the six limits prevent both literal materialism and disembodied spiritualism—bardo is actual experience, not mere metaphor. This section (12011-12244) presents the four-bardo system distinctive to Dzogchen. The architecture moves from the fundamental view that bardo is ultimately non-existent in primordial purity, through etymology and classification, to detailed description of each bardo's appearances. The view throughout is that bardo is not merely after death but describes the entire condition of non-recognition. The four bardos—nature-remaining, death-time, dharmatā, existence—represent the complete cycle from life through death to rebirth. The translator must preserve both the technical precision of the descriptions and the ultimate view that bardo is appearance of non-recognition, not inherent reality. The descriptions are phenomenologically precise—what is actually experienced—and serve as maps for recognition, not merely philosophical speculation.
[12201-12230] Transitional passage. The Tibetan text moves from previous topic to next. Wylie: ''od lnga lhun grub kyi btsun mo 'dzom par/ khye'u snang ba d...' This structural marker serves as bridge between doctrinal expositions. The lotsawa recognizes the transition and prepares the reader for the next topic. Structural function: transitional clarity. Register: structural awareness.
[12231-12244] Transitional passage. The Tibetan text moves from previous topic to next. Wylie: '<span class="term">/'byung ba thams cad rang dengs su/</span> /'gyur ba 'di la the tsh...' This structural marker serves as bridge between doctrinal expositions. The lotsawa recognizes the transition and prepares the reader for the next topic. Structural function: transitional clarity. Register: structural awareness.
02 23 02 01
[12245-12350] Aggregate analysis. The basis—the five aggregates (phung po lnga)—as support for sentient existence. Line 12245: 'dang po la gsum ste/...' establishes the structural framework. The cognitive trace recognizes how form, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness constitute the experiential basis. Structural function: aggregates analysis presentation. Register: analytical precision.
02 23 02 02
[12351-12521] Meditation on impermanence (mi rtag pa) and emptiness (stong pa nyid). Impermanent compounded dharmas ('dus byas chos) resemble dream (rmi lam), illusion (sgyu ma). Standard similes: star (skar ma), dust (rdul), eye-disease (rab rib), lamp (mar me), magical-illusion (sgyu ma), dew (thigs pa), water-bubble (chu bur), dream (rmi lam), lightning (glog), cloud (sprin). View register: impermanence as gateway to understanding emptiness. The ten similes represent different aspects of impermanence. Star: visible then gone. Dust: disturbed by slightest wind. Eye-disease: illusory appearance. Lamp: dependent on fuel. Magic: created by conditions, not real. Dew: disappears with sun. Water-bubble: brief formation from conditions. Dream: vivid yet unreal. Lightning: momentary flash. Cloud: forms and disperses. View register: phenomena as like these—appearing briefly, dependent on conditions, without substance. Life impermanent like dream (rmi lam lta bu)—dream establishment not exists (rmi lam gtan la phab pa med). Dreams appear vivid and real, yet have no substantial existence. View register: waking life as dreamlike. Translation risk: "like dream" suggesting unreality in nihilistic sense. Preservation: dreams are real experiences with unreal objects; waking life is similar—experience is real, objects are empty. Life like rushing water (chu bo)—by falling water not sit as one (chu 'bab pas gcig tu mi sdod). Water never rests in one place, constantly flowing. View register: life as constant flux. Translation risk: water simile appearing cliché. Preservation: the force of 'bab pa (falling, rushing) indicates the momentum of samsara—life moves on, cannot be held. Life like wind not grasped (rlung bzung du med)—by wind beings not seized (rlung gis sems can mi 'dzin). Wind cannot be grasped or held; likewise life. View register: life's ungraspable nature. Translation risk: "grasped" suggesting understanding. Preservation: 'dzin pa means physically grasping—you cannot hold wind in your hand; you cannot hold life. It moves through your fingers. Life like short-duration emanation (sprul pa)—emanation not remain always (sprul pa rtag tu mi gnas). Magical emanations appear temporarily then dissolve. View register: body as emanation. Translation risk: "emanation" suggesting magical creation. Preservation: sprul pa indicates apparent form without substantial basis—the body appears, functions, then dissolves, like a magician's creation. Life like not-true magical-illusion (sgyu ma)—magical illusion true ground not seized (sgyu ma bden gzung ma byung). Magic appears real but has no true ground. View register: groundlessness of phenomena. Translation risk: "not-true" suggesting deception. Preservation: sgyu ma is not deceit but appearance without substance—the magician isn't lying, but the elephant isn't really there. Life like not-staying traveler (lam 'gro)—traveler not always sit (lam 'gro rtag tu mi sdod pa). Travelers rest briefly then move on; life is journey without permanent rest. View register: life as pilgrimage, not destination. Translation risk: traveler simile appearing trivial. Preservation: the lam 'gro (path-goer) is on a journey—life is the journey, death the next stage. The point is non-remaining. These are standard Buddhist contemplations applied to Dzogchen practice motivation. The structural note emphasizes this application. View register: impermanence as motivation, not discouragement. Translation risk: impermanence inducing nihilism or despair. Preservation: impermanence is freeing—if everything changes, liberation is possible. The contemplation motivates practice by showing the urgency. Impermanence serves as gateway to emptiness—by seeing that phenomena are impermanent, one understands they lack inherent existence. View register: impermanence revealing emptiness. Translation risk: impermanence as separate from emptiness. Preservation: in Madhyamaka, impermanence proves lack of svabhava—inherent existence would require permanence. Contemplating impermanence opens to seeing emptiness. "Compounded dharmas" ('dus byas chos) are conditioned phenomena—those arising from causes and conditions. Only compounded dharmas are impermanent; the uncompounded (nirvana) is not. View register: conditioned vs. unconditioned distinction. Translation risk: "compounded" suggesting complexity. Preservation: 'dus byas means assembled or compounded—put together from parts and conditions. This excludes the unconditioned, which is permanent. "Dream establishment not exists" (rmi lam gtan la phab pa med) indicates dreams cannot be established as real—they appear but lack substantial existence. View register: appearances without establishment. Translation risk: "not exists" suggesting non-existence. Preservation: med pa means cannot be established as real—dreams certainly appear (snang), but cannot be proven substantial (bden par grub pa). The application to Dzogchen practice: understanding impermanence motivates seeking the unconditioned—recognizing that all compounded phenomena are impermanent and unsatisfactory, one turns to the primordial purity which is neither arising nor ceasing. View register: impermanence pointing beyond itself. Translation risk: impermanence as merely depressing. Preservation: the contemplation leads to Dzogchen—seeing all is impermanent, one seeks the impermanent ground, which is ka dag. The similes emphasize that phenomena are vivid (gsal) yet unreal (bden med)—like dreams, illusions, mirages. This is not nihilism but accurate description. View register: appearance and emptiness as compatible. Translation risk: vivid OR unreal (either/or). Preservation: the teaching is vivid AND unreal—appearances are clear and distinct, yet lack inherent existence. This is the middle way. While the similes are standard Buddhist, Dzogchen applies them distinctively—not to induce renunciation only, but to recognize the dreamlike nature as the play of rigpa. View register: impermanence recognized as display. Translation risk: standard application only. Preservation: in Dzogchen, impermanence is not just a reason to renounce samsara, but a characteristic of rigpa's display—empty yet apparent. These contemplations are integrated into Dzogchen practice—not merely preliminary, but ongoing recognition. Every appearance recognized as impermanent and dreamlike is seen as rigpa's play. View register: integration of view and practice. Translation risk: contemplations as merely preliminary. Preservation: while these are often preliminary practices (sngon 'gro), in Dzogchen they continue as recognition—seeing impermanence is seeing the nature of display. This section (12351-12521) presents the standard Buddhist contemplations on impermanence and emptiness through ten similes, applied specifically to Dzogchen practice motivation. The architecture uses familiar similes—star, dust, dream, lightning—to establish the fleeting, insubstantial nature of phenomena. The view throughout is that impermanence is not merely a reason for renunciation but a characteristic of rigpa's display—recognizing phenomena as impermanent and dreamlike is recognizing their true nature. The translator must preserve the similes' evocative power while conveying that these are not depressing truths but liberating recognitions. The dream simile is particularly important—life is like a dream, vivid yet unreal, and recognizing this is the beginning of waking up to the true nature of mind.
02 23 03 01
[12522-12778] Signs of death in bardo—the visionary appearances indicating approach of death in the intermediate state. In space realm (mkha' spyod), reflections become impermanent and dissolve—this dissolution indicates death approaching. Specific signs: when limbs break in four pieces, death in four months. When head breaks above, in three months. When upper and lower separate, in two months. When rolled into ball, in one month. Connection cord of sky-earth—if cut, cannot exceed nineteen days. From Mount Meru sides, White Lioness not descending—in sixteen days cannot but befall. Between mountain and plain, wish-fulfilling tree trunk breaks—these examined by wise ones. Ocean water vapor dissolves—divided by wise in sequence. Structural function: detailed signs for recognizing approaching death in Dzogchen bardo teachings. These signs appear in the becoming bardo (srid pa'i bar do) or in advanced practitioners' visionary experience, indicating the remaining time before death or transition. The structural function: providing objective indicators for subjective experience. View register: signs as natural phenomena to be recognized, not feared. Translation risk: signs appearing as divination or superstition. Preservation: these are visionary experiences with specific time correlations—like medical symptoms indicating prognosis, these signs indicate temporal trajectory. The "space realm" (mkha' spyod) refers to the visionary space of bardo experience where appearances manifest. "Reflections become impermanent and dissolve" (gzugs brnyan mi rtag 'gags) indicates that stable visionary forms begin to break down. View register: dissolution as natural process, not catastrophe. Translation risk: dissolution appearing as loss or failure. Preservation: 'gags pa means "cease" or "dissolve"—the forms that appeared stabilize in bardo now dissolve, indicating transition. This is natural, like ice melting. When visionary "limbs break in four" (yan lag bzhi chag), this indicates death in four months. The four limbs represent the four elements or four directions; their breaking indicates elemental dissolution beginning. View register: body symbolism in visionary experience. Translation risk: literalizing as physical limb injury. Preservation: this is visionary—seeing one's own bardo body limbs breaking apart. The four months indicate the time required for complete elemental dissolution. When the "head breaks above" (mgo gong chag), death in three months. The head represents consciousness and the space element; its breaking indicates the dissolution of the most subtle element. View register: hierarchical dissolution from gross to subtle. Translation risk: gruesome imagery disturbing practice. Preservation: chag here means "break" in the sense of dissolving structure—like a building crumbling. The three months indicate accelerated dissolution as subtler elements destabilize. When "upper and lower separate" (stod smad so sor), death in two months. This indicates the dissociation of the body's energetic polarity—upper centers separating from lower centers, wisdom winds from karmic winds. View register: separation as loss of integration. Translation risk: spatial literalism. Preservation: stod smad refers to the two halves of the subtle body—when they separate, the cohesive energy that maintains form dissipates. Two months indicate rapid approach. When "rolled into ball" (gyang glom), death in one month. The ball indicates the gathering of remaining energies into a condensed form—the final coalescence before complete dissolution. View register: ball as final gathering, not defeat. Translation risk: imagery appearing claustrophobic. Preservation: glom means "gathered" or "rolled"—the scattered energies now condense, preparing for final transition. One month indicates imminent change. The "connection cord of sky-earth" (gnam sa'i sbrel thag) represents the energetic link between the upper and lower chakras, between wisdom and manifestation. "If cut, cannot exceed nineteen days" indicates that when this central channel connection breaks, death is very near. View register: cord as vital connection, not bondage. Translation risk: "cut" suggesting violence. Preservation: sbrel thag means "connecting rope"—the energetic link that maintains embodied existence. When it "cuts," separation is imminent. "From Mount Meru sides, White Lioness not descending" (ri rab gshog gzhir seng ge dkar mo ma babs) indicates that the descending white energy (associated with method and white essence) fails to manifest. View register: symbolism of directions and energies. Translation risk: mythological imagery obscuring meaning. Preservation: Mount Meru represents the central channel; the White Lioness represents the descending white bindu. When it doesn't descend, the balance is lost—death in sixteen days. "Between mountain and plain, wish-fulfilling tree trunk breaks" (ri thang bar dpag bsam shing gi sdong po chag) indicates the breaking of the central axis that supports existence. The wish-fulfilling tree represents the tree of life, the central channel as source of all manifestation. View register: tree as axis mundi, central channel. Translation risk: botanical literalism. Preservation: dpag bsam shing is the mythical tree that grants all wishes—here representing the central channel that sustains life. Its breaking indicates the root of existence destabilizing. "Ocean water vapor dissolves" (rgya mtsho chu yi rlangs pa 'gags) indicates the evaporation of the water element's supporting energy. The ocean represents the vast basis; water vapor its manifesting power. View register: water as life-sustaining element. Translation risk: meteorological literalism. Preservation: rlangs pa is steam or vapor—the capacity of water to sustain life. When this dissolves, the water element can no longer support embodied existence. The phrase "examined by wise ones" (mkhas pas brtags) and "divided by wise in sequence" (rim pas mkhas pas dbye) indicates that these signs require interpretation by those who know the bardo teachings. View register: wisdom needed to read the signs correctly. Translation risk: elitism or obscurantism. Preservation: mkhas pa means "skilled" or "knowing"—those trained in these teachings can interpret the signs. This is not secret-keeping but specialized knowledge, like medical diagnosis. The temporal correlations—four months, three months, two months, one month, nineteen days, sixteen days—are approximate indicators, not mechanical predictions. Individual constitution and practice affect timing. View register: time as flexible, not fixed. Translation risk: rigid timeframes creating anxiety. Preservation: these are guidelines—some may transition faster, some slower. The practitioner uses these to gauge remaining time for practice, not to create fear. These signs serve practical function—they alert the practitioner to intensify practice, complete preparations, or apply specific death-bed techniques. For advanced practitioners, recognizing these signs allows conscious navigation of death. View register: signs as navigational aids, not omens. Translation risk: fatalistic acceptance or anxious avoidance. Preservation: knowing the signs empowers the practitioner—like knowing weather signs allows preparation. The bardo practitioner is a navigator, not a victim. These signs appear in the context of Thögal (thod rgal) practice where visionary experiences are cultivated and recognized. The signs of death in bardo mirror the signs of successful Thögal practice—dissolution of forms, light manifestations, elemental transformation. View register: death and practice as continuous. Translation risk: conflating death signs with practice signs. Preservation: the same visionary dynamics operate in both—the practitioner familiar with Thögal recognizes death signs as familiar territory. This section (12522-12778) presents the complete framework of death signs in the bardo context. The architecture moves from general dissolution indicators to specific temporal signs, establishing a systematic method for recognizing approaching death. The view throughout is that death gives warning signs that can be recognized by the wise, allowing conscious preparation and transition. The translator must preserve the visionary symbolism while conveying that these are actual experiences in advanced practice and bardo states, not mere metaphor. The signs operate at multiple levels—physical, energetic, visionary—providing comprehensive indication of the transition from embodied existence to the next state. The practitioner who knows these signs is not caught by surprise but navigates the transition with awareness and confidence.

[12779-12814] Dzogchen death practice introduces consciousness transference method through AH red combined with HUM throwing visualization. Initial stage establishes colored syllables as energetic vehicles. Red AH represents vital essence; HUM serves as consciousness vehicle. Final throwing phase executed without ordinary conceptual engagement—direct energetic projection beyond discursive thought. Tshur gyi gsum ka involves drawing three HUMs inward to three doors: body, speech, and mind. This visualization setup creates integration of all aspects of being into single point of recognition. Practice framework establishes essential structure for death moment liberation.
[12815-12842] HUM visualization technical precision: awareness visualized as blue HUM drawn to own rigpa; speech HUM drawn to lower door. Body, speech, and mind—three doors—are strengthened through this practice. Breath and HUM coordination increases body-speech-mind strength. Drawn with HUM HUM: consciousness drawn inside through specific energetic manipulation. At that time, other's wind—hot and cold—enters own interior. Result certainty established: success indicators demonstrate effective practice application.
[12843-12880] Eye recognition marks crucial transition: that time, other's eyes coming HRIK—flash of recognition. Then body able to stand HAR—signs of successful energetic manipulation. Having arisen thus, eye thusness shown. Dharmata bardo direct appearance manifests. Thigle introduction: eye HAR arisen, bindu emptiness lamp appears. Thumb and finger introduction method points directly to nature. Clear light self-existing in self revealed. This now: when exiting body, dharmata bardo's self-appearance manifests—not other, but own nature. Essence pointing direct recognition.
[12881-12920] Recognition instruction: self-recognize through three times struck—definitive pointing. Seeing that appearance, hearing that instruction. Voice emerging: good sign. Sign arisen: also struck—confirmation signs establish recognition. Dharmata bardo non-thinking samadhi obtained. Certain: becoming Buddha. Result assurance through direct recognition. Nyi zla kha sbyor citation provides authoritative scriptural support. Compassion and benefit extension: if performing others' benefit, compassion grasping self. Three doors opened. Breath held, drawn, thrown. Three syllables inserted for altruistic extension.
[12921-12960] Practice repetition develops stability: doing again and again, appearance becomes thus. If body strength obtained, bestow instructions. Consciousness clear, place equally. Progressive development establishes capacity. Faculty doors and eye thusness: doors of faculties in own presence. Eye thusness placed looking. Equal remaining mind arises. Non-thinking samadhi obtained—complete practice realization.
[12961-13020] Hitting instruction called tshang sprugs—robe-shake method. Great Perfection essential point. Gathering faculties, hitting clarity. Key of reversing death—critical method. Comprehensive practice summary: AH red HUM throwing, three HUMs drawing in, strength increase certainty, eye recognition liberation, thigle introduction essence, three strikes recognition, samadhi Buddha result. Death practice importance: time of death crucial juncture. Practice determines outcome. Recognition brings liberation; non-recognition leads to continuation.
[13021-13080] Altruistic dimension integrates self and others: self-benefit through recognition, others' benefit through compassion. Both integrated. Opening three doors enables benefit for others. Technical precision: HUM color blue, location lower door, breath specific pattern, visualization clear and precise. Result certainty: wind entering influences other, eye recognition self-liberates, samadhi Buddha certain.
[13081-13160] Practice integration: AH initial, HUM main practice, thigle recognition, samadhi result—all together complete path. Contemporary relevance: ancient method maintains timeless application. Modern death same process; practice remains effective. Recognition still essential. Final summary: death practice complete instructions, three doors opened, recognition achieved, liberation certain. Ultimate pointing: practice points to nature, nature beyond practice, recognition already present, liberation already complete.
[13161-13240] Closing dedication extends benefit: may practice benefit beings, may death be liberation, may all recognize nature, may all be freed. Death practice represents pinnacle of practical instruction—method for achieving liberation at crucial moment of death through precise energetic manipulation and recognition. Practice centers on syllable HUM, visualized as blue at lower door, serving as consciousness vehicle. Through specific breathing patterns—holding, drawing in, throwing—combined with visualization of three HUMs at three doors, practitioner increases strength of body, speech, and mind.
